Record: 1
Title:
(Un)natural boundaries: Mixed race, gender, and sexuality.
Authors:
Allman, Karen Maeda, U Washington, Seattle, WA, US
Source:
The multiracial experience: Racial borders as the new frontier. Root, Maria P. P. (Ed); pp. 277-290; Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; 1996. xxviii, 481 pp.
Page Count:
14
ISBN:
0-8039-7058-7 (Hardcover)
0-8039-7059-5 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
interactions between social constructs of race & gender & sexuality in mixed-race lesbian identity
Abstract:
argue . . . that race and gender are not fixed or natural properties of individuals, but, rather, social constructs with real world consequences / race and gender are mutually co-constructive, shifting and historically situated idea systems that not only shape how individuals and groups perceive themselves and others, but also aid us in organizing and trying to make sense of ourselves as embodied beings / propose that race, gender, and sexuality exist as a sort of unstable triad; shifts in one create disturbances in the other two racialized gender / mixed blood/lesbian interruptions / mixed-race lesbian identity (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Interracial Offspring; *Lesbianism; *Social Identity; Ethnic Identity
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 2
Title:
'...But...But I am Brown.' The ascribed categories of identity: Children and young people of mixed parentage.
Authors:
Goodyer, Annabel, London South Bank University, London, United Kingdom
Okitikpi, Toyin, Aventure, United Kingdom, toyinokitikpi@hotmail.com
Address:
Okitikpi, Toyin, FRSA, 33 Creighton Road, Queens Park, London, United Kingdom, NW6 6EE, toyinokitikpi@hotmail.com
Source:
Child Care in Practice, Vol 13(2), Apr, 2007. pp. 83-94.
Page Count:
12
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
1357-5279 (Print)
1476-489X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed parentage, children, categorization of social groups, racial identity, young people, ascribed categories of identity
Abstract:
This paper explores the concept of the categorization of social groups by looking at the issue of ascribed categories of identity for children and young people of mixed parentage. Our exploration of the knowledge-base in this area reveals that children and young people have clearly expressed views about their racial identity and that these views are broadly consistent across research studies. In essence, children and young people's expressed views are that they are not mixed-race, black or white, but are in fact brown. The emerging sociology of childhood and the government's current child participation agenda emphasize the centrality of children and young peoples' perspectives on the provision of services that seek to support them. Through this perception, which places children and young people's own understandings of their racial identity at the forefront of the analysis, we added fresh understandings to the existing data concerning ascribed categories of identity for children and young people of mixed parentage. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Interracial Offspring; *Social Groups
PsycINFO Classification:
Psychosocial & Personality Development (2840)

Record: 3
Title:
‘Browning’ the Black/White beauty binary.
Authors:
Phoenix, Aisha
Source:
European Journal of Women's Studies, Vol 17(2), May, 2010. pp. 166-168.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Reviewed Item:
Tate, Shirley Anne. (2009) Black Beauty: Aesthetics, Stylization, Politics Aldershot: Ashgate, 180 pp 978-0-7546-7145-9.
ISSN:
1350-5068 (Print)
1461-7420 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Black women, beauty, aesthetics, politics, racism
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Black Beauty: Aesthetics, Stylization, Politics by Shirley Anne Tate (2009). This book seeks to counter representations that depict black women as 'dupes of patriarchy and racism' who lack beauty agency and 'yearn for whiteness'. This book maintains that through stylization black women are ‘expanding the boundaries of what counts as black beauty', rather than 'inscribing a white aesthetic onto their bodies'. The book argues that 'Black mixed race' women use fake tan to become 'browning'. While their behavior mimics that of white people who wish to be brown, she suggests that the young women do not want to be white, rather, through fake tanning they ‘radically revalue dark skin positively' and subvert ‘the colonial priority of "race" in which white was right'. Perhaps the most controversial points the book makes are about skin bleaching. The book challenges the tendency for black women's beauty work to be automatically associated with a desire to be white. The book also problematizes the invisibility of politics in white women's beauty work and urges readers to consider the 'race' work inherent in white women’s beauty practices. The concludes that a non-essentialist, inclusive black politics is required that 'disrupts white supremacy's light skin privilege which seeks to place darker-skinned, kinkier-haired women outside of beauty itself'. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Aesthetics; *Blacks; *Politics; *Racism
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Review-Book
Release Date:
20101101
Copyright:
The Author(s). 2010
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1177/13505068100170020503
Accession Number:
2010-09767-007
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2010-09767-007&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2010-09767-007&site=ehost-live&scope=site

Record: 4
Title:
‘Keeping the story alive’: Is ethnic and racial dilution inevitable for multiracial people and their children?
Authors:
Song, Miri, University of Kent, Canterbury, England, a.m.song@kent.ac.uk
Gutierrez, Caitlin O'Neill, University of Kent, Canterbury, England, caitlin.oneill.g@gmail.com
Address:
Song, Miri, a.m.song@kent.ac.uk
Source:
The Sociological Review, Vol 63(3), Aug, 2015. pp. 680-698.
Page Count:
19
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
US : Routledge & Kegan Paul
US : Sherratt Hughes
US : Sociological Publications Ltd.
United Kingdom : University College of North Staffordshire
ISSN:
0038-0261 (Print)
1467-954X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed race, parenting, dilution, ancestry, children, whitening, identification
Abstract:
This paper explores how multiracial parents with White partners articulate narratives of ethnic and racial ‘dilution’ and cultural loss in relation to the socialization of their children. In our broader study of how multiracial parents raise their children, we found that parents commonly spoke of concerns around dilution and generational change in relation to four key themes: the loss of cultural knowledge and diminishing practices that connected parents and their children to a minority ancestry; the embodiment of White‐appearing children and the implications of this for family relationships; the use of biological or genetic discourses in relation to reduced blood quantum; and concerns amongst Black/White participants about whitening and the loss of racial consciousness. Parental understandings of dilution varied greatly; some expressed sadness at ‘inevitable’ loss; others were more philosophical about generational change; and others still proactively countered loss through strategies to connect their children to their minority heritages. We show that despite growing awareness of the social constructedness of race and an emergent cosmopolitanism among these parents, discourses of genetics, cultural lineage, and the ‘naturalness’ of race continue to hold sway amongst many multiracial parents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Parent Child Relations; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:

Male
Female

Thirties (30-39 yrs)
Middle Age (40-64 yrs)
Methodology:

Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Publication History:
Accepted: Mar 17, 2015; First Submitted: Jul 2, 2014
Release Date:
20150921
Copyright:
The Authors. The Sociological Review—The Editorial Board of The Sociological Review. 2015
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1111/1467-954X.12308
Accession Number:
2015-40664-004

https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2015-40664-004&site=ehost-live&scope=site

Record: 5
Title:
A clearer picture of multiracial substance use: Rates and correlates of alcohol and tobacco use in multiracial adolescents and adults.
Authors:
Chavez, George F., Department of Psychology, Rutgers, State University of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, US, gchavez@eden.rutgers.edu
Sanchez, Diana T., Department of Psychology, Rutgers, State University of New Jersey, New Brunswick, NJ, US
Address:
Chavez, George F., Department of Psychology, Rutgers, State University of New Jersey, 53 Avenue E, Piscataway, New Brunswick, NJ, US, 08854-8040, gchavez@eden.rutgers.edu
Source:
Race and Social Problems, Vol 2(1), Mar, 2010. pp. 1-18.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
1867-1748 (Print)
1867-1756 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multiracial substance use, alcohol use, tobacco use, adolescents, adulthood, cross cultural differences
Abstract:
Existing studies indicate that multiracial adolescents face greater substance use rates than monoracial adolescents. However, it is unclear whether the risk identified in adolescence persists into adulthood. The current study uses data from the 2001 California Health Interview Survey to analyze the alcohol and tobacco use of multiracial adolescents and adults compared to European American, African American, Native American, Asian/Pacific Islander American, and Latino American individuals. Results generally support the hypothesis that multiracial adolescents and adults face higher rates of substance use than African American and Asian/Pacific Islander American individuals, though this pattern of results was reversed in comparison with Native Americans and European Americans, and less consistent compared to Latino Americans. We further establish and discuss the correlates of drinking and smoking behavior for mixed-race individuals—comparing them to other racial groups. We review the limitations of our design and the implications for future research on multiracial substance use. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Age Differences; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Drug Usage; *Risk Factors; Adolescent Development; Adult Development; Alcohol Abuse; Tobacco Smoking
PsycINFO Classification:
Drug & Alcohol Usage (Legal) (2990)

20111010

Record: 6
Title:
A cognitive-behavioral mechanism leading to adolescent obesity: Children's social images and physical activity.
Authors:
Hampson, Sarah E., University of Surrey, Guildford, United Kingdom, sarah@ori.org
Andrews, Judy A., Oregon Research Institute, Eugene, OR, US
Peterson, Missy, Oregon Research Institute, Eugene, OR, US
Duncan, Susan C., Oregon Research Institute, Eugene, OR, US
Address:
Hampson, Sarah E., Oregon Research Institute, 1715 Franklin Boulevard, Eugene, OR, US, 97403, sarah@ori.org
Source:
Annals of Behavioral Medicine, Vol 34(3), Nov, 2007. pp. 287-294.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
US : Lawrence Erlbaum
Other Journal Titles:
Behavioral Medicine Update
Other Publishers:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0883-6612 (Print)
1532-4796 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
adolescent obesity, influence of social images of other children, physical activity
Abstract:
Background: Increasing levels of youth obesity constitute a threat to the nation's health, and identification of the influences during childhood that lead to youth obesity is urgently needed. Physical activity is one such influence that is potentially modifiable. Purpose: This study examined the influence of children's social images of other children who engage in physical activity on the development of their own physical activity over 3 years and related growth in physical activity to levels of obesity 2 years later. Methods: Participants (N = 846, 50% female) were members of the Oregon Youth Substance Use Project, a longitudinal study of a community sample. The racial/ethnic composition of the sample was 86% Caucasian; 7% Hispanic; 1% Black; and approximately 2% each of Asian/Pacific Islander, American Indian, or Alaskan Native, and other or mixed race/ethnicity. The mean age at the first assessment was 9.5 years. A model examining the effect of early social images on the growth of physical activity (athleticism modeled as a curve of factors) predicting obesity was evaluated using latent growth modeling. Results: More favorable social images predicted the initial levels (i.e., intercept) but not the change over time (i.e., slope) of children's athleticism, and both the intercept and the slope of athleticism predicted obesity. Conclusions: Children's social images of exercise in early childhood influence their subsequent activity levels, and hence obesity, and should be targeted in obesity prevention interventions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Obesity; *Physical Activity; *Social Influences; *Social Perception
PsycINFO Classification:
Developmental Psychology (2800)
Eating Disorders (3260)
Population:

Male
Female

US

School Age (6-12 yrs)
Adolescence (13-17 yrs)
Grant Sponsorship:
Sponsor: National Institute on Drug Abuse
Grant Number: DA 10767
Recipients: No recipient indicated
Methodology:

Format Covered:

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1007/BF02874553
PMID:
18020938

Record: 7
Title:
A contemporary argument for the recognition of global mixed race populations.
Authors:
Sandoval, J. S. Onésimo
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 60(4), 2015.
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
King-O’Riain, Rebecca C. (Ed); Small, Stephen (Ed); Mahtani, Minelle (Ed); Song, Miri (Ed); Spickard, Paul (Ed). (2014) Global Mixed Race New York, NY: New York University Press. 335pp. $79.00 HC $26.00 PB 978-0-8147-7073-3 (Hardcover); 978-0-8147-8915-5 (Paperback).
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
global mixed race, mixed populations, mixed descent, societies, social construction, concepts
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Global Mixed Race by Rebecca C. King-O’Riain, Stephen Small, Minelle Mahtani, Miri Song, and Paul Spickard (see record 2014-20689-000). The book is composed of 11 chapters organized around two levels of research: (1) societies with established populations of mixed descent, and (2) societies with newer populations of mixed descent. The chapters offer the reader a rich narrative that explores the complex process of the social construction of concepts that describe populations around the world that are mixed race or mixed descent or populations that have mixed identities. The book as a whole and many of the chapters do make a significant contribution to the general understanding of mixed populations around the world. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)

*Concepts; *Globalization; *Population; *Race (Anthropological); *Society

Record: 8
Title:
A darker shade of pale revisited: Disaggregated Blackness and colorism in the 'post-racial' Obama era.
Parent Book Series:
New directions in American history
Authors:
Banks, Taunya Lovell, University of Maryland, School of Law, Baltimore, MD, US
Source:
Color matters: Skin tone bias and the myth of a postracial America. Norwood, Kimberly Jade (Ed); pp. 95-117; New York, NY, US: Routledge/Taylor & Francis Group; 2014. vii, 248 pp.
Page Count:
23
ISBN:
978-0-415-51774-4 (Hardcover)
978-0-415-51775-1 (Paperback)
978-1-315-81933-4 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Blackness, colorism, Obama, black Americans, light-skinned black elites, white Americans, whiteness, racial inequality, antidiscrimination laws, skin tone, racial classification, racial self-identification, socioeconomic status, color, post-racial
Abstract:
The election of Barack Hussein Obama as the forty-fourth president of the United States suggests that conventional notions of blackness are being disaggregated. The old hypodescent rule has lost its power to define who is black and who is not, especially for light-skinned black Americans and individuals with some African ancestry and one white parent. Further, conventional racial designations today may be less important than factors such as skin tone, especially when combined with traditional tropes of high-status whiteness like elite education, stable family structure, high socioeconomic status, and "command of spoken English." Empirical research suggests the existence of a small group of light-skinned black elites that dates back to the antebellum era who were able to accumulate and pass on small amounts of wealth. The intergenerational transfer of even small amounts of wealth created opportunities for their descendants not available to most black Americans. Today, these' descendants still benefit from the advantages created as a result of light skin tone and relative economic success. This group and the mixed-race children of one white parent are posed to move beyond unitary blackness into a middle group between white and most black Americans. The movement away from unitary blackness may result in a pigmentocracy that reinforces whiteness even as the country becomes less white. One byproduct of this change is that racial inequality between those raced as white and black will become more severe. Twentieth-century antidiscrimination laws that treat blackness as one-dimensional are ill equipped to combat more subtle race-based discrimination. This chapter explores whether skin tone, rather than racial classification or racial self-identification, will, in the near future, determine who gets better access to quality education, jobs, and real power in America; in other words, does color and socioeconomic status, more than old racial classification schemes, matter in the "post-racial" Obama era and, if so; what are the legal implications of this development? (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Ethnic Identity; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Racism; *Social Discrimination; Color; Laws; Self Concept; Skin (Anatomy); Socioeconomic Status; Whites

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2013-37399-004&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2013-37399-004&site=ehost-live&scope=site">A darker shade of pale revisited: Disaggregated Blackness and colorism in the 'post-racial' Obama era.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 9
Title:
A Feminist Critique of Research on Interracial Family Identity: Implications for Family Health.
Authors:
Byrd, Marcia M., Nursing Department, College of St. Catherine, St. Paul, MN, US, mmbyrd@stkate.edu
Garwick, Ann W., Center for Child and Family Health Promotion Research, School of Nursing, University of Minnesota, MN, US
Address:
Byrd, Marcia M., College of St. Catherine, Department of Nursing, F-22, 2004 Randolph Avenue, St. Paul, MN, US, 55105, mmbyrd@stkate.edu
Source:
Journal of Family Nursing, Vol 10(3), Aug, 2004. pp. 302-322.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
1074-8407 (Print)
1552-549X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
family identity, identity formation, Black-White interracial reltionships, biracial children, health promotion
Abstract:
The focus of this literature review is on family identity formation within a social cultural context for families, couples, and women who are in committed Black-White interracial relationships that include biracial children. This review and synthesis of interdisciplinary literature was limited to U.S. research studies completed between 1990 and 2002. The American racial lens represented the environmental context that this article seeks to capture. Health care providers lack knowledge of this complex mixed-race family identity formation and its implications for healthy interracial families. Family nurses who can assess and intervene in a culturally competent manner will be essential to promoting health and eliminating health disparities for these interracial families of color. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Title:
A field study of race and age similarity effects on interview ratings in conventional and situational interviews.
Authors:
Lin, Thung-rung, Los Angeles Unified School District Personnel Commission, Personnel Selection Branch, CA, US
Dobbins, Gregory H.
Farh, Jiing-lih
Source:
Journal of Applied Psychology, Vol 77(3), Jun, 1992. pp. 363-371.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
ISSN:
0021-9010 (Print)
1939-1854 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race & age similarity, outcome ratings in conventional structured vs situational panel employment interview, Black & White & Hispanic interviewers & interviewees
Abstract:
Examined the effects of interviewer and interviewee race and age similarity on interview outcomes under 2 different interview formats: a conventional structured panel interview and a situational panel interview. A total of 2,805 applicants were interviewed. The panels consisted of same-, mixed-, or different-race and same-, mixed-, or different-age groups. Analyses revealed stronger same-race effects with the conventional structured interview than with the situational interview. Furthermore, these same-race effects could be avoided by using mixed-race interview panels. No age similarity effects were detected with either interview procedure. Implications for future research and practice are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Age Differences; *Interviewers; *Job Applicant Interviews; *Job Applicants; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Blacks; Whites; Latinos/Latinas
PsycINFO Classification:
Personnel Management & Selection & Training (3620)
Population:
Human
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Methodology:
Empirical Study; Interview
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Publication History:

Release Date:
19921001

<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=1992-37226-001&site=ehost-live&scope=site">A field study of race and age similarity effects on interview ratings in conventional and situational interviews.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO

A Field Study of Race and Age Similarity Effects on Interview Ratings in Conventional and Situational Interviews

By: Thung-Rung Lin
Personnel Selection Branch, Los Angeles Unified School District, Los Angeles, California;
Gregory H. Dobbins
Department of Management, University of Tennessee
Jiing-Lih Farh
Department of Management, Louisiana State University

Acknowledgement: All three authors contributed equally to this research. The project was partially funded by the Business Services Divsion and the Personnel Commission, Los Angeles Unified School District. An earlier version of this article was presented at the 51st Annual Meeting of the Academy of Management, Miami, 1991.

We would like to thank Bradford C. Petersen and Carol L. Manligas for their assistance in data collection, Anita Ford and I. A. Ryanen for their suggestions and support, and three anonymous reviewers for their helpful comments.

The employment interview is the most commonly used selection procedure and has been examined in literally hundreds of studies (Cascio, 1991). This research has focused on topics such as the reliability and validity of the interview, the information processing of interviewers, and the effects of demographic variables on interview outcomes (see Eder & Ferris, 1989, for a review).

Harris (1989) conducted an extensive review of the selection interview literature and identified several areas in need of future research. He proposed that more research should (a) investigate the effects of race and age on interview ratings and (b) directly compare various interview strategies. The present study responded to both of these recommendations. Specifically, we investigated whether age and race similarity between interviewer and interviewee influenced interview outcomes and whether these effects were moderated by interview type (conventional structured panel interviews vs. situational panel interviews).

Interviewer–Interviewee Race Similarity

Surprisingly few studies have investigated the effects of interviewer and interviewee race on interview outcomes. There has been more research on the effects of race on performance evaluations. Because an interview is, to some extent, a performance evaluation of how well the applicant responds to an interviewer's questions, both the interview and performance evaluation research shall be briefly reviewed.

One major research orientation has been the assumption that minority applicants are evaluated less favorably than are majority applicants. Although this hypothesis is consistent with a large body of research in social cognition (e.g., Fiske & Taylor, 1984), it has not been consistently supported. Whereas some studies have found that Whites are rated more favorably than are Blacks (e.g., Parsons & Liden, 1984; Sackett, DuBois, & Noe, 1991), most research indicates that interview ratings of Blacks and Whites do not differ (Campion, Pursell, & Brown, 1988; see Arvey & Faley, 1988, for a review). Furthermore, even when Blacks and Whites receive different ratings, the variance accounted for by race tends to be very small (e.g., Kraiger & Ford, 1985; Landy & Farr, 1980). In addition, some studies have found that Blacks are actually rated more favorably than are Whites (e.g., McIntyre, Moberg, & Posner, 1980).

Most research has neglected the interaction between interviewer and interviewee race on interview ratings. Rand and Wexley (1975) proposed that raters will tend to give higher ratings to individuals who are similar to them. This “similar-to-me” effect is consistent with research that indicates that individuals like others who they believe are similar to them (e.g., Clark & Fiske, 1982) and liking affects performance ratings (Cardy & Dobbins, 1986). Thus, it seems likely that interviewers should exhibit a same-race bias, that is, give higher ratings to same-race interviewees than to different-race interviewees.

Several studies have investigated the similar-to-me hypothesis. Studies using resumes (e.g., Peters & Terborg, 1975) and videotapes (e.g., Rand & Wexley, 1975) found that when a subject observed an interviewee similar to him- or herself, the subject liked the interviewee more, viewed the interviewee as more qualified, and rated the interviewee as more suitable for hiring relative to a dissimilar interviewee. Furthermore, Pulakos and Wexley (1983) found that perceived similarity affected managers' ratings of subordinate performance. After their extensive review of performance appraisal research, Landy and Farr (1980) concluded, “Ratees tend to receive higher ratings from raters of the same race” (p. 82). In a meta-analysis of ratee race effects on performance ratings, Kraiger and Ford (1985) found that both White and Black raters gave significantly higher job performance ratings to members of their own race, but this effect accounted for only a small amount of variance. Pulakos, White, Oppler, and Borman (1989) also found significant Rater Race × Ratee Race interactions on ratings of job performance, but such interactions accounted for less than 1% of the variance.

Several problems exist with past research that has examined race effects in interviews. First, whereas a large number of the performance appraisal studies have been conducted in real organizations, most of the selection interview studies have been based on simulations (Campion & Arvey, 1989). Second, there has been little research testing the same-race bias in interviews. Third, past research has neglected Hispanic applicants, despite the fact that this segment of the work force is growing dramatically (U.S. Department of Labor, 1988).

The first purpose of the present study was to examine same-race bias in a field interview setting with Blacks, Whites, and Hispanics. On the basis of the similar-to-me effect, we expected that interview ratings would be more favorable when the interviewer and interviewee were of the same race than when they were of different races.

We use the term race broadly in this article to reflect differences among Blacks, Whites, and Hispanics. Because the Hispanics in the present study were White, we recognize that whereas the Black/White and Black/Hispanic comparisons examined race differences, the White/Hispanic comparisons examined differences in ethnic background. Thus, we were examining both race and ethnicity.

Interviewer–Interviewee Age Similarity

Because of the overall increase in the age of the population, the number of employees between the ages of 45 and 60 will increase dramatically during the next 10 years (U.S. Department of Labor, 1988). Research indicates that most individuals perceive older employees as less employable, less motivated, less productive, less creative, and having less potential for development than their younger counterparts (e.g., Dedrick & Dobbins, 1991; Rosen & Jerdee, 1976). These negative stereotypes could result in older employees' being evaluated less favorably in the interview than equally qualified younger applicants.

Although the findings are somewhat conflicting, past research has tended to show that younger interviewees are evaluated more favorably than are older interviewees (e.g., Arvey, Miller, Gould, & Birch, 1987; Avolio & Barrett, 1987; Gordon, Rozelle, & Baxter, 1988). For example, Gordon et al. (1988) found that older employees received lower evaluations than did younger employees, especially when raters were held accountable for their recommendations. Past research has not, however, examined the effects of Interviewer–Interviewee age similarity on interview ratings. According to the similar-to-me hypothesis, interviewers should evaluate an interviewee more favorably when the interviewee is similar to them in age. The second purpose of the present study was to evaluate this prediction.

Interview Structure

A large body of research has attempted to determine the most effective interview strategy (see Eder & Ferris, 1989, for a review). Although the overall validity of the interview is dismal, research indicates that structured interviews tend to produce higher validity coefficients than unstructured interviews (e.g., McDaniel, Schmidt, & Hunter, 1988; Ulrich & Trumbo, 1965; Wiesner & Cronshaw, 1988), with some of the highest validity coefficients being obtained with the situational interview (Latham, 1989). In the situational interview, a job analysis is first conducted, and each critical incident is turned into a “What would you do if…” question. A scoring guide is developed to facilitate agreement between interviewers. Each interviewee is asked to indicate how he or she would respond to the situation. The research that has been conducted with the situational interview has found concurrent validity coefficients ranging from .30 to .46 and predictive validity coefficients ranging from .14 to .45 (Latham, 1989).

Little research has examined the potential adverse impact of the situational interview. Latham, Saari, Pursell, and Campion (1980) found that the situational interview did not discriminate against Blacks and women. Past research has not, however, examined the fairness of the situational interview for Hispanics or older employees or the extent to which same-race or same-age bias occurs with situational interviews.

The third purpose of the present study was to determine whether the magnitude of same-race and same-age bias is affected by interview format. A large body of research has indicated that stereotypes exert a greater effect on judgments when raters are forced to make judgments with little or irrelevant information (Glick, Zion, & Nelson, 1988; Heilman, 1984; Krueger & Rothbart, 1988; Tosi & Einbender, 1985). In essence, when raters encounter high degrees of ambiguity, they are more likely to rely on their stereotypes when making judgments about individuals. Given the highly structured and behavioral orientation of the situational interview and its detailed scoring guide, less same-race and same-age bias should occur in it than in the less structured conventional interview.

Interview Panels

Panel interviews are conducted by a group of interviewers. They are typically used in civil service selection procedures because the panel “reduces the impact of idiosyncratic biases that single interviewers might introduce” (Campion et al., 1988, p. 29). Furthermore, panel interviews should be more reliable than individual interviews because multiple independent ratings are collapsed into a composite (Wiesner & Cronshaw, 1988). Several researchers have proposed that panel interviews may be more valid than individual interviews (e.g., Arvey & Campion, 1982), and Wiesner and Cronshaw (1988) found support for this proposal in a meta-analysis.

We were unable to locate any empirical research that has examined the effects of age and race characteristics of panels on their interview ratings. Although most panels are instructed to ignore race, age, and gender information, diverse panels (e.g., a panel containing a Black and White member) may be less influenced by interviewee demographic characteristics than are homogeneous panels (e.g., a panel consisting of only White members). The fourth purpose of the present study was to examine such a possibility.

Overview of the Present Study

Black, White, and Hispanic applicants for custodian jobs in a large, West Coast urban school district were interviewed by a two-interviewer panel using a situational or a conventional structured interview. The race and age of panels varied across interviews. The interview data were collected in 2 consecutive years. In the 1st year (Sample A), applicants were interviewed by two-person panels using a conventional structured interview format. In the 2nd year (Sample B), a situational interview procedure was used. We expected that (a) interview ratings would be more favorable when the interview panel was of the same race as the interviewee, (b) interview ratings would be more favorable when the interview panel was similar in age to the interviewee, and (c) more same-age and same-race bias would be observed with the conventional than with the situational interview.

Method

Subjects

Sample A consisted of 1,645 applicants who were applying for a custodian job. This sample was predominantly Black and Hispanic (74% and 22%, respectively), with White being the minority race (4%). The mean age of the applicants was 33.1 years, 66.2% were male, and 60.7% had a high school diploma.

Sample B consisted of 1,160 applicants who were applying for the same job. Among the applicants, 5.3% were White, 71% were Black, and 23.6% were Hispanic. Mean age for the sample was about 30 years and 66.7% were male. Educational level was unavailable for this sample.

Because Blacks, Whites, and Hispanics made up 99% of applicants, applicants of other races (e.g., Chinese or Japanese) were not included in the study.

Interviewers

The interviewers were primarily personnel specialists employed by the school district and supervisors of custodian jobs. All possible race combinations were represented in the interview panels: White/White, Black/Black, Hispanic/Hispanic, White/Black, White/Hispanic, and Black/Hispanic.

Interview Procedures

Conventional structured interview

Campion et al. (1988) delineated six characteristics of a highly structured interview: (a) Questions are developed on the basis of a job analysis, (b) the same questions are asked of each candidate, (c) rating scales are anchored with behaviors, (d) a panel records and rates answers, (e) the interview is consistently administered to all candidates, and (f) special attention is given to fairness in accordance with testing guidelines. Our interview procedure met all of these criteria, except that rating scales were not anchored with specific examples of effective and ineffective performance. Thus, our interview procedure was a conventional structured interview (hereinafter referred to as CSI; Maurer & Fay, 1988).

Each CSI was conducted by a two-person panel. The typical interview lasted about 30 min. Each panel interviewed about 10 ratees or applicants per day with ratees randomly assigned to different panels.

The CSI was designed to assess three dimensions (willingness to perform custodial duties, work attitudes, and interpersonal skills), which were identified on the basis of a job analysis. Job-related questions were asked to assess each of the dimensions, and the same questions were asked of all job candidates. Interviewers were given behavioral definitions of the dimensions and told to focus on certain aspects of applicants' responses to the interview questions.

The interviewers were instructed to rate each interviewee on the three dimensions and then arrive at an overall score, ranging from 0 to 100, with 26 serving as the lowest possible passing score. After panel members had independently evaluated the interviewee, they were instructed to discuss their evaluations whenever there was a 10-point or larger difference in overall ratings. In addition, at the end of each day, interviewers were instructed to rank the interviewees and adjust their final scores if necessary to reflect the relative strengths of the interviewees.

All interviewers received a 1 hr training session. The majority of this training focused on the meaning of the dimensions and the manner in which each dimension could be observed in responses to the interview questions. In addition, the training focused on determining the manner in which overall scores should be assigned to interviewees.

Prior to conducting the interviews, interviewers had an opportunity to review the candidate's application blank. In addition to asking the structured interview questions, interviewers were informed that they could ask follow-up questions about the candidate's application blank if they desired. However, they were instructed that their interview ratings should be based almost entirely on the applicant's responses to the interview questions.

Situational interview

The situational interview procedure was modeled after the critical incident technique (Flanagan, 1954). Thirty-one situational questions and their corresponding benchmarks were generated with the assistance of job experts. Two interview forms were developed, each with 20 questions. These forms contained 9 identical questions and 11 questions unique to each form. The 22 unique questions consisted of 11 pairs, with each pair focusing on similar content. One of each pair of the unique questions was assigned to each interview form. Specifics of the situational interview have been provided by Lin, Magel, and Manligas (1986).

Prior to the interview, all interviewers went through a 3-hr training session. Interviewers studied the interview questions and then practiced rating videotapes of mock interviews.

Like the CSI procedure, each ratee was interviewed by a two-person panel. Interviewers alternated in reading questions to the interviewee. Both interviewers independently rated an applicant's answers by comparing them with benchmarks. A score of 1 (poor), 3 (mediocre), or 5 (good) was assigned to each answer. If an applicant's answer did not match any of the benchmarks, interviewers were instructed to write down the interviewee's answer and continue with the interview. When the interview was over, the interviewers would then grade these answers by consulting a grading manual. The applicant's score for the interview was the sum of the scores across the 20 questions.

Overall Interview Score

Because all interviews were conducted by panels and panel raters were instructed to consult with each other before arriving at their final scores, it is not surprising that the two interviewers' final scores were highly correlated (r = .99 for CSIs and .99 for situational interviews). Therefore, the final scores assigned by the two interviewers were averaged for each applicant to form an overall interview score. All results reported herein are based on this overall interview score.

Interviewer–Interviewee Race and Age Similarity

Race similarity

Each applicant was interviewed by one of three types of panels. In the first type, both interviewers were of the same race as the interviewee (e.g., a Black applicant interviewed by two Black interviewers). This type of panel was expected to be most susceptible to same-race bias. The second type consisted of mixed-race panels in which one interviewer was of the same race as the applicant (e.g., a Black applicant interviewed by a Black and a White interviewer). This type of panel represented a moderate level of Interviewer–Interviewee race similarity. To the extent that the same-race interviewer had some influence on the evaluation process in mixed-race panels, we believed there would be some same-race bias (although the magnitude of bias was expected to be less than in same-race panels). In the final type of panel, both interviewers were of races different from that of the interviewee (e.g., a Black applicant interviewed by a White and a Hispanic interviewer). Because there was no similarity in race in this type of panel, we believed it would be free of same-race bias and thus could serve as a control group against which same-race bias could be assessed.

Age similarity

Interviewees were divided into four age groups: under 25, 25 to 35, 35 to 45, and over 45. The interview panel was classified as same age when both interviewers were in the same age group as the interviewee (e.g., a 40-year-old applicant interviewed by 39- and a 42-year-old interviewer). The interview panel was classified as mixed age when one of the interviewers was in the same age group as the interviewee (e.g., a 40-year-old applicant interviewed by a 39- and a 49-year-old interviewer). The interview panel was classified as different age when both interviewers were of a different age group than the interviewee (e.g., a 40-year-old applicant interviewed by a 26- and a 53-year-old interviewer). As noted earlier, interview ratings were expected to be higher in same-age groups than in different-age groups.

Results

Analyses of variance (ANOVAs) were conducted to assess same-age and same-race bias in situational interviews and CSIs. Interview ratings were analyzed separately for each race and each age group, because true differences could exist between groups (e.g., 35- to 45-year-olds could actually be more qualified than 25- to 35-year-olds). Thus, we compared the ratings given to each type of interviewee (e.g., Blacks) by interview panels of same (e.g., Black/Black), mixed (e.g., Black/White), and different (e.g., Hispanic/White) race and age. Because interviewees were randomly assigned to interview panels, there should not have been any true performance differences in the candidates interviewed by same-, mixed-, and different-race and -age interview panels. Analyses could not be conducted to examine same-sex bias: Because most of the sample and interviewers were male, extremely unequal cell sizes resulted when sex was considered as a variable.

Interviewer–Interviewee Race Similarity

Conventional structured interviews

Table 1 presents the means, standard deviations, and results of ANOVAs for interviewer race. Separate analyses were conducted for Black, White, and Hispanic applicants. As can be seen, interviewer race was highly significant for Black applicants. However, the cell sizes were unequal across the three interviewer groups, and the assumption of homogeneity of variance was violated, Bartlett-Box F(2, 1207) = 6.29, p < .01. Because past research has indicated that nonorthogonal ANOVA procedures are not robust when the assumption of homogeneity of variance is violated (e.g., Glass, Peckham, & Sanders, 1972), a Kruskal-Wallis test was also conducted. The results paralleled the results of the ANOVA, χ2(2, N = 1,210) = 24.10, p < .01. The Games-Howell procedure was used to conduct post hoc analyses. According to Kirk (1982), the Games-Howell procedure is robust for post hoc nonorthogonal, pairwise comparisons. The results showed that Black/Black panels rated Black applicants more favorably than did Black/other and other/other panels. Interview ratings made by Black/other and other/other panels did not significantly differ.

 

Interviewer race was also highly significant for Hispanic interviewees (see Table 1). Once again, because the variances, Bartlett-Box F(2, 365) = 17.48, p < .01, and the samples were unequal across the three interviewer groups, a Kruskal-Wallis test was conducted. The results paralleled the results of the ANOVA, χ2(2, N = 368) = 12.28, p < .01. Post hoc comparisons using the Games-Howell procedure showed that Hispanic/Hispanic panels rated Hispanic interviewees more favorably than did Hispanic/other or other/other panels. Interview scores did not significantly differ between Hispanic/other and other/other panels.

For White interviewees, interviewer race had no significant effect on interview scores. As can be seen in Table 1, the pattern of means was contrary to our expectations. Specifically, White interviewees were evaluated as less qualified by White/White interview panels than by other/other interview panels.

Situational interviews

Table 2 presents the means, standard deviations, and results of ANOVAs for interviewer race on interview scores in situational interviews. Interviewer race had a significant effect for Black interviewees. Post hoc comparisons showed that the only difference among the three types of panels was that Black/Black panels rated Black interviewees more favorably than did other/other panels.

 

For Hispanic and White interviewees, interviewer race had no significant effect on interview scores.

Race Similarity as a Function of Interview Type

The preceding analyses suggested that same-race bias was more prevalent with the CSI than with the situational interview. To directly test this notion, we performed a 2 × 3 ANOVA with similarity of interview panel (same vs. mixed vs. different race) and type of interview procedure (CSI vs. situational) as the independent variables. Once again, this analysis was conducted separately for Black, White, and Hispanic interviewees because a main effect for interviewee race would not be interpretable (true differences could exist between the populations).

Black applicants

The ANOVA revealed a significant main effect for interview type, F(1, 2029) = 20.37, p < .01, and similarity of the interview panel, F(2, 2029) = 12.19, p < .01. These main effects were qualified by a significant Similarity of Interview Panel × Interview Type interaction, F(2, 2029) = 5.68, p < .01. This interaction can be interpreted by examining the means in the top panels of Tables 1 and 2. As can be seen, although same-race bias occurred with both interview procedures, there was a greater difference between ratings made by Black/Black interviewers and other/other interviewers in the CSI than in the situational interview. Thus, more same-race bias occurred for Black interviewees in the CSI than in the situational interview.

Hispanic applicants

The ANOVA revealed a significant main effect for similarity of the interview panel, F(2, 636) = 7.13, p < .01. However, the Interview Panel × Interview Type interaction was not significant, F(2, 636) = 2.55, p > .05, indicating that same-race bias did not differ significantly across interview procedures.

White applicants

No significant effects were obtained for White interviewees. Interview ratings were not significantly affected by the interview type, similarity of the interview panel, or the interaction between these two factors.

Interviewer–Interviewee Age Similarity

Conventional structured interviews

Table 3 presents the means, standard deviations, and results of ANOVAs for interviewer age in CSIs. Across the four interviewee age groups, there were no significant effects for interviewer age.

 

Situational interviews

Table 4 presents the means, standard deviations, and results of ANOVAs for interviewer age in situational interviews. As can be seen, interviewer age did not affect interview ratings in any of the four interviewee age groups.

 

Discussion

Interviewer–Interviewee race similarity had a small but significant effect on interview ratings. Evidence of same-race bias was obtained for Black interviewees in the situational interview and in the CSI and for Hispanic interviewees in the CSI. These findings are consistent with the similar-to-me effect described by Rand and Wexley (1975). In addition, the same-race effect appeared stronger in CSIs than in situational interviews. For example, whereas race similarity had a significant effect for both Black and Hispanic interviewees in CSIs, the effect was significant only for Black interviewees in situational interviews. Furthermore, the Interview Type × Similarity of Interview Panel interaction was significant for Black interviewees.

As was noted earlier, both CSIs and situational interviews were based on a thorough job analysis. In addition, all interviewers were appropriately trained. Thus, it does not seem likely that stronger same-race bias was found with the CSI simply because it was less well conducted than the situational interview. Instead, the results suggest that adding structure to interviews may minimize same-race bias. Such a finding is consistent with a large body of research that indicates that demographic variables exert more influence on personnel decisions when raters are forced to make decisions with limited information and without explicit guidelines for evaluating behavior (e.g., Tosi & Einbender, 1985).

Several factors may explain the same-race bias obtained in the present study. First, as proposed earlier, interviewers may believe that individuals who are demographically similar to them possess more positive characteristics and will develop into better employees. This explanation is essentially the similar-to-me hypothesis as presented by Rand and Wexley (1975). These similar-to-me effects may have been minimized with the situational interview because such a procedure forces raters to make evaluations on the basis of the extent to which an answer matches a benchmark.

The same-race effects also could have been produced because Black and Hispanic applicants may have felt less threatened when being interviewed by same-race interviewers and thus may have provided the interviewers with more information about their skills and abilities. Thus, increased communication could have accounted for the high interview ratings given by same-race interviewers. The situational interview may have minimized such same-race effects by forcing interviewees to communicate with all interviewers, irrespective of whether they felt comfortable with such interactions.

Same-race bias was not obtained with White interviewees in the present study. Examination of Tables 1 and 2 indicates that White applicants were underrepresented in the occupational structure for this job. A power analysis indicated that the power to detect a small effect size was .25, and the power to detect a medium effect size was .43 (Cohen, 1977). Thus, the present findings are inconclusive for White interviewees. Future research should test the similar-to-me hypothesis for White interviewees in jobs that attract more White applicants.

Interview Panel

Another interesting and potentially important finding was that the same-race bias was sharply reduced when mixed-race panels were used in interviews. Across all analyses, post hoc comparisons failed to detect significant differences between mixed-race panels and other race panels. This finding suggests that including at least one different-race interviewer in a panel may serve as a check and balance on the evaluation process. An implication of this finding is that organizations should avoid using single-race interview panels whenever possible.

Age Bias

Contrary to our expectations, we did not find same-age bias in interview ratings. As was noted earlier, little research has examined the effects of age on interview ratings in field settings. The present results seem to suggest that raters in the real world have more job-related information available, which minimizes the need to use age as a primary factor in selection recommendations.

Limitations

Several limitations of the study should be noted. These limitations emanate from the fact that the study was conducted in a field setting. First, true performance levels of interviewees are unknown. The methodology of the present study was designed to respond to this problem. Specifically, interviewees within each race and age group were randomly assigned to interview panels, and the data were analyzed separately for each race and age group. Comparisons were not made across interviewee race or age groups (e.g., comparing the mean rating given to Blacks, Whites, and Hispanics) because true differences may exist between populations. However, without true performance levels, it was impossible to determine whether the same-race bias occurred because of an inflation of ratings given by same-race interviewers or a deflation of ratings given by different-race interviewers. Future research should examine the locus of same-race bias by using designs that allow true performance levels to be ascertained.

A second limitation is that although same-race bias was more prevalant in the CSI than in the situational interview, the specific mechanism(s) producing this pattern of findings was not investigated. The CSI and situational interview differed on numerous dimensions, such as types of questions asked, number of questions asked, and scoring procedures. It addition, the two interview procedures may have been differentially reliable. Some of these factors, or a combination of them, could have produced the present pattern of findings. Future research should delineate the specific characteristics of the situational interview that minimize same-race bias.

A third potential limitation is that cell sizes were dramatically different in the study. For example, as can be seen in Table 1, there was a minimum cell size of 14 cases (White interviewees rated by two White interviewers) and a maximum cell size of 968 cases (Black interviewees rated by two Black interviewers). In fact, the unequal distribution of cases prevented the simultaneous analysis of age and race. In order to appropriately respond to these conditions, nonorthogonal ANOVAs were performed (see Milligan, Wong, & Thompson, 1987). In addition, all post hoc significance tests were conducted with the Games-Howell procedure, a procedure that is robust for nonorthogonal post hoc comparisons (Kirk, 1982). In the two cases in which sample size varied and homogeneity of variance was violated (Hispanic and Black interviewees with the CSI), Kruskal-Wallis nonparametric ANOVAs were conducted.

A fourth limitation is that the effect sizes in the study were fairly small (see Tables 1 and 2). Before dismissing these effects as unimportant, several points should be considered. First, the interview procedures used in the present study were much more rigorous than interviews used in many organizations. As noted earlier, our CSI was based on a job analysis, and all applicants were asked the same job-relevant questions. The present findings suggest that adding structure to an interview procedure reduces same-race bias. Thus, although not explicitly examined in the present study, we believe that more same-race bias would be found in a purely unstructured interview than was obtained in the CSI in the present study.

It should also be noted that variance accounted for is not synonymous with practical utility. Obviously, any bias will result in less than optimal use of human resources and possibly prompt equal employment opportunity litigation. Furthermore, indices of variance accounted for may be misleading when small influences sum to produce a meaningful outcome (Abelson, 1985). For example, if all interviewers in a large organization are affected by same-race bias, the organization may fail to select the most qualified candidates.

A final limitation is that the present study focused on custodian jobs. We believe that the interview process for this job is similar to that used with many other jobs (and thus would expect same-race bias in other jobs), but we recognize that generalizability is an empirical question. Future research should determine the extent to which the present findings generalize to other positions, especially those in managerial and professional jobs.

In summary, same-race bias occurred and was more prevalent in the CSI than in the situational interview. Little evidence of same-age bias was obtained with either interview procedure. Furthermore, same-race bias could be avoided by using mixed-panel interviews. Although the interpretation of the results must be tempered by the methodological limitations associated with real-world research, the results nevertheless provide evidence to bolster previous observations of race effects in the selection process (see Harris, 1989) and expand the conclusions to include another ethnic group, Hispanics.

Record: 11
Title:
A longitudinal evaluation of the positive action program in a low-income, racially diverse, rural county: Effects on self-esteem, school hassles, aggression, and internalizing symptoms.
Authors:
Guo, Shenyang, Brown School of Social Work, Washington University, St. Louis, MO, US, s.guo@wustl.edu
Wu, Qi, School of Social Work, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, US, qiwu@email.unc.edu
Smokowski, Paul R., School of Social Welfare, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, US, smokowski@ku.edu
Bacallao, Martica, School of Social Welfare, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, US, marticabacallao@gmail.com
Evans, Caroline B. R., School of Social Work, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, US, careyrobertson@gmail.com
Cotter, Katie L., School of Social Work, Arizona State University, Phoenix, AZ, US, katie.cotter@asu.edu
Address:
Guo, Shenyang, Brown School of Social Work, Washington University, CB# 1196, One Brookings Drive, St. Louis, MO, US, 63130, s.guo@wustl.edu
Source:
Journal of Youth and Adolescence, Sep 28, 2015.
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0047-2891 (Print)
1573-6601 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
School-based interventions, Positive Action, Self-esteem, Aggression, Rural, Propensity score analysis
Abstract:
Positive Action is a school-based program that aims to decrease problem behaviors (e.g., violence, substance use) and increase positive behaviors (e.g., school engagement, academic achievement). Although a number of studies have shown that Positive Action successfully achieves these goals, few studies have evaluated the program’s effectiveness in rural schools. Given that rural youth are at an increased risk for risky behaviors (e.g., violence, substance use), this is a critical gap in the existing Positive Action research base. The current study assesses the impact of Positive Action on change rates of self-esteem, school hassles, aggression, and internalizing symptoms in a group (N = 1246, 52 % female) of ethnically/racially diverse (27 % White, 23 % African American, 12 % mixed race/other, 8 % Latino, 30 % as American Indian) middle school youth (age range 9–20) located in two violent, low-income rural counties in North Carolina. One county engaged in Positive Action over the 3-year study window while the other county did not. Following multiple imputation and propensity score analysis, 4 two-level hierarchical linear models were run using each of the outcome measures as dependent variables. The results indicate that the program generates statistically significant beneficial effects for youth from the intervention county on self-esteem scores and school hassles scores. Although the program generates beneficial effects for intervention youth on the change in aggression scores, the finding is not statistically significant. The finding on the change in internalizing scores shows a non-significant detrimental effect: the youth from the comparison county have lower internalizing scores than those from the intervention county. Implications are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

No terms assigned

Developmental Psychology (2800)

Record: 12
Title:
A longitudinal test of social cognitive career theory's academic persistence model among Latino/a and White men and women engineering students.
Authors:
Lee, Hang-Shim, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK, US, hangshim.lee@okstate.edu
Flores, Lisa Y., University of Missouri, MO, US
Navarro, Rachel L., University of North Dakota, Grand Forks, NC, US
Kanagui-Muñoz, Marlen, Kaiser Permanente, Oakland, CA, US
Address:
Lee, Hang-Shim, School of Applied Health and Educational Psychology, Oklahoma State University, 406Willard Hall, Stillwater, OK, US, 74078, hangshim.lee@okstate.edu
Source:
Journal of Vocational Behavior, Vol 88, Jun, 2015. pp. 95-103.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0001-8791 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Social cognitive career theory, Academic persistence model, Engineering, Gender and ethnic minority
Abstract:
This study tested Social Cognitive Career Theory's (SCCT) academic persistent model among engineering students from a longitudinal perspective and examined whether relations among the variables in the model differed between Whites and Latinos/as and between men and women engineering majors. Three hundred fifty engineering student participants (172 Latino/as; 155 Whites; 23 mixed race) who were attending a Hispanic-serving institution in the Southwest completed measures of math/science ACT, college GPA, engineering self-efficacy, engineering goals, and persistence. The academic persistence model within the engineering domain provided an excellent fit to the data. Significant group differences between women and men were found; however, there were no group differences across ethnicity. Implication for further research and interventions based on SCCT's academic persistence model are discussed in relation to academic persistence in engineering for women and Latinos/as. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Career Development; *Engineers; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Cognition; *Students; Human Services; Human Sex Differences; Occupational Guidance; Persistence; Theories; Whites; Latinos/Latinas

Title:
A qualitative examination of multiracial students' coping responses to experiences with prejudice and discrimination in college.
Authors:
Museus, Samuel D., Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, US
Sariñana, Susan A. Lambe, Private Practice, Cambridge, MA, US
Ryan, Tasha Kawamata, Azusa Pacific University, Azusa, CA, US
Address:
Museus, Samuel D., Indiana University, W.W Wright Education Building, Room 4228, 201 North Rose Avenue, Bloomington, IN, US, 47405-1006
Source:
Journal of College Student Development, Vol 56(4), May, 2015. pp. 331-348.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
US : ACPA Executive Office
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of College Student Personnel
ISSN:
0897-5264 (Print)
1543-3382 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
coping responses, multiracial, prejudice, discrimination, mixed-race students, higher education
Abstract:
National data indicate that multiracial individuals comprise a substantial and growing proportion of the US population, but this community is often invisible in higher education research and discourse. This study aims to increase knowledge of mixed-race students in higher education by examining the ways in which they cope with experienced prejudice and discrimination in college. Findings indicate that multiracial college students cope with prejudice and discrimination by educating others about multiracial issues, utilizing support networks, embracing fluidity of multiracial identity, and avoiding confrontation with sources of prejudice and discrimination. Implications for research and practice are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Coping Behavior; *Discrimination; *Higher Education; *Interracial Offspring; *Prejudice; Race and Ethnic Discrimination

Title:
A qualitative study of biracial identity among Afro-Germans living in Germany.
Authors:
Hubbard, Rebecca R., University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL, US, hubbardrr@gmail.com
Utsey, Shawn O., Virginia Commonwealth University, VA, US
Address:
Hubbard, Rebecca R., Counseling Center (MC 333), University of Illinois at Chicago, 1200 W. Harrison St. 2010 SSB, Chicago, IL, US, 60607, hubbardrr@gmail.com
Source:
Identity: An International Journal of Theory and Research, Vol 15(2), Apr, 2015. pp. 89-112.
Page Count:
24
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Lawrence Erlbaum
ISSN:
1528-3488 (Print)
1532-706X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed race, biracial identity, multiracial identity, racial identity development, biracial Afro-Germans, cultural influences, racial socialization, black-white biracial, racial identity negotiation
Abstract:
The increase of mixed race individuals in Europe is shifting the racial environment, making it increasingly important to understand the experiences of multiracial and biracial individuals in the European context. This study, utilizing a qualitative design, explored racial identity development of biracial Afro-Germans living in Germany. The purpose of the study was to understand the strategies that biracial individuals use to negotiate their racial identity, factors that influence their development, cultural influences, and racial socialization processes. Interviews with biracial Afro-Germans were conducted using phenomenological interviewing techniques. Twelve themes emerged from the data that are best conceptualized in an ecological model. Implications of the findings include a need for continued research with Black-White biracial populations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*African Cultural Groups; *Ethnic Identity; *Identity Formation; *Interracial Offspring; Blacks; Racial and Ethnic Groups; Sociocultural Factors; Whites

Record: 15
Title:
A social identity approach to person memory: Group membership, collective identification, and social role shape attention and memory.
Authors:
Van Bavel, Jay J., New York University, New York, NY, US, jay.vanbavel@nyu.edu
Cunningham, William A., Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, US
Address:
Van Bavel, Jay J., Department of Psychology, New York University, 6 Washington Place, Room 752, New York, NY, US, 10003, jay.vanbavel@nyu.edu
Source:
Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, Vol 38(12), Dec, 2012. pp. 1566-1578.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0146-1672 (Print)
1552-7433 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social identity, person memory, group membership, collective identification, social role, attention, memory
Abstract:
Evidence indicates that superior memory for own-group versus other-group faces (termed own-group bias) occurs because of social categorization: People are more likely to encode own-group members as individuals. The authors show that aspects of the perceiver’s social identity shape social attention and memory over and above mere categorization. In three experiments, participants were assigned to a mixed-race minimal group and showed own-group bias toward this minimal group, regardless of race. Own-group bias was mediated by attention toward own-group faces during encoding (Experiment 1). Furthermore, participants who were highly identified with their minimal group had the largest own-group bias (Experiment 2). However, social affordances attenuated own-group bias—Memory for other-group faces was heightened among participants who were assigned to a role (i.e., spy) that required attention toward other-group members (Experiment 3). This research suggests that social identity may provide novel insights into person memory. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:

Record: 16
Title:
A survey of medical and nursing services to educational centres for children with disabilities in greater Cape Town.
Authors:
Westwood, A. T. R., Red Cross War Memorial Children's Hosp, Dept of Paediatrics & Child Health, Rondebosch, South Africa
Source:
Southern African Journal of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, Vol 5(1), 1993. pp. 38-41.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
South Africa : South African Association for Child and Adolescent Psychiatry and Allied Professions
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of Child and Adolescent Mental Health; Southern African Journal of Child and Adolescent Mental Health
Other Publishers:
South Africa : NISC Pty Ltd
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Language:
English
Keywords:
medical & nursing services to Greater Cape Town educational centers for physically or intellectually disabled children & adolescents, nurses & principles, Mental Retardation
Abstract:
A standard questionnaire was administered to 33 personnel members (nurses or principles) of educational centers for physically and intellectually disabled children under 18 yrs of age. These educational centers included special schools for physically disabled children with normal or borderline IQs, training centers for children with IQ 30–50, and special care centers for profoundly retarded children. The results show that 75% of Black, 40% of mixed race, and 10% of White children had no regular contact with a doctor through their special educational centers. Staff at the centers identified this as a major encumbrance; many times their advice was not followed or no response was received from the referral center. It is concluded that without a coordinated comprehensive system of review for disabled children, it is likely that many problems, including behavioral and psychiatric disorders, are not being adequately dealt with. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Attitudes; *Disorders; *Medical Treatment (General); *Special Education; *Quality of Services; Health Personnel Attitudes; Nurses; Physical Disorders; School Administrators; Health Personnel; Intellectual Development Disorder

Medical Treatment of Physical Illness (3363)

Record: 17
Title:
Accessing the food systems in urban and rural Minnesotan communities.
Authors:
Smith, Chery, Department of Food Science and Nutrition, University of Minnesota, St. Paul, MN, US, csmith@umn.edu
Miller, Hannah, Department of Food Science and Nutrition, University of Minnesota, St. Paul, MN, US
Address:
Smith, Chery, Department of Food Science and Nutrition, 225 FScN, 1334 Eckles Ave, St. Paul, MN, US, 55108-6099, csmith@umn.edu
Source:
Journal of Nutrition Education and Behavior, Vol 43(6), Nov-Dec, 2011. pp. 492-504.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of Nutrition Education
Other Publishers:
Canada : BC Decker
ISSN:
1499-4046 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
food systems, urban communities, rural communities, health
Abstract:
Objective: Explore how urban and rural Minnesotans access the food system and to investigate whether community infrastructure supports a healthful food system. Design: Eight (4 urban and 4 rural) focus groups were conducted. Setting and Participants: Eight counties with urban influence codes of 1, 2, 4, 5, 8, and 10. Fifty-nine (urban, n = 27; rural, n = 32) adults. The sample was of mixed race and had a range of incomes. Almost half of the sample was obese. Main Outcome Measure: Food systems access and the role of community infrastructure, civic engagement, and reciprocal relationships in food provisioning in counties with different urban influence codes. Analyses: Themes and subthemes were identified through emerging concepts. Results: Food access varied based on rurality and community infrastructure. Three themes emerged: community infrastructure around the conventional food system and food provisioning, alternative food resources, and perceptions of the effect food and of the influence diet and exercise have on health. Conclusions and Implications: Civic engagement and community infrastructure affected food access. Rural residents rely more on retail grocery stores, gardening, hunting, and informal food exchange systems, whereas urban residents rely more on the retail grocery stores and food safety net systems. Hunting and gardening may contribute valuable nutrients to the diet. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Communities; *Food; *Health; *Rural Environments; *Urban Environments
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 18
Title:
Acting (to) Out: Approaching Homosexuality in a 15-Year-Old Boy with Anxiety and Depression.
Authors:
Jackson, Joseph A., Department of Psychiatry, Division of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston, MA, US, jjackson14@partners.org
Telingator, Cynthia J., Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, Cambridge Hospital, Cambridge, MA, US
Pleak, Richard R., Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park, NY, US
Pollack, William S., Centers for Men and Young Men, McLean Hospital, Belmont, MA, US
Address:
Jackson, Joseph A., Department of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, Massachusetts General Hospital, Yawkey Center for Outpatient Care, 55 Fruit St., YAW 6900, Boston, MA, US, 02114, jjackson14@partners.org
Source:
Harvard Review of Psychiatry, Vol 13(1), Jan-Feb, 2005. pp. 43-53.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Informa Healthcare
US : Lippincott Williams & Wilkins
ISSN:
1067-3229 (Print)
1465-7309 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
homosexuality, anxiety, depression, gender identity, sexual orientation, adolescent development
Abstract:
Presents a clinical case report of approaching homosexuality in a 15-year-old mixed-race boy ("JM") with anxiety and depression. He reported that his anxiety had been growing progressively worse since enrolling in a nearby vocational high school. He endorsed multiple depressive symptoms, including sadness and hopelessness, loss of interest, poor concentration, decreased energy, and increased sleep and appetite, with a 30-pound weight gain over several months. He had experienced occasional passive suicidal ideation, however, he denied any history of self-injurious behavior. The clinicians discuss the complications that may arise in an initial encounter with an adolescent dealing with issues of sexual identity with the reference of JM's case. The exploration of adolescents' sexuality and of positive and negative feelings about their sexual orientation should take place in a therapeutic relationship in which the therapist can remain neutral. Premature closure of the therapist's thinking about an adolescent's sexual orientation may be harmful. It should also be noted how important it is for the therapist to help the gay adolescent find positive role models. While gender identity and sexual orientation are sensitive issues, especially for an adolescent, clinicians must inquire about them in the same caring, nonjudgmental manner as any other aspect of the patient's life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Anxiety; *Gender Identity; *Major Depression; *Male Homosexuality; *Psychotherapy; Adolescent Development
PsycINFO Classification:
Psychotherapy & Psychotherapeutic Counseling (3310)
Population:
Human
Male
Outpatient
Location:
US
Age Group:

Title:
Activism and identity through the word: A mixed-race woman claims her space.
Authors:
Thompson, Wendy M.
Source:

Page Count:

1-56023-462-8 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
activism, identity, mixed-race, bisexual, Asian, African American
Abstract:
When I first heard that this book was being assembled, I felt compelled to write about my own experience and create a voice for myself and for people like me who struggle within margins. I wanted to reserve a place for myself within this space we call Asian/Pacific America. I wanted to speak out as a bisexual woman, a poor woman, a young woman, and a mixed-blood woman who has survived sexual violence. that I am a complex individual who is simply trying to change the world. I am a woman yelling from the sidelines, creating new narratives, bringing forth a new experience, using her power to transform and fight and bring beauty to this society. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
