Record: 46
Title:
Beyond westem dis/orders: Thinness and self-starvation of other-ed women.
Authors:
Nasser, Mervat, Department of Mental Health and Cultural Diversity, Institute of Psychiatry, Kings College, London, England
Malson, Helen, University of the West of England, Bristol, England
Source:
Critical feminist approaches to eating dis/orders. Malson, Helen (Ed); Burns, Maree (Ed); pp. 74-86; New York, NY, US: Routledge/Taylor & Francis Group; 2009. xxi, 257 pp.
Page Count:
13
ISBN:
978-0-415-41810-2 (Paperback)
978-0-415-41811-9 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
feminist perspective, ethnic minority, non-western girls, culture, difference, ethnicity, eating disorders, women
Abstract:
Our aim in this chapter is therefore to discuss, from a critical feminist perspective, questions of culture, difference and ethnicity and of 'eating disorders' amongst ethnic minority and non-western girls and women. Our discussion here is inevitably shaped and delimited in some ways by our own gendered, racialised and disciplinary subject positions. Mervat Nasser is an Egyptian consultant psychiatrist who has been living and working in England for 30 years. Helen Malson is a critical feminist psychologist and a white British mother of a mixed-race daughter. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:

Record: 47
Title:
Biracial and Multiracial Identity: Influence on Self-Identity as African American.
Authors:
Constantine, Madonna G., Columbia U, Teachers Coll, Dept of Counseling & Clinical Psychology, New York, NY, US
Miville, Marie L., Columbia U, Teachers Coll, New York, NY, US
Kindaichi, Mai M., Columbia U, Teachers Coll, Dept of Counseling & Clinical Psychology, New York, NY, US
Source:
Contemporary mental health issues among African Americans. Harley, Debra A. (Ed); Dillard, John Milton (Ed); pp. 133-145; Alexandria, VA, US: American Counseling Association; 2005. xx, 336 pp.
Page Count:
13
ISBN:
1-55620-236-9 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
biracial, multiracial, self-identity, African Americans
Abstract:
According to the 2000 U.S. Census, 6.8 million people, or 2.4% of the national population, identified themselves by two or more races (i.e., biracial or multiracial; Jones & Smith, 2001). Nearly 1.8 million of these individuals reported being Black or African American in combination with another racial or ethnic group. Reported population figures regarding biracial African Americans, however, may be underestimations of the actual size of this population (Brown, 1995; Root, 1996). In particular, the degree to which parents of interracial children address their children's racial group orientation and how people of mixed race heritage identify with either or both racial groups may influence population estimates (Winn & Priest, 1993). In this chapter, we provide some background information pertaining to the historical and current experiences of biracial and multiracial African Americans. We also discuss considerations in the self-identification process for biracial and multiracial African Americans, and we present several prominent identity development models for biracial and multiracial people. In addition, we present issues that mental health counselors might wish to consider when working with biracial and multiracial African Americans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

*Blacks; *Ethnic Identity; *Interracial Offspring; *Self Concept

Abstract:
Presents a comparative analysis of literature to explore developmental and social implications of biracial identity, specifically among Black/White biracial persons. Discussion includes the formation of biracial identity and bicultural socialization, consequences of social marginality, and social stigma as a central facet of biracial life. The interpersonal style of the biracial person within majority and minority groups is described. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Biracial, bicultural, bisexual: Bisexuality and multiple identities.

Keywords:

Abstract:
This article is based on interviews of twenty-seven women (aged 20-59 yrs). The women were primarily Caucasian, but a few were of mixed race. This article focuses on the women of mixed race and one or more Caucasian women who met other cultural aspects of identity such as religious beliefs, age, and politics. The purpose is to discuss how these factors impact their construction of bisexual identity. First comes a brief review of the literature on sexual identity models, racial identity models, age differences, religious differences, and feminism. Then the women speak. Following each woman's voice, her main points are related to therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 50
Title:
Black + White = Black: Hypodescent in reflexive categorization of racially ambiguous faces.
Authors:
Peery, Destiny, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, US, d-peery@northwestern.edu
Bodenhausen, Galen V., Northwestern University, Evanston, IL, US, galen@northwestern.edu
Address:
Peery, Destiny, Department of Psychology, Northwestern University, 2029 Sheridan Rd., Evanston, IL, US, 60208, d-peery@northwestern.edu
Source:
Psychological Science, Vol 19(10), Oct, 2008. pp. 973-977.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0956-7976 (Print)
1467-9280 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
reflexive categorization, racially ambiguous faces, racial identities, multiracial backgrounds, principle of hypodescent
Abstract:
Historically, the principle of hypodescent specified that individuals with one Black and one White parent should be considered Black. Two experiments examined whether categorizations of racially ambiguous targets reflect this principle. Participants studied ambiguous target faces accompanied by profiles that either did or did not identify the targets as having multiracial backgrounds (biological, cultural, or both biological and cultural). Participants then completed a speeded dual-categorization task requiring Black/not Black and White/not White judgments (Experiments 1 and 2) and deliberate categorization tasks requiring participants to describe the races (Experiment 2) of target faces. When a target was known to have mixed-race ancestry, participants were more likely to rapidly categorize the target as Black (and not White); however, the same cues also increased deliberate categorizations of the targets as "multiracial." These findings suggest that hypodescent still characterizes the automatic racial categorizations of many perceivers, although more complex racial identities may be acknowledged upon more thoughtful reflection. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Cues; *Face Perception; *Judgment; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; Parents
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
US

Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs)

Record: 51
Title:
Black and White, or shades of gray? Racial labeling of Barack Obama predicts implicit race perception.
Authors:
Malahy, Lori Wu, Department of Psychology, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, US, loriwu@u.washington.edu
Sedlins, Mara, Department of Psychology, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, US
Plaks, Jason, Department of Psychology, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON, Canada
Shoda, Yuichi, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, US, yshoda@u.washington.edu
Address:
Malahy, Lori Wu, Department of Psychology, University of Washington, Box 351525, Seattle, WA, US, 98195-1525, loriwu@u.washington.edu
Source:
Analyses of Social Issues and Public Policy (ASAP), Vol 10(1), Dec, 2010. pp. 207-222.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
ISSN:
1529-7489 (Print)
1530-2415 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Blacks, Whites, racial labeling, Barack Obama, race perception, individual differences, elections
Abstract:
The present research capitalized on the prominence and multiracial heritage of U.S. 2008 presidential election candidate Barack Obama to examine whether individual differences in classifying him as Black or as multiracial corresponded to differences in implicit perception of race. This research used a newly developed task (Sedlins, Malahy, & Shoda, 2010) with digitally morphed mixed-race faces to assess implicit race perception. Participants completed this task four times before and one time after the election. We found that people who labeled Obama as Black implicitly perceived race as more categorical than those who labeled Obama as multiracial. This finding adds to the growing literature on multiracial perception by demonstrating a relationship between the explicit use of multiracial and monoracial race classification and implicit race perception. The results suggest potential implications for governmental, educational, and judiciary usage of racial categories. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:

Record: 52
Title:
Black beauty: Shade, hair and anti-racist aesthetics.
Authors:
Tate, Shirley, Center for Interdisciplinary Gender Studies, University of Leeds, Leeds, United Kingdom, s.a.tate@leeds.ac.uk
Address:
Tate, Shirley, Centre for Interdisciplinary Gender Studies, University of Leeds, Coach House, Leeds, United Kingdom, LS2 9JT, s.a.tate@leeds.ac.uk
Source:
Ethnic and Racial Studies, Vol 30(2), Mar, 2007. Special Issue: Feminism and Postcolonization: Knowledge/Politics. pp. 300-319.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0141-9870 (Print)
1466-4356 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
aesthetics, beauty, racism, biracial Black women, Black women
Abstract:
Dark skin shade and natural afro-hair are central in the politics of visibility, inclusion and exclusion within black anti-racist aesthetics. This article focuses on black beauty as performative through looking at how the discourse of dark skin equals black beauty is destabilized in the talk of 'mixed race' black women. A dark skin shade and natural afro hair become ambiguous signifiers as the women's talk leads to a mobility of black beauty. Their talk is thus an interception in which there can never be a definitive reading of black beauty while also pointing to the binaries of the black anti-racist aesthetics on which they draw. Thus, while women are rooted in racialized and racializing notions of beauty they expand the boundaries of the beautiful black woman's body. Black beauty as an undecidable resists binaries without ever constituting a third term and arises through the disidentification and shame of cultural melancholia. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Title:
Black children away from home: Black children—issues of identity.
Authors:
Coleman, Jacquelyn, Guy's Hosp, Children & Adolescent Team, London, England
Source:
Educational and Child Psychology, Vol 14(2), 1997. pp. 34-41.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
United Kingdom : British Psychological Society
ISSN:
0267-1611 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
self & ethnic identity development, Black & mixed race children living in care of Social Service, England
Abstract:
Discusses the experiences of Black children in the care of Social Services and away from home. The issues explored are particularly pertinent for these children in making sense of their own identities, lives and emotional attachments. The material referred to is drawn from work carried out within the Southwark Social Services/Guy's Hospital Child Psychology's Service for Black Children Looked After program. The author concentrates on the concept of self- and ethnic identity as it affects Black children and children of mixed parentage. W. E. Cross's (1991) model of identity development is referred to and is found to be helpful in understanding self-rejection and conflict not as indicative of long-term crisis, but as part of a process, a quest for self and integration. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Database:

Record: 54
Title:
Blacks' and Whites' perceptions of verbal aggression.
Authors:
Phelps, Rosemary E., U Georgia, Coll of Education, Athens, US
Meara, Naomi M.
Davis, Kathleen L.
Patton, Michael J.
Source:
Journal of Counseling & Development, Vol 69(4), Mar-Apr, 1991. pp. 345-350.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
US : American Association for Counseling and Development
Other Journal Titles:
Occupations; Personnel & Guidance Journal; The Vocational Guidance Magazine
Other Publishers:
US : American Counseling Assn
US : American Personnel & Guidance Association
US : Graduate School of Education, Harvard University
US : National Occupational Conference
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0748-9633 (Print)
1556-6676 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
same vs mixed race target dyads, perceptions of verbal aggression in vignette interactions, 18–41 yr old Black vs White females
Abstract:
80 Black and 80 White undergraduate and graduate women (aged 18–41 yrs) were presented with a set of materials depicting 2 women as verbally aggressive. In a between-Ss design, each S was presented with a set of materials depicting one of the following: 2 women who were (1) of the same race as the S, (2) of a different race from the S, or (3) a mixed racial pair. Each S was asked to rate the randomly chosen identified aggressor on several variables related to aggression. Results of a 2 × 2 × 2 multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) involving race of participant, race of identified aggressor, and race of target indicate a main effect of race of Ss such that the White Ss viewed all episodes as more aggressive than the Black Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Aggressive Behavior; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Perception; *Verbal Communication; Blacks; Whites

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 55
Title:
Blood pressure, ethnicity, and psychosocial resources.
Authors:
Dressler, William W., U Alabama, Coll of Community Health Sciences, University
dos Santos, Jose E.
Viteri, Fernando E.
Source:
Psychosomatic Medicine, Vol 48(7), Sep-Oct, 1986. pp. 509-519.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
US : Lippincott Williams & Wilkins
ISSN:
0033-3174 (Print)
1534-7796 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
psychosocial resources such as social supports & coping styles, BP pressure, Black vs White vs mixed race Ss, Brazil, implications for risks for hypertension
Abstract:
Examined the hypothesis that psychosocial resources (including social supports and coping styles) help to protect individuals from risk associated with psychosocial stressors and that the protective effect may extend to standard risk factors as well. In a study of 128 Ss (mean age 33.1 yrs) conducted in Brazil, it was found that psychosocial resources modified Black–White differences in blood pressure. Highest mean blood pressures were observed among mixed-race and Black Brazilians who had low psychosocial resources; Afro-Brazilians with high psychosocial resources had lower blood pressures than White Brazilians. Implications of these results for the mechanisms linking ethnicity, psychosocial factors, and blood pressure are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Blood Pressure; *Coping Behavior; *Psychosocial Factors; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Support; At Risk Populations; Blacks; Hypertension; Racial and Ethnic Groups; Whites
PsycINFO Classification:
Cardiovascular Disorders (3295)
Population:
Human
Location:

Record: 56
Title:
Brazil in black and white? Race categories, the census, and the study of inequality.
Authors:
Loveman, Mara, Department of Sociology, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, US, mloveman@ssc.wisc.edu
Muniz, Jeronimo O., Department of Sociology, Federal University of Minas Gerais, Belo Horizonte, Brazil, jeronimo@fafich.ufmg.br
Bailey, Stanley R., Department of Sociology, University of California, Irvine, CA, US, bailey@uci.edu
Address:
Loveman, Mara, 1180 Observatory Drive, 8128 Sewell Social Science Building, Madison, WI, US, 53706-1393, mloveman@ssc.wisc.edu
Source:
Ethnic and Racial Studies, Vol 35(8), Aug, 2012. pp. 1466-1483.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0141-9870 (Print)
1466-4356 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Brazil, racial differences, social structure, policy making, census
Abstract:
Many scholars advocate the adoption of a black-and-white lens for the analysis of racial inequality in Brazil. Drawing on a nationally representative dataset that includes race questions in multiple formats, we evaluate how removal of the ‘brown’ category from the census or other social surveys would likely affect: (1) the descriptive picture of Brazil’s racial composition; and (2) estimates of income inequality between and within racial categories. We find that a forced binary question format results in a whiter and more racially unequal picture of Brazil through the movement of many higher income mixed-race respondents into the white category. We also find that regardless of question format, racial inequality in income accounts for relatively little of Brazil’s overall income inequality. We discuss implications for public policy debates in Brazil, and for the broader scientific and political challenges of ethnic and racial data collection and analysis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Government Policy Making; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Structure
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)

Record: 57
Title:
Breaking bad news to parents with disabled children: A cross-cultural study.
Authors:
Krauss-Mars, A. H., Children's Ctr, Rondebosch, South Africa
Lachman, P.
Source:
Child: Care, Health and Development, Vol 20(2), Mar-Apr, 1994. pp. 101-113.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0305-1862 (Print)
1365-2214 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
problems experienced when told by doctor or psychologist of child's physical &/or mental disability, White vs mixed vs Black parents of 2 mo to 7.1 yr olds, South Africa
Abstract:
Investigated the problems parents experienced when told that their child was physically and/or mentally disabled across different ethnic groups in South Africa. The parents of 65 children (aged 2–85 mo) drawn from a sample of 40 mixed race, 26 White, and 24 Black children participated. Except for the Xhosa speaking parents, the majority of parents received the diagnosis in their own language (English or Afrikaans). Most Xhosa speaking parents denied having received an explanation of the diagnosis, or having had an opportunity to ask questions. Only a few Black parents reported being asked as to their understanding of the diagnosis. White parents tended to deny the diagnosis of mental handicap more often than the other groups despite reporting that explanations were given. Most parents felt satisfied with the way the news was given to them and reported good progress in their children, and some of them expected their children to go to a normal school. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Emotional Responses; *Parents; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Therapeutic Processes; Blacks; Disorders; Mental Retardation; Racial and Ethnic Groups; Whites

Title:
Breaking barriers for multiracial individuals and families.
Authors:
Wehrly, Bea
Source:
Culture and counseling: New approaches. Harper, Frederick D. (Ed); McFadden, John (Ed); pp. 313-323; Needham Heights, MA, US: Allyn & Bacon; 2003. xxi, 426 pp.
Page Count:
11
ISBN:
0-205-35901-9 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multiracial individuals, interracial families, counseling strategies, barriers
Abstract:
In this brief chapter, the author hopes to achieve two goals: (1) to introduce readers to issues, challenges, and barriers faced by multiracial individuals and interracial families in the United States and (2) to suggest counseling strategies for helping people in the mixed-race population to overcome these barriers. The history of race mixing in the United States is addressed in Wehrly (1996) and Wehrly, Kenney, and Kenney (1999) and will not be repeated here. After a section on definitions of terms pertinent to the interracial population, this chapter will concentrate on societal and professional issues related to work with the mixed-race population and on counseling strategies to assist mixed-race individuals and families in breaking barriers that may be inhibiting the attainment of their full human potential. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

PsycINFO
Record: 59
Title:
Built and Social Environments: Associations with Adolescent Overweight and Activity.
Authors:
Nelson, Melissa C., Division of Epidemiology and Community Health, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, US, nelson@epi.umn.edu
Gordon-Larsen, Penny, Department of Nutrition, University of North Carolina, NC, US
Song, Yan, Department of City and Regional Planning, Chapel Hill, NC, US
Popkin, Barry M., Department of Nutrition, University of North Carolina, NC, US
Address:
Nelson, Melissa C., Division of Epidemiology and Community Health, University of Minnesota, 1300 S. 2nd Street, WBOB Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN, US, 55454-1015, nelson@epi.umn.edu
Source:
American Journal of Preventive Medicine, Vol 31(2), Aug, 2006. pp. 109-117.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0749-3797 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
overweight, physical activity, neighborhood characteristics, social environments, socioeconomic status, built
Abstract:
Background: Little is known about the patterning of neighborhood characteristics, beyond the basic urban, rural, suburban trichotomy, and its impact on physical activity (PA) and overweight. Methods: Nationally representative data (National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health, 1994-1995, n =20,745) were collected. Weight, height, PA, and sedentary behavior were self-reported. Using diverse measures of the participants' residential neighborhoods (e.g., socioeconomic status, crime, road type, street connectivity, PA recreation facilities), cluster analyses identified homogeneous groups of adolescents sharing neighborhood characteristics. Poisson regression predicted relative risk (RR) of being physically active (five or more bouts/week of moderate to vigorous PA) and overweight (body mass index equal or greater than the 95th percentile, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention/National Center for Health Statistics growth curves). Results: Six robust neighborhood patterns were identified: (1) rural working class; (2) exurban; (3) newer suburban; (4) upper-middle class, older suburban; (5) mixed-race urban; and (6) low-socioeconomic-status (SES) inner-city areas. Compared to adolescents living in newer suburbs, those in rural working-class (adjusted RR[ARR]=1.38, 95% confidence interval [CI]=1.13-1.69), exurban (ARR=1.30, CI=1.04-1.64), and mixed-race urban (ARR=1.31, CI=1.05-1.64) neighborhoods were more likely to be overweight, independent of individual SES, age, and race/ethnicity. Adolescents living in older suburban areas were more likely to be physically active than residents of newer suburbs (ARR=1.11, CI=1.04-1.18). Those living in low-SES inner-city neighborhoods were more likely to be active, though not significantly so, compared to mixed-race urban residents (ARR=1.09, CI=1.00-1.18). Conclusions: These findings demonstrate disadvantageous associations between specific rural and urban environments and behavior, illustrating important effects of the neighborhood on health and the inherent complexity of assessing residential landscapes across the United States. Simple classical urban-suburban-rural measures mask these important complexities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Motor Processes; *Obesity; *Social Environments; Adolescent Psychology; Neighborhoods; Socioeconomic Status
PsycINFO Classification:

Population:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 60
Title:
Can we tolerate the relationships that race compels?
Parent Book Series:
Systemic thinking and practice series
Authors:
Campbell, David, Tavistock Clinic, London, England
Source:
Culture and reflexivity in systemic psychotherapy: Mutual perspectives. Krause, Inga-Britt (Ed); pp. 39-51; London, England: Karnac Books; 2012. xxxv, 234 pp.
Page Count:
13
ISBN:
978-1-85575-778-3 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
systemic psychotherapy, culture, reflexivity, therapeutic relationship, race, family therapy, dialogue, conversations
Abstract:
For me, one of the influential ideas within the original Milan approach to family therapy was coined by Shands (1971), who advocated that we should strive to "stamp out nouns", and I think this could not be more appropriate than it is in this potentially volatile field of race and culture. If we see race and culture as "nouns", that is, fixed entities with attached meanings; we lose the potential to see them as pauses in ongoing conversations (Krause, 2002). It would be helpful to see terms such as black, white, or mixed race as pauses or stopping points in ongoing conversations about race. The conversations take place in particular contexts containing elements of the past and the future, but if they can be constructed in a dialogical format they acquire the ability to change and develop new meanings. I think we have an ethical responsibility, if we choose to become engaged in this topic, to keep conversations going. So, the focus of this chapter is how to introduce the topic of race and culture into dialogical processes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Conversation; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Family Therapy; *Psychotherapeutic Processes; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Culture (Anthropological); Race (Anthropological)
PsycINFO Classification:

Culture & Ethnology (2930)

Chapter

15

PsycINFO
Record: 61
Title:
Cannabis use disorders are comparatively prevalent among nonwhite racial/ethnic groups and adolescents: A national study.
Authors:
Wu, Li-Tzy, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US, litzy.wu@duke.edu
Brady, Kathleen T., South Carolina Clinical and Translational Research Institute, Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, SC, US
Mannelli, Paolo, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US
Killeen, Therese K., Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Clinical Neuroscience Division, Charleston, SC, US
Institutional Authors:
NIDA AAPI Workgroup, Bethesda, MD, US
Address:
Wu, Li-Tzy, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Duke University School of Medicine, Box 3903, Durham, NC, US, 27710, litzywu@yahoo.com
Source:
Journal of Psychiatric Research, Vol 50, Mar, 2014. pp. 26-35.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0022-3956 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cannabis use disorders, ethnic groups, major depression, alcohol disorder, nicotine dependence
Abstract:
The racial/ethnic composition of the US population is shifting, with the nonwhite population growing faster than whites. We examined cannabis use disorder (CUD) prevalences and correlates in seven racial/ethnic groups. We included cannabis use (CU) prevalence as a comparison. Data were from the 2005–2011 National Surveys on Drug Use and Health (N = 394,400). Substance use among respondents aged ≥12 years was assessed by computer-assisted, self-interviewing methods. The following were included as control variables: age, sex, family income, government assistance, county type, residential stability, major depressive episode history, arrest history, nicotine dependence, alcohol disorder, and survey year. Past-year CU prevalence increased significantly from 10.45% in 2005 to 11.41–11.54% during 2009–2011. Compared with whites, mixed-race individuals had higher odds of CU; Asian Americans and Hispanics had lower odds of CU. There were no significant yearly changes in CUD prevalence in the sample during 2005–2011 (1.58–1.73%). Compared with whites, individuals who were mixed-race, black, and Native American had higher odds of CUD; Asian Americans had lower odds. In aggregate, 15.35% of past-year cannabis users met criteria for a CUD in the 12-month period. Past-year cannabis users who were black, Native American, Hispanic, or Asian American had higher odds of CUD than white users. In each racial/ethnic group, adolescent cannabis users generally showed greater odds of CUD than adult users. Behavioral health indicators (major depressive episode, arrest history, nicotine dependence, alcohol disorder) were associated with CU and CUD. In conclusion, CUD disproportionally affects nonwhite groups and youth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 62
Title:
Capturing 'mixed race' in the decennial UK censuses: Are current approaches sustainable in the age of globalization and superdiversity?
Authors:
Aspinall, Peter J., University of Kent, Canterbury, United Kingdom
Song, Miri, University of Kent, Canterbury, United Kingdom
Source:
Global mixed race. King-O'Riain, Rebecca C. (Ed); Small, Stephen (Ed); Mahtani, Minelle (Ed); Song, Miri (Ed); Spickard, Paul (Ed); pp. 213-237; New York, NY, US: New York University Press; 2014. xxii, 335 pp.
Page Count:
25
ISBN:
978-0-8147-7073-3 (Hardcover)
978-0-8147-8915-5 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed-race, globalization, super-diversity, ethnic identity, minority groups
Abstract:
This chapter discusses mixed-race in the decennial UK census and whether the approaches sustainable in the age of globalization and super-diversity. Multiethnic states such as Britain face various challenges in the classification and enumeration of ethnic minority, populations in the future due to two main demographic changes. First, in the new global migration, many of the new-migrant groups have no link historically or culturally to Britain's colonial past, but comprise what Kymlicka calls "polyethnic minorities." Second, a significant growth in mixed partnerships and people, and their increasingly diverse modes of identification, poses key questions about the validity and reliability of official classifications. Understandings of "race" and the significance of ethnic and racial difference are not only changeable across time, but are also sensitive to specific contexts and localities. Understandings of "race" and "mixed race" are moving targets, and thus there is always a potential disjuncture between ordinary understandings and practices "on the ground," and official measures of such complex phenomena. Where there is a need for data on the ethnic diversity of the population, new forms of data collection are needed. At a population group level, multiticking probably offers the best opportunity, in spite of concerns about data quality and response stability. However, "origins-based 'groupness'" may best be captured by an ancestry or ethnic origins question of the type that has been asked in the US and Canadian censuses. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Globalization; *Interethnic Family; *Minority Groups; *Racial and Ethnic Differences
PsycINFO Classification:

Population:

England; Wales

Chapter

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 63
Title:
Caregiver Appraisals of Functional Dependence in Individuals With Dementia and Associated Caregiver Upset: Psychometric Properties of a New Scale and Response Patterns by Caregiver and Care Recipient Characteristics.
Authors:
Gitlin, Laura N., Thomas Jefferson University, Philadelphia, PA, US
Roth, David L., University of Alabama, Birmingham, AL, US
Burgio, Louis D., University of Alabama, Birmingham, AL, US
Loewenstein, David A., University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL, US
Winter, Laraine, Thomas Jefferson University, Philadelphia, PA, US
Nichols, Linda, University of Tennessee, TN, US
Argüelles, Soledad, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL, US
Corcoran, Mary, George Washington University, Washington, DC, US
Burns, Robert, University of Tennessee, TN, US
Martindale, Jennifer, University of Tennessee, TN, US
Source:
Journal of Aging and Health, Vol 17(2), Apr, 2005. pp. 148-171.
Page Count:
24
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0898-2643 (Print)
1552-6887 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
caregiver appraisals, functional dependence, dementia, caregiver reaction, Caregiver Assessment of Function and Upset, psychometric properties
Abstract:
Objective: To evaluate psychometric properties and response patterns of the Caregiver Assessment of Function and Upset (CAFU), a 15-item multidimensional measure of dependence in dementia patients and caregiver reaction. Method: 640 families were administered the CAFU (53% White, 43% African American, and 4% mixed race and ethnicity). We created a random split of the sample and conducted exploratory factor analyses on Sample 1 and confirmatory factor analyses on Sample 2. Convergent and discriminant validity were evaluated using Spearman rank correlation coefficients. Results: A two-factor structure for functional items was derived, and excellent factorial validity was obtained. Convergent and discriminant validity were obtained for function and upset measures. Differential response patterns for dependence and caregiver upset were found for caregiver race, relationship, and care recipient gender but not for caregiver gender. Discussion: The CAFU is easily administered, reliable, and valid for evaluating appraisals of dependencies and upsetting care areas. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Caregiver Burden; *Caregivers; *Dementia; *Measurement; *Psychometrics

Record: 64
Title:
Case study of a 19-year-old female sexually abused as a child.
Authors:
Dillon, Catherine M., Objective/Projective Tests, Inc., Brooklandville, MD, US
Source:
Studies of objective/projective personality tests. Karp, Stephen A. (Ed); pp. 139-148; Brooklandville, MD, US: Objective/Projective Tests; 1999. 160 pp.
Page Count:
10
Language:
English
Keywords:
interpretation of scores on Draw-A-Person Questionnaire & Karp Objective Word Association Test & Apperceptive Personality Test: Brief Adult, 19 yr old female sexually abused as a child
Abstract:
Monta, a 19-yr-old female of mixed race, was sexually abused by men living with her mother between ages 6 and 12. Pregnant at 16 she dropped out of school, went on welfare, entered a therapy support group for abuse victims, and is currently attempting to finish high school. She volunteered to take a battery of tests for the author and took the Draw-A-Person Questionnaire (S. A. Karp, 1990, 1999), Karp Objective Word Association Test (Karp, 1996) and the Apperceptive Personality Test: Brief Adult (Karp et al, 1993). Findings are compared and contrasted across tests. The author concludes that Monta's results reflect many problems, the most consistent reflecting emotional immaturity and distorted views of sex. Despite the negative life experiences, her outlook is comparatively positive. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Child Abuse; *Projective Personality Measures; *Sexual Abuse; *Test Interpretation; Apperception; Human Figures Drawing; Questionnaires; Victimization; Word Associations

PsycINFO
Record: 65
Title:
Categorical and contextual bases of person memory and stereotyping.
Authors:
Taylor, Shelley E., Harvard U
Fiske, Susan T.
Etcoff, Nancy L.
Ruderman, Audrey J.
Source:
Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, Vol 36(7), Jul, 1978. pp. 778-793.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
ISSN:
0022-3514 (Print)
1939-1315 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
sex & race structure of interacting small groups & membership in group, person memory & stereotyping, college students as social perceivers
Abstract:
In 3 studies, a total of 207 White university summer school students observed slide and type portrayals of interacting small groups that were of mixed sex or mixed race. Hypotheses were that (a) social perceivers encode person information by race and sex; (b) this fact leads to minimizing within-group and exaggerating between-group differences; (c) perceivers stereotype accordingly; (d) within-group attributes, both stereotyped and nonstereotyped, are exaggerated in inverse proportion to the size of the minority subgroup; (e) better discriminations are made within smaller subgroups; (f) imputations of attributes to groups as a whole are also sensitive to the makeup of the group; and (g) all these behaviors are attenuated when the perceiver is a member of the subgroup evaluated. All but the last hypothesis received at least partial support. Results are discussed in terms of categorization processes and suggest that normal cognitive processes explain the process of stereotyping quite well. (32 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Group Structure; *Human Sex Differences; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Perception; *Stereotyped Attitudes; Classification (Cognitive Process); Group Participation
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Perception & Cognition (3040)

Record: 67
Title:
Children's ability to recognize other children's faces.
Authors:
Feinman, Saul, U Wyoming
Entwisle, Doris R.
Source:
Child Development, Vol 47(2), Jun, 1976. pp. 506-510.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Journal Titles:
Child Development: Abstracts & Bibliography
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0009-3920 (Print)
1467-8624 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
age & race & integrated vs segregated school, facial recognition ability, 1st vs 2nd vs 3rd vs 6th graders
Abstract:
Studied facial recognition ability in 288 children from 4 grades—1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 6th—who also varied by sex, race, and school type, the last being segregated or integrated. Ss judged whether each of 40 pictures of children's faces had been present in a set of 20 pictures viewed earlier. Facial recognition ability increased significantly with each grade but leveled off between ages 8 and 11. Blacks' performance was significantly better than Whites', and Blacks were better at recognizing faces of Whites than Whites were at recognizing Blacks. Ss from an integrated school showed smaller differences recognizing Black or White faces than Ss from segregated schools, but the effect appeared only for Ss of the integrated school who also lived in mixed-race neighborhoods. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Age Differences; *Facial Features; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Recognition (Learning); *School Integration; Elementary School Students; Perceptual Development; Pictorial Stimuli; Visual Perception

Record: 68
Title:
Cigarette smoking for weight loss or control among adolescents: Gender and racial/ethnic differences.
Authors:
Fulkerson, Jayne A., U Minnesota, Dept of Epidemiology, Minneapolis, MN, US, fulkerson@epi.umn.edu
French, Simone A., U Minnesota, Dept of Epidemiology, Minneapolis, MN, US
Address:
Fulkerson, Jayne A., Div of Epidemiology, U Minnesota, 1300 South Second Street, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN, US, 55454, fulkerson@epi.umn.edu
Source:
Journal of Adolescent Health, Vol 32(4), Apr, 2003. pp. 306-313.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of Adolescent Health Care
ISSN:
1054-139X (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cigarette smoking, weight control, racial/ethnic differences, gender differences, adolescents
Abstract:
Describes gender and racial/ethnic differences in the prevalence of cigarette smoking for weight loss or control in an adolescent population-based sample, and relationships among heavy smoking, weight concerns and smoking to lose or control weight. Anonymous questionnaires were administered to 81,247 9th and 12th grade public school students. Variables of interest included smoking frequency, weight concerns, and smoking for weight loss or control. With the exception of black females, female smokers of different racial/ethnic groups were as likely as white girls to smoke for weight loss or control. Compared to white male smokers, American Indian and Asian American male smokers were more likely to smoke for weight loss or control, and black, Hispanic, and mixed race male smokers were equally likely to smoke for weight loss or control. Heavy smokers, smokers who perceived themselves as overweight or were weight-concerned were significantly more likely to report smoking as a weight control method. Smoking for weight control is prevalent across many race/ethinic groups and both genders among adolescents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Adolescent Attitudes; *Human Sex Differences; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Tobacco Smoking; *Weight Control; Weight Loss

Record: 69
Title:
Clinical commentary: Ben.
Authors:
Bellman, Debbie Bandler, Child and Adolescent Section, British Association of Psychotherapists, United Kingdom
Address:
Bellman, Debbie Bandler, 27 Somali Road, London, United Kingdom, NW2 3RN
Source:
Journal of the British Association of Psychotherapists (BAP), Vol 42(1), Jan, 2004. pp. 63-66.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
US : John Wiley & Sons
ISSN:
0954-0350 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
omnipotence, psychotherapy, therapists, psychotherapeutic process
Abstract:
This is a lively and sensitive account of a session with a latency-aged boy beginning to engage in a dialogue with his therapist. As such it illustrates what must have been an internal change, a change that allowed Ben to feel safe enough to have moments of talking to the therapist as a nine-year-old boy as opposed to as a superhero. It is helpful to know at the outset that a first sibling is soon due, and to have a sense of the material preceding the session given. The introduction conveys a clear sense of Ben as a boy relying on omnipotent defences to protect him from feeling frightened, helpless, powerless, and perhaps also terrifyingly small in the face of others experienced as mercilessly powerful. The session begins in the waiting room. Ben is hiding. Understandably, the therapist does not want to engage in play in the waiting room, but Ben is disappointed to be found. Soon Ben puts the therapist on the spot in regard to the date of his birthday. At this point in the session, however, Ben withdraws when the therapist explicitly takes up his anxiety about the new baby messing up his birthday. We also learn why we were given the detail that Ben is a boy of mixed race. The baby must have a different father from Ben, as the new sibling will be white. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Omnipotence; *Psychotherapeutic Processes; *Psychotherapy; *Therapists
PsycINFO Classification:
Psychotherapy & Psychotherapeutic Counseling (3310)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 70
Title:
Clinical material: Ben.
Authors:
No authorship indicated
Source:
Journal of the British Association of Psychotherapists (BAP), Vol 42(1), Jan, 2004. pp. 51-54.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
US : John Wiley & Sons
ISSN:
0954-0350 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
psychotherapy, television watching, computer games, verbal abuse, anxiety, manic activity, worries
Abstract:
This session occurs in the fifth term of twice-weekly psychotherapy with a nine-year-old mixed-race boy. In the weeks before this session, the therapy time has been filled with much manic activity. Ben has been leaping around the room with great athletic agility from chair to table to sofa while at the same time recounting to me in much detail and with a great deal of animation the exploits of his favourite characters from films such as Spiderman, Dragonball-Z and the James Bond films. Attempts by me to help him feel less anxious and to think about what is behind all this activity have usually been met with verbal abuse or an angry leaving of the room. He has been particularly hostile to any links I have tried to make between his worries and the impending arrival of a first sibling. However, we have been able to establish together that watching television and playing computer games are his 'addiction' (his words), and that he feels that he needs to act like a warrior and be on his mettle most of the time as life can be so frightening. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 71
Title:
Communicating prejudice in the media: Upending racial categories in Doubles.
Authors:
Ono, Kent O., U California, Davis, CA, US
Source:
Communicating prejudice. Hecht, Michael L. (Ed); pp. 206-220; Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; 1998. ix, 404 pp.
Page Count:
15
ISBN:
0-7619-0124-8 (Hardcover)
0-7619-0125-6 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
text analysis of media representations of race & their role in construction of political realities & social practices & communication of prejudice
Abstract:
This chapter examines how prejudice is communicated in the media. The author focuses his discussion on representations of race and seeks an analytic frame that avoids recreating the system it attempts to critique. He seeks to articulate a lens for explicating media that neither embraces racialization and racial divisions nor accepts a priori racial definitions that maintain existing hierarchies. After reviewing the predominant trends in research on media representations of race (good-bad representations, discrimination, pedagogy about race, audience reception, images and stereotypes, and uses and gratifications), he describes recent trends that examine Whiteness, diaspora, exhilic experiences, and "otherness." From these trends, he builds his discussion based on the assumption that media representations are sites of political contestation involving disparities of power. He is concerned about how media images participate in the construction of political realities in addition to reflecting social practice. He uses a text, Doubles, which problematizes binary, essentializing racial purity by focusing on bi- and mixed-race people to challenge images of racial purity and unpack the practice of substituting "American" for "White." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (introduction)
Subjects:
*Communication; *Imagery; *Mass Media; *Prejudice; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; Politics; Interpersonal Control
PsycINFO Classification:
Mass Media Communications (2750)
Population:
Human
Intended Audience:
Psychology: Professional & Research (PS)
Format Covered:
Print

Book; Edited Book
Document Type:
Chapter

1998-07470-010

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 72
Title:
Community music therapy with adolescents.
Authors:
Ragland, Zane, Osawatomie State Hosp, Rainbow Unit, Kansas City, KS
Apprey, Maurice
Source:
Journal of Music Therapy, Vol 11(3), Fal 1974. pp. 147-155.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
US : American Music Therapy Assn
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Oxford University Press
ISSN:
0022-2917 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
community music therapy, modification of disturbed behavior patterns & adjustment & communication skills, 12-17 yr olds
Abstract:
Describes a music project with 4 basic goals: (a) to recognize, modify, and reconstruct disturbed behavior patterns; (b) to improve adolescents' adjustment to school, community, church, domestic situations, and personal problems; (c) to alleviate shame, allow self-expression, and achieve verbal and nonverbal catharsis; (d) to teach communication skills and various strategies for survival-social, educational, and spiritual. Ss were 22 12-17 yr olds of mixed race and religious affiliation. Choral music led to related group activities; other results of the project during 21/2 yrs are also described. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved)

*Music Therapy

Record: 73
Title:
Community Undesirability in Black and White: Examining Racial Residential Preferences through Community Perceptions.
Authors:
Krysan, Maria, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL, US, krysan@uic.edu
Address:
Krysan, Maria, Department of Sociology, University of Illinois at Chicago, (m/c 312), 1007 W. Harrison Street, Chicago, IL, US, 60607, krysan@uic.edu
Source:
Social Problems, Vol 49(4), Nov, 2002. pp. 521-543.
Page Count:
23
Publisher:
US : University of California Press
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Oxford University Press
ISSN:
0037-7791 (Print)
1533-8533 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
community undesirability, blacks, whites, racial residential preferences, community perceptions, neighborhoods
Abstract:
While studies of racial residential preferences generally converge on the pattern that blacks prefer neighborhoods with a substantial proportion of African Americans, but whites are uncomfortable with no more than 20% black, the forces underlying these preferences receive comparatively less empirical attention. This paper uses perceptions of community undesirability as a measure of racial residential preferences to address this question. Data come from the Multi-City Study of Urban Inequality, which asked large samples of whites and African Americans in Atlanta, Boston, Detroit, and Los Angeles to rate the desirability of 5-7 local communities. In addition to the closed-ended ratings, this paper draws on a systematic analysis of open-ended survey data asking respondents to explain why they find communities undesirable. Overall, blacks rate most communities as more desirable than whites, and African Americans find desirable many of the communities in which they are the numerical minority. Whites rate mixed race communities as undesirable, in part because of a desire to avoid black neighbors, but also because of what may be an over-inflated perception of crime in those communities. Analyses of African American community ratings highlight the importance of racial climate in shaping perceptions of communities and argue against the assertion that racial composition alone is the key factor in black preferences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Communities; *Neighborhoods; *Preferences; *Racial and Ethnic Relations; Blacks; Whites
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:

Location:
US

Adulthood (18 yrs & older)

PsycINFO
Record: 74
Title:
Comorbid substance use disorders with other axis I and II mental disorders among treatment-seeking Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians/Pacific Islanders, and mixed-race people.
Authors:
Wu, Li-Tzy, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US, litzy.wu@duke.edu
Blazer, Dan G., Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US
Gersing, Kenneth R., Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US
Burchett, Bruce, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US
Swartz, Marvin S., Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US
Mannelli, Paolo, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US
Institutional Authors:
NIDA AAPI Workgroup
Address:
Wu, Li-Tzy, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Duke University School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Box 3903, Durham, NC, US, 27710, litzywu@yahoo.com
Source:
Journal of Psychiatric Research, Vol 47(12), Dec, 2013. pp. 1940-1948.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0022-3956 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
comorbidity, substance use disorders, mental disorders, treatment seeking behavior, racial differences, Asian Americans, mixed race people, biracial, Native Hawaiians, Pacific Islanders
Abstract:
Little is known about behavioral healthcare needs of Asian Americans (AAs), Native Hawaiians/Pacific Islanders (NHs/PIs), and mixed-race people (MRs)dthe fastest growing segments of the U.S. population. We examined substance use disorder (SUD) prevalences and comorbidities among AAs, NHs/PIs, and MRs (N = 4572) in a behavioral health electronic health record database. DSM-IV diagnoses among patients aged 1-90 years who accessed behavioral healthcare from 11 sites were systematically captured: SUD, anxiety, mood, personality, adjustment, childhood-onset, cognitive/dementia, dissociative, eating, factitious, impulse-control, psychotic/schizophrenic, sleep, and somatoform diagnoses. Of all patients, 15.0% had a SUD. Mood (60%), anxiety (31.2%), adjustment (30.9%), and disruptive (attention deficit-hyperactivity, conduct, oppositional defiant, disruptive behavior diagnosis, 22.7%) diagnoses were more common than others (psychotic 14.2%, personality 13.3%, other childhood-onset 11.4%, impulse-control 6.6%, cognitive 2.8%, eating 2.2%, somatoform 2.1%). Less than 1% of children aged < 12 years had SUD. Cannabis diagnosis was the primary SUD affecting adolescents aged 12e17. MRs aged 35-49 years had the highest prevalence of cocaine diagnosis. Controlling for age at first visit, sex, treatment setting, length of treatment, and number of comorbid diagnoses, NHs/PIs and MRs were about two times more likely than AAs to have ≥ 2 SUDs. Regardless of race/ethnicity, personality diagnosis was comorbid with SUD. NHs/PIs with a mood diagnosis had elevated odds of having SUD. Findings present the most comprehensive patterns of mental diagnoses available for treatment-seeking AAs, NHs/PIs, and MRs in the real-world medical setting. In-depth research is needed to elucidate intraracial and interracial differences in treatment needs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Comorbidity; *Drug Abuse; *Mental Disorders; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Asians; Hawaii Natives; Health Care Seeking Behavior; Pacific Islanders

Title:
Competing narratives: Race and multiraciality in the Brazilian racial order.
Authors:
Daniel, G. Reginald, University of California, Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, CA, US
Lee, Andrew Michael
Source:
Global mixed race. King-O'Riain, Rebecca C. (Ed); Small, Stephen (Ed); Mahtani, Minelle (Ed); Song, Miri (Ed); Spickard, Paul (Ed); pp. 91-118; New York, NY, US: New York University Press; 2014. xxii, 335 pp.
Page Count:
28
ISBN:
978-0-8147-7073-3 (Hardcover)
978-0-8147-8915-5 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial formation theory, multiraciality, racial order, narratives, identity politics
Abstract:
Drawing from Omi's and Winant's racial formation theory, the competing narratives are defined racial projects that exhibit both cultural and political initiatives endeavoring to bring about social structural change. The cultural initiatives involve identity politics that strive to rescue identities from distortion and erasure by the dominant society; the political initiatives seek to reorganize and redistribute resources, and have called upon the state to play a key role. This chapter examines these racial projects as they relate to the intersection of Black and multiracial identity politics and the politics of collecting racial data as in the census and affirmative action. In order to achieve their objectives, these projects have engaged in what racial formation theory defines as re-articulation. This entails redefining racial identities and political interests by recombining familiar ideas and values in new ways. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Interethnic Family; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Multiculturalism; Narratives; Politics; Theories
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Location:
Brazil

Title:
Conciliator of chief: Obama, his family and his presidency.
Authors:
Fuchsman, Kenneth
Source:
The Journal of Psychohistory, Vol 40(1), Sum 2012. pp. 50-65.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
US : Assn for Psychohistory
Reviewed Item:
Jacobs, Sally H. (2011) The Other Barack: The Bold and Reckless Life of President Obama's Father New York, Public Affairs, xiv, 297 pp., $27.99. Hardcover

Sharma, Dinesh. (2011) Barack Obama in Hawai'i and Indonesia: The Making of a Global President Santa Barbara, CA: Praeger, xxvi, 274 pp., $48. Hardcover

Frank, Justin A. (2011) Obama on the Couch: Inside the Mind of the President New York: Free Press, 269 pp., $26. Hardcover

Renshon, Stanley A. (2011) Barack Obama and the Politics of Redemption New York: Routledge, 386 pp., 2011, $24.95, Hardcover

Suskind, Ron. (2011) Confidence Men: Wall Street, Washington, and the Education of a President New York: Harper, 515 pp., $29.99, Hardcover
ISSN:
0145-3378 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
presidency, life, Barack Obama, family, economics, politics, culture, race, physical abuse, childhood, parent child relations
Abstract:
Reviews the books, The Other Barack: The Bold and Reckless Life of President Ohama's Father by Sally H. Jacobs (2011), Barack Obama in Hawai'i and Indonesia: The Making of a Global President by Dinesh Sharma (2011), Obama on the Couch: Inside the Mind of the President by Justin A. Frank (2011), Barack Obama and the Politics of Redemption by Stanley A. Renshon (2011) and Confidence Men: Wall Street, Washington, and the Education of A President by Ron Suskind (2011). Sally H. Jacobs' well-researched biography, The Other Barack: The Bold and Reckless Life of President Obama's Father, helps us sort through some myths surrounding the relationship of the President's parents. Dinesh Sharma writes about the physical abuse of Barack Jr.'s childhood in Indonesia and Hawaii. Justin Frank has written Obama on the Couch: Inside the Mind of the President. Frank recognizes that Ann Obama needed to disguise the family history when dealing with her son. For the notion of "the mother and son" being "left by the father," Frank writes, "is a fantasy" as the mother "was living in Settle at the time of Barack Sr's departure." Frank says this is a "myth" that protects Obama from anger at his mother. Stanley Renshon in Barack Obama and the Politics of Redemption, sees the President's political agenda as originating in his personal psychology. Renshon maintains "that Obama has still not reconciled himself to his mixed race and cultural background". Some of these diverging views can be clarified when examining how President Obama handled the economic and political challenges following the severe 2008 recession. Economic and political policy are central subjects of Ron Suskind's Confidence Men: Wall Street, Washington, and the Education of A President. His account of how Obama functioned in the drive for health care reform diverges from Renshon's. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Considering the significance of ancestry through the prism of mixed-race identity.
Authors:
Tashiro, Cathy J., U Washington, Tacoma, WA, US
Source:
Advances in Nursing Science, Vol 25(2), Dec, 2002. pp. 1-21.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
US : Lippincott Williams & Wilkins
ISSN:
0161-9268 (Print)
1550-5014 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
ancestry, racial identity, healthcare, mixed race, self identity, Blacks, Asian Americans
Abstract:
Examined the significance of ancestry on racial identity and its influence on healthcare. 20 individuals of mixed African-American-White and Asian-American-White ancestries (aged 45-94 yrs) completed interviews concerning self-identity. Results show that racial identity included the 5 dimensions of cultural identity, ascribed racial identity, racial identification to others, racial self-identification, and situational racialization of feeling. Mixed African-Americans described greater consistency in ascribed racial identity and a consistency between ascribed racial identity and racial identification to others. Mixed Asian-American subjects appeared to be less restricted by racial definitions. Findings suggest that the assessment of health care needs should not be based on narrow definitions of race. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 78
Title:
Conspiracy beliefs about HIV infection are common but not associated with delayed diagnosis or adherence to care.
Authors:
Clark, April, Department of Medicine, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, US
Mayben, Jennifer K., Department of Family and Community Medicine, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, US
Hartman, Christine, Department of Medicine, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, US
Kallen, Michael A., Department of Medicine, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, US
Giordano, Thomas P., Department of Medicine, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX, US, tpg@bcm.tmc.edu
Address:
Giordano, Thomas P., Michael E. DeBakey VA Medical Center, (152), 2002 Holcombe Boulevard, Houston, TX, US, 77030, tpg@bcm.tmc.edu
Source:
AIDS Patient Care and STDs, Vol 22(9), Sep, 2008. pp. 753-759.
Page Count:
7
Publisher:
US : Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.
ISSN:
1087-2914 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
conspiracy beliefs, HIV infection, delayed diagnosis, adherence to care
Abstract:
We sought to determine the prevalence of HIV conspiracy beliefs in patients with HIV and how those beliefs correlate with access and adherence to HIV care and health outcomes. From March to December 2005, 113 patients at four public facilities in Houston, Texas, diagnosed with HIV for 3 years or less, participated in a cross-sectional survey. Conspiracy beliefs were assessed with five items that dealt with HIV origin, cure, and vaccine. Medical records were reviewed for CD4 cell counts, HAART use, and appointment dates. Statistical analyses (including analysis of variance [ANOVA], χ² testing, and regression) determined the predictors of conspiracy beliefs and correlated them with outcomes. Sixty-three percent of the participants endorsed 1 or more conspiracy beliefs. African American patients more often held HIV conspiracy beliefs than white and other/mixed race patients (73%, 52%, 47%; p = 0.045). Persons holding 1 or more conspiracy beliefs had higher CD4 cell counts at diagnosis (254 cells/mm³ versus 92, p = 0.03); and similar rates of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) use (73% versus 71%), 100% adherence to HAART by self-report (53% versus 45%,), mean adherence by pharmacy refill (83% versus 87%), and gaps in care greater than 120 days (49% versus 53%), compared to subjects who did not hold any conspiracy beliefs (all p > 0.40). Since recruitment focused on patients in care, patients with extreme conspiracy beliefs may be underrepresented. Despite this, more than 50% of the study population endorsed 1 or more conspiracy belief. However, these beliefs did not negatively impact access or adherence to HIV care. Efforts to improve adherence to HIV care may not need to focus on eliminating conspiracy beliefs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Health Attitudes; *HIV; *Medical Diagnosis; *Treatment Compliance
PsycINFO Classification:
Immunological Disorders (3291)
Population:

Male
Female

US

Middle Age (40-64 yrs)

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2008-13743-009&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Conspiracy beliefs about HIV infection are common but not associated with delayed diagnosis or adherence to care.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 79
Title:
Construction and Initial Validation of the Multiracial Experiences Measure (MEM).
Authors:
Yoo, Hyung Chol
Jackson, Kelly F.
Guevarra, Rudy P. Jr.
Miller, Matthew J.
Harrington, Blair
Source:
Journal of Counseling Psychology, Oct 12, 2015.
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Other Publishers:
US : Wm. C. Brown Co.
ISSN:
0022-0167 (Print)
1939-2168 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multiracial experiences, mixed race, risk and resilience, measurement
Abstract:
This article describes the development and validation of the Multiracial Experiences Measure (MEM): a new measure that assesses uniquely racialized risks and resiliencies experienced by individuals of mixed racial heritage. Across 2 studies, there was evidence for the validation of the 25-item MEM with 5 subscales including Shifting Expressions, Perceived Racial Ambiguity, Creating Third Space, Multicultural Engagement, and Multiracial Discrimination. The 5-subscale structure of the MEM was supported by a combination of exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses. Evidence of criterion-related validity was partially supported with MEM subscales correlating with measures of racial diversity in one’s social network, color-blind racial attitude, psychological distress, and identity conflict. Evidence of discriminant validity was supported with MEM subscales not correlating with impression management. Implications for future research and suggestions for utilization of the MEM in clinical practice with multiracial adults are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
No terms assigned
PsycINFO Classification:
Health & Mental Health Treatment & Prevention (3300)
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Publication Status:
Online First Posting
Publication History:
Accepted: Aug 6, 2015; Revised: Jul 17, 2015; First Submitted: Mar 11, 2015
Release Date:
20151012
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1037/cou0000117
Accession Number:

Database:

Record: 80
Title:
Contextual variation in automatic evaluative bias to racially-ambiguous faces.
Authors:
Ito, Tiffany A., Department of Psychology, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, US, Tiffany.Ito@Colorado.Edu
Willadsen-Jensen, Eve C., Department of Psychology, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, US
Kaye, Jesse T., Department of Psychology, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, US
Park, Bernadette, Department of Psychology, University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, US
Address:
Ito, Tiffany A., Department of Psychology and Neuroscience, University of Colorado, 345 UCB, Boulder, CO, US, 80309-0345, Tiffany.Ito@Colorado.Edu
Source:
Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, Vol 47(4), Jul, 2011. pp. 818-823.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0022-1031 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
contextual variation, automatic evaluative bias, face perception, racial differences
Abstract:
Three studies examined the implicit evaluative associations activated by racially-ambiguous Black–White faces. In the context of both Black and White faces, Study 1 revealed a graded pattern of bias against racially-ambiguous faces that was weaker than the bias to Black faces but stronger than that to White faces. Study 2 showed that significant bias was present when racially-ambiguous faces appeared in the context of only White faces, but not in the context of only Black faces. Study 3 demonstrated that context produces perceptual contrast effects on racial-prototypicality judgments. Racially-ambiguous faces were perceived as more prototypically Black in a White-only than mixed-race context, and less prototypically Black in a Black-only context. Conversely, they were seen as more prototypically White in a Black-only than mixed context, and less prototypically White in a White-only context. The studies suggest that both race-related featural properties within a face (i.e., racial ambiguity) and external contextual factors affect automatic evaluative associations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Contextual Associations; *Cultural Test Bias; *Face Perception; *Racial and Ethnic Differences
PsycINFO Classification:
Visual Perception (2323)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Grant Sponsorship:
Sponsor: National Institute of Mental Health, US
Grant Number: R01MH071257
Recipients: Ito, Tiffany A.
Methodology:
Empirical Study; Quantitative Study
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Publication History:
First Posted: Mar 2, 2011; Revised: Dec 15, 2010; First Submitted: May 14, 2010
Release Date:
20110711
Correction Date:
20120618

PMID:
21691437
Accession Number:
2011-08619-012

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2011-08619-012&site=ehost-live&scope=site

Record: 81
Title:
'Course Is Team Taught': Dimensions of Difference in Classroom Pedagogy.
Authors:
Lengermann, Patricia, George Washington University, Washington, DC, US
Niebrugge, Jill, American University, Washington, DC, US
Source:
Journal of Lesbian Studies, Vol 9(4), 2005. pp. 57-72.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
US : Haworth Press
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
1089-4160 (Print)
1540-3548 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
classroom pedagogy, team teaching, poverty, couple team, personal experience
Abstract:
We report on students' response to kinds of difference in the classroom as we have assessed it in our personal experience as a same-sex, mixed race, leftist couple team teaching in two disciplines and at five separate schools over a number of years. We argue that students are more accepting of differences arising out of sexual preference and race and most resistant to differences arising out of class, especially poverty. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Classrooms; *Couples; *Life Experiences; *Teaching; *Team Teaching Method; Poverty

Record: 82
Title:
Creating connection: A relational-cultural approach with couples.
Book Series:
Family therapy and counseling
Authors:
Jordan, Judith V., (Ed), Jean Baker Miller Training Institute, Wellesley Centers for Women, Wellesley, MA, US
Carlson, Jon, (Ed), Division of Psychology and Counseling, Governors State University, University Park, IL, US
Source:
New York, NY, US: Routledge/Taylor & Francis Group; 2013. xx, 249 pp.
Page Count:
249
ISBN:
978-0-415-81758-5 (Paperback)
978-0-415-52991-4 (Hardcover)
978-0-203-11734-7 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
relational-cultural theory, couples therapy, psychotherapeutic techniques, treatment guidelines, relational resilience, well being, sociocultural factors, psychosocial factors, life span, psychological growth
Abstract:
Relational-Cultural Theory (RCT) posits that people grow through and toward relationship throughout the lifespan. Rather than emphasizing movement toward autonomy and self-sufficiency, it focuses on the power of connection in people's lives. Culture and power are seen as formative in individual and social development. As a model, RCT is ideal for work with couples: it encourages active participation in relationships, fosters the well-being of everyone involved, and provides guidelines for working with disconnections and building relational resilience. Creating Connection helps readers to understand the pain of disconnection and to use RCT to heal relationships in a variety of settings, including with heterosexual couples, stepparents, lesbian and gay couples, and mixed race couples. In addition to an emphasis on helping couples find authentic connection, RCT points to the need for changing the cultural conditions that contribute to the problems of disconnection. Polarities of "you vs. me" will be replaced with the healing concept of "us". (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (cover)
Subjects:
*Couples Therapy; *Psychotherapeutic Techniques; *Relationship Quality; *Resilience (Psychological); *Sociocultural Factors; Life Span; Psychosocial Factors; Treatment Guidelines; Well Being
PsycINFO Classification:
Group & Family Therapy (3313)
Population:
Human

Source: The multiracial experience: Racial borders as the new frontier.
Record: 83
Title:
Critical race theory and white racism: Is there room for white scholars in fighting racism in education?
Authors:
Bergerson, Amy Aldous, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT, US
Source:
International Journal of Qualitative Studies in Education, Vol 16(1), Jan-Feb, 2003. Special Issue: Whiteness issues in teacher education. pp. 51-63.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0951-8398 (Print)
1366-5898 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
critical race theory, CRT, educational researchers, educational settings, alternative methods, personal lives, white racism, academic performance, social justice
Abstract:
Critical race theory (CRT) offers educational researchers a compelling way to view racism in education by centering issues of race and using counterstories to challenge dominant views in both research and practice. This article provides an overview of CRT and illuminates the dilemmas for white researchers wishing to incorporate CRT into their work. The author argues that while CRT may not be fully open to white researchers, their strategic use of CRT can help legitimize its use in fighting racism in educational settings. Building on her participation in CRT discussions in a mixed-race setting, the author suggests that white researchers must work to center race in their personal lives and work, engage in the strategic and sensitive use of CRT, and join in the effort to legitimize research that utilizes alternative methods such as CRT. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Classroom Environment; *Multicultural Education; *Racism; *Social Dilemma; *Whites; Minority Groups

Record: 84
Title:
Crosscultural comparison of effects of instrumental enrichment on children in a South African mining town.
Authors:
Skuy, Mervyn, U of the Witwatersrand, Div of Specialised Education, Johannesburg, South Africa
Mentis, Martene
Durbach, Fleur
Cockcroft, Kate
Fridjhon, Peter
Mentis, Mandia
Source:
School Psychology International, Vol 16(3), Aug, 1995. pp. 265-282.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0143-0343 (Print)
1461-7374 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
instrumental enrichment, intellectual ability & creativity & self concept & scholastic achievement, White vs mixed race vs Black 5th graders, South Africa
Abstract:
Compared the effects of instrumental enrichment (IE) among 3 groups of 5th graders in segragated schools: 57 White children, 27 children of mixed race, and 37 Black children. The IE program was comprised of 14 paper-and-pencil instruments each focused on a different cognitive operation. Ss' teachers received workshops in the theory and practice of mediated learning experiences and a set of curriculum packages embodying IE concepts. Both prior to and following the IE program, Ss' performance was measured in the areas of intellectual ability, creativity, self-concept, and scholastic achievement. Postintervention improvements for all groups on cognitive measures were significant, with varying results on scholastic, creativity, and self-concept measures. The improvements were greatest among the Black Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Teaching Methods; Academic Achievement; Blacks; Cognitive Ability; Creativity; Elementary School Students; Self Concept; Whites

Title:
Cross-cultural issues and racism in a multi-cultural society.

Abstract:
convey and consider cultural, cross-cultural and racial issues as experienced in [the author's] work as a child psychotherapist [in Great Britain] (chapter)

describes how racial identity can be used for good or ill as a way of dealing with and organising our emotional needs and experiences / describes a [6-yr-old] girl who needs to be aware of her mixed race identity to understand the meaning her father has in her life and to be able to mourn his death / [presents the case of a 11-yr-old] boy who has made Black people the carrier of angry feelings about a Black stepfather as well as his own more vulnerable feelings / had this not been dealt with in therapy he might have turned to politically organised racism as an outlet for this feeling / psychotherapy or psychoanalysis cannot deal with organised racism, but it can give us insight into some of the forces behind it (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (book)

Record: 86
Title:
Cross-cultural study of facial beauty.
Authors:
Cruz, Germano Vera, University of Toulouse II, Poitiers, France, germano.veracruz@gmail.com
Address:
Cruz, Germano Vera, University of Toulouse II, 4, rue du Capitaine Dreyfus, Logement 25, 86000, Poitiers, France, germano.veracruz@gmail.com
Source:
Journal of Psychology in Africa, Vol 23(1), 2013. pp. 87-90.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
US : Elliott & Fitzpatrick
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of African Psychology; Journal of Psychology in Africa; South of the Sahara, the Caribbean, and Afro-Latin America
Other Publishers:
US : National Information Services Corporation
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
1433-0237 (Print)
1815-5626 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cross cultural facial beauty, judgment
Abstract:
This research studies proportionality, thinness and smooth skin as cross cultural facial beauty attributes. Participants (N = 450; males = 216, females = 234) were college students from three cultural areas: Mozambique (N = 150), Brazil (N = 150) and France (N = 150). They evaluated 25 facial images from real people of a mixed-race background (descendants of White and Black: all young females 18-24 years) for proportionality, thinness and smooth skin. The results show agreement between Mozambicans and Brazilians on the salience of proportionality and breadth of face as beauty attributes. The French participants were different in preferring a thinner face profile as a beauty quality. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Database:
