Record: 87
Title:
Cross-racial identification of transformed, untransformed, and mixed-race faces.
Authors:
Ayuk, Robinson E., U Wales, School of Psychology, Cardiff, Wales
Source:
International Journal of Psychology, Vol 25(4), Aug, 1990. pp. 509-527.
Page Count:
19
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0020-7594 (Print)
1464-066X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cross racial recognition of transformed vs untransformed vs mixed race faces, 18–44 yr olds, Europe vs Africa, replication & extension
Abstract:
Replicated and extended a study by H. D. Ellis and J. B. Deregowski (see record 1982-02697-001) by examining the recognition memory of 32 European and 32 African Ss (aged 18–44 yrs) for same-race, other-race, and mixed-race faces. Faces were either transformed or untransformed in pose between initial study and recognition test. No significant effects on cross-race eyewitness identification were found for either race or either S or target, nor were there any full cross-over interactions. Europeans found transformed faces generally more difficult to identify than Africans. Both races performed well on nontransformed cross-racial faces, but Europeans were significantly poorer on transformed Black faces, indicating an "other-race" effect. Task characteristics may be an important variable in cross-racial identification. (French abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cross Cultural Differences; *Face Perception; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Experimental Replication; Memory; Task Complexity
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Methodology:
Empirical Study; Experimental Replication
Format Covered:
Print

Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article

Record: 88
Title:
Cuban teacher perspectives on race and racism: The pedagogy of home-school relations.
Authors:
Kempf, Arlo
Source:
Teachers College Record, Vol 116(6), Jun, 2014. pp. 1-21.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
US : Teachers College, Columbia University
Other Journal Titles:
Rec. Trav. Offert Georgévitch, Beograd

ISSN:
0161-4681 (Print)

Language:

Keywords:
race, racism, pedagogy, Cuban teacher perspectives, parents, professional responsibility, home-school relations
Abstract:
Background/Context: Cuba’s education system has been the focus of academic study by researchers on and off the island who frequently cite the comparative success of Cuban students on measures such as the UNESCO math and language assessments. Few studies, however, consider the significance of race within Cuban education generally or the home–school relationship in particular. Indeed, there has been no empirical work made available on these topics for nearly a decade. Significant sociopolitical changes are underway in Cuba, with implications for the role of the state in the cultural life of the nation. Education is a key transmission point between the state and its people, with teachers as frontline cultural workers. Purpose: This article examines the way Cuban teachers address racism in their professional practice, with a specific focus on teacher home visits to address racism with parents/guardians. The author analyzes the relationship between Cuban teachers and the families of students they teach (an under-researched form of teacher practice in an under-researched context). Little is known about teachers reaching and teaching parents directly about issues such as racism. Further, there is limited research on the ways in which understanding of citizenship and professional responsibility impact teachers’ work and pedagogy in their interactions with parents. Setting: Havana, Cuba. Participants: All interviewees were teachers from downtown Havana. Twenty-two male and 23 female teachers participated. Fifteen of the teachers were Mestizo (of mixed race), one was Chinese-Cuban, 21 were Afro-Cuban, and eight were White. Survey participants were drawn from across Havana’s 15 boroughs. Among respondents, 67.4% were female and 32.6% were male. As far as race, 57.8% identified as Mestizo, 18.9% identified as Afro-Cuban, 22% identified as White, and 1.3% identified as Chinese. Research Design: This is a mixed-method study using qualitative interviews (N = 45 participants), and a quantitative survey (N = 150 respondents). Conclusions/Recommendations: Teachers regularly enter the homes of parents in an effort to promote diversity and to counter perceived racism among parents/guardians. The fact that teachers have the authority and sense of entitlement to do so points to possibilities for a significant retooling of the ecology systems framework. Many teachers undertake this work with parents/guardians just as they would when addressing student academic performance. This race-work is supported by state-generated social capital that, in Cuba, embeds conceptions of race within a larger public context, as opposed to treating race as a private matter to be subjectively and privately understood. As quasi-curriculum, antiracism is something everyone is expected to learn. This suggests that a careful consideration of the way concepts of nation, citizenship, and professional responsibility inform teacher preparation and practice in Cuba may deepen our understanding of teachers’ race-work in North American contexts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Parent School Relationship; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Racism; *Teacher Attitudes; *Teachers; Parents; Professional Development; Teaching

Record: 89
Title:
Daughters of traditions.
Authors:
Ghuman, Paul Singh, University of Wales, Wales, asg@aber.ac.uk
Address:
Ghuman, Paul Singh, asg@aber.ac.uk
Source:
The Psychologist, Vol 18(10), Oct, 2005. pp. 620-622.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
United Kingdom : British Psychological Society
ISSN:
0952-8229 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Asian women, cultural differences, Western societies, acculturation, dual socialization, psychological concerns, cultural awareness
Abstract:
This article discusses the conflict between home and school values and values of the wider Western societies in the lives of Asian women. Following a brief review of some research, the author points out several areas of concern for both researchers and applied psychologists. Themes/concepts of culture conflict, acculturation and dual socialization, formation of personal and social identities, self-image and coping strategies; all need further exploration to work out their associations with psychosomatic illnesses. Also noted is an unexplored area of research, namely the psychological concerns and perceptions of girls (and boys) of dual cultural heritage or mixed race, as they could be bridge-builders between the host society and new citizens/immigrants. It is concluded that the importance of cultural awareness and understanding when counseling young people of Asian ancestry, or other minority groups, cannot be overstated. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 90
Title:
Defining difference: Race and racism in the history of psychology.
Authors:
Winston, Andrew S., (Ed), University of Guelph, Dept of Psychology, Guelph, ON, Canada
Source:
Washington, DC, US: American Psychological Association; 2004. xi, 303 pp.
Page Count:
303
ISBN:
1-59147-027-7 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racism, racial differences, history of psychology, theories, sciences, mixed race persons, interracial marriage, sociocultural contexts, intelligence, heredity, textbooks, activism, segregation
Abstract:
This is the first book to bring together recent scholarship on the history of psychology and race. Throughout the history of the field, psychological discourse has been shaped by social concerns, and its discourse on race is no exception. Psychologists have both promoted and fought against racism, and a nuanced historical account requires analysis of both dimensions. The contributors seek to understand the relationship between the changes in the field and broader social change by mapping the changing discourse for "defining difference" through race. Topics covered include essentialism and the history of the concept of race, ideas of race in the work of nineteenth-century and twentieth-century psychologists, psychological discourse on topics such as "mixed-race" people, political uses of racial research, changes in textbook presentations of race and intelligence, and international perspectives on psychology and race. Contributors also examine the prominence and persistence of American research on racial differences in intelligence as well as the work of Kenneth Clark and Horace Mann Bond in combating racism in science and society. This important volume increases readers' understanding of the link between racial studies and social attitudes in our time. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (publicity materials)
Subjects:
*History of Psychology; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Racism; Activism; Intelligence; Interracial Marriage; Interracial Offspring; Race (Anthropological); Sciences; Sociocultural Factors; Theories
PsycINFO Classification:

Source: The multiracial experience: Racial borders as the new frontier.
Record: 91
Title:
Democratizing conversations: Racialized talk in a post-desegregated middle school.
Authors:
Schultz, Katherine, U Pennsylvania, Graduate School of Education, Philadelphia, PA, US, kathys@gse.upenn.edu
Buck, Patricia, U Pennsylvania, Graduate School of Education, Philadelphia, PA, US
Niesz, Tricia, U Pennsylvania, Graduate School of Education, Philadelphia, PA, US
Source:
American Educational Research Journal, Vol 37(1), Spr 2000. pp. 33-65.
Page Count:
33
Publisher:
US : American Educational Research Assn
Other Publishers:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0002-8312 (Print)
1935-1011 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
conversational style, desegregation, middle school students, racial attitudes, Whites, Blacks, interracial relations
Abstract:
Examined the conversational styles employed by students attending a desegregated middle school while discussing race. Students discussed issues related to race in focus groups initially comprised solely of White, Black, or nondominant individuals. Subsequently, subjects (Ss) then convened in mixed-race groups, with conversation styles examined. Results show that Ss employed 2 distinct types of conversational styles. In the 1st type, which may be labeled "bridging talk", Ss used multiple strategies to build unity across differences. In the 2nd type, "conflict talk," Ss discursively created borders and conflict. Findings suggest promises and challenges for each type of discussion. A 3rd form for consideration, "democratic conversation," would invite perspectives while acknowledging the privileging and silencing that accompany them. It is concluded that educators should hold conversations that explicitly address the power dynamics inherent in such conversations and teach the conceptual tools and language to identify these dynamics. Although these conversations across racial lines are sometimes threatening and difficult, they are a critical component of democratic education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Conversation; *Discourse Analysis; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Racial and Ethnic Relations; *Social Integration; Blacks; Middle School Students; Whites

Record: 92
Title:
Demography of immigrant youth: Past, present, and future.
Authors:
Passel, Jeffrey S., Pew Hispanic Center, WA, US
Source:
The Future of Children, Vol 21(1), Spr 2011. pp. 19-41.
Page Count:
23
Publisher:
US : David and Lucile Packard Foundation
ISSN:
1054-8289 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
demographic trends, immigrant youths, family members, geographic distribution, poverty, policy makers
Abstract:
Jeffrey Passel surveys demographic trends and projections in the U.S. youth population, with an emphasis on trends among immigrant youth. He traces shifts in the youth population over the past hundred years, examines population projections through 2050, and offers some observations about the likely impact of the immigrant youth population on American society. Passel provides data on the legal status of immigrant youth and their families and on their geographic distribution and concentration across the United States. He emphasizes two demographic shifts. First, immigrant youth—defined as those children under age eighteen who are either foreign-born or U.S.-born to immigrant parents—now account for one-fourth of the nation’s 75 million children. By 2050 they are projected to make up one-third of more than 100 million U.S. children. Second, the wave of immigration under way since the mid-1960s has made children the most racially and ethnically diverse age group in the United States. In 1960 Hispanic, Asian, and mixed-race youth made up about 6 percent of all U.S. children; today that share is almost 30 percent. During that same period the share of non-Hispanic white children steadily dropped from about 81 percent to 56 percent, while the share of black children climbed very slightly to 14 percent. By 2050 the share of non-Hispanic white children is projected to drop to 40 percent, while that of Hispanic children will increase to about one-third. This changing demographic structure in U.S. youth is likely to present policy makers with several challenges in coming decades, including higher rates of poverty among youth, particularly among foreign-born children and children of undocumented parents; high concentrations of immigrants in a handful of states; and a lack of political voice. A related challenge may be intergenerational competition between youth and the elderly for governmental support such as education funding, Social Security, and government health benefits. In conclusion, Passel notes that today’s immigrants and their children will shape many aspects of American society and will provide virtually all the growth in the U.S. labor force over the next forty years. Their integration into American society and their accumulation of human capital thus require continued attention from researchers and policy makers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Demographic Characteristics; *Immigration; *Regional Differences; *Trends; Family Members; Policy Making; Poverty

Record: 93
Title:
Depression and Trail Making Test scores in a sample of cocaine abusers.
Authors:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US, drmachorton@hotmail.com
Roberts, Charles, Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US
Address:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., 5903 Lone Oak Drive, Bethesda, MD, US, 20814, drmachorton@hotmail.com
Source:
International Journal of Neuroscience, Vol 113(4), Apr, 2003. pp. 595-604.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Gordon & Breach Science Publishers, Inc.
US : Informa Healthcare
ISSN:
0020-7454 (Print)
1563-5279 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Trail Making Test, cocaine abusers, depression effects, cognitive impairments, Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study, demographic effects
Abstract:
Depression effects on the Trail Making Test (TMT), a test often used for screening cognitive impairments, were examined in a sample of cocaine abusers in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample of 4,299 Ss was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study (DATOS). DATOS was a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991-1993 in 96 programs in 11 cities in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of depression on the TMT scores A and B, and also derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing parts A and B of the TMT in this large treatment sample of cocaine abusers. The variables of sex, age, ethnicity, and education were included in analyses to control for demographic effects. The TMT part A and the difference score were the least sensitive TMT scores to the effects of depression but all TMT R-squares were quite small. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cognitive Assessment; *Cognitive Impairment; *Drug Abuse; *Major Depression; *Measurement; Cocaine; Demographic Characteristics; Drug Rehabilitation; Neuropsychological Assessment

Record: 94
Title:
Depressive symptoms in African American medical patients.
Authors:
Baker, F. M., U Maryland, Dept of Psychiatry, Baltimore, US
Parker, Donna A.
Wiley, Cynthia
Velli, Susan A.
Johnson, Janice T.
Source:
International Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry, Vol 10(1), Jan, 1995. pp. 9-14.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
US : John Wiley & Sons
ISSN:
0885-6230 (Print)
1099-1166 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
depressive symptoms, medically ill African American 50 yr olds & older
Abstract:
Determined prevalence of depressive symptoms in African-American medical clinic patients (aged 50+ yrs) and described the depressive symptoms and depressive illness. 66 African Americans in active treatment at a university hospital medical clinic were screened for the presence of depressive symptoms with the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D). 32% of the Ss screened positive for depressive symptoms. Based on a clinical interview using the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-III-Revised (DSM-III-R) checklist, 11% had affective disorders and were referred for psychiatric evaluation. Data demonstrate that levels of depressive symptoms among medically ill, African American medical clinic patients with 2 or more medical illnesses were higher than reported for medical clinic samples composed of White Americans or mixed race Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:

Record: 95
Title:
Derived Trail Making test indices in a sample of alcohol abusers: Demographic effects.
Authors:
Roberts, Charles, Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Address:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockwall II Building, Suite 840, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, MD, US, 20857, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Source:
International Journal of Neuroscience, Vol 112(3), Jan, 2002. pp. 337-346.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Gordon & Breach Science Publishers, Inc.
US : Informa Healthcare
ISSN:
0020-7454 (Print)
1563-5279 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
alcohol abusers, drug abuse treatment program, derived indices, Trail Making test, demographic variables, cognitive impairment
Abstract:
Derived indices on the Trail Making test (TMT), a test often used for screening cognitive impairments, were examined in a sample of alcohol abusers in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample of 1,000 Ss (aged 18 yrs and older) was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study (DATOS). The DATOS was a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991-1993 in 96 programs in 11 cities in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of demographic variables on derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing parts A and B of the TMT in this large treatment sample of alcohol abusers. The variables of age, ethnicity, and education were statistically significant for the total (A+B), interaction (A×B/100), and difference score (B-A) derived indices of the TMT. The ratio score (B/A) was only significant for education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 96
Title:
Derived Trail Making Test indices in a sample of amphetamine abusers: Demographic effects.
Authors:
Roberts, Charles, Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Address:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockwall II Building, Suite 840, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, MD, US, 20857, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Source:
International Journal of Neuroscience, Vol 112(5), May, 2002. pp. 575-584.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Gordon & Breach Science Publishers, Inc.
US : Informa Healthcare
ISSN:
0020-7454 (Print)
1563-5279 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
demographic effects, Derived Trail Making Test, amphetamine abusers, drug rehabilitation
Abstract:
Derived indices on the Trail Making Test (TMT), a test often used for screening for cognitive impairment, were examined in a sample of amphetamine abusers in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample of 185 Ss was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study--a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991 to 1993 in 96 programs in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of demographic variables on derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing Parts A and B of the TMT in this large treatment sample of substance abusers. The variables of sex, age, ethnicity, and education were not statistically significant for selected derived indices of the TMT. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 97
Title:
Derived Trail Making Test indices in a sample of hallucinogen abusers: Demographic effects.
Authors:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Roberts, Charles, Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US
Address:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockwall II Building, Suite 840, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, MD, US, 20857, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Source:
International Journal of Neuroscience, Vol 112(5), May, 2002. pp. 565-573.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Gordon & Breach Science Publishers, Inc.
US : Informa Healthcare
ISSN:
0020-7454 (Print)
1563-5279 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
demographic effects, Derived Trail Making Test, hallucinogen abusers, drug rehabilitation
Abstract:
Derived indices on the Trail Making Test (TMT), a test often used for screening for cognitive impairment, were examined in a sample of hallucinogen abusers in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample of 128 Ss was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study--a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991 to 1993 in 96 programs in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of demographic variables on derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing Parts A and B of the TMT in this sample. Results indicate that the variables of sex and age were not statistically significant for derived indices of the TMT. The variable of ethnicity was significant for the all derived indices except the ratio score (divide Part B by Part A) and the variable of education was significant for the interaction score (multiply Part A by Part B and divide by 100). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cognitive Assessment; *Demographic Characteristics; *Drug Abuse; *Drug Rehabilitation; *Hallucinogenic Drugs

Record: 98
Title:
Derived Trail Making Test indices in a sample of heroin abusers: Demographic effects.
Authors:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Subatance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Roberts, Charles, Subatance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US
Address:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockwall II Building, Suite 840, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, MD, US, 20857, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Source:
International Journal of Neuroscience, Vol 112(2), Jan, 2002. pp. 225-234.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Gordon & Breach Science Publishers, Inc.
US : Informa Healthcare
ISSN:
0020-7454 (Print)
1563-5279 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Trail Making Test, derived indices, demographic variables, heroin abusers, drug abuse treatment
Abstract:
Derived indices on the Trail Making Test (TMT), a test often used for screening cognitive impairment, were examined in a sample of heroin abusers in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample of 1,548 Ss was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study, a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991-1993 in 96 programs in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of demographic variables on derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing parts A and B of the TMT in this sample. Results show that the variables of age, ethnicity, and education were strongly statistically significant for the total (A+B) and interaction (A×B/100) derived indices of the TMT. Similarly, the difference score (B-A) was significant for race/ethnicity and education, but the ratio score (B/A) was not significant for any demographic variable. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cognitive Assessment; *Demographic Characteristics; *Drug Rehabilitation; *Heroin Addiction
PsycINFO Classification:
Drug & Alcohol Rehabilitation (3383)

Record: 99
Title:
Derived Trail Making Test indices in a sample of marijuana abusers: Demographic effects.
Authors:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Roberts, Charles, Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US
Address:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockwall II Building, Suite 840, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, MD, US, 20857, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Source:
International Journal of Neuroscience, Vol 112(4), Apr, 2002. pp. 429-438.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Gordon & Breach Science Publishers, Inc.
US : Informa Healthcare
ISSN:
0020-7454 (Print)
1563-5279 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Derived Trail Making Test indices, cognitive impairment, marijuana abusers, treatment program, demographic effects
Abstract:
Derived indices on the Trail Making Test (TMT), a test often used for screening for cognitive impairment, were examined in a sample of marijuana abusers in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed-race sample of 259 Ss (aged 18 yrs and over) was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study (DATOS). The DATOS was a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991 to 1993 in 96 programs in 11 cities in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of demographic variables on derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing Parts A and B of the TMT in this large treatment sample of marijuana abusers. The variables of age, ethnicity, and education were statistically significant for the total (A+B), and interaction (A×B/100) derived indices of the TMT. The difference score (B-A) was significant only for ethnicity and the ratio score (B/A) was not significant for any demographic variable. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 100
Title:
Derived Trail Making Test indices in a sample of narcotic/other opiate abusers: Demographic effects.
Authors:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Roberts, Charles, Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US
Address:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockwall II Building, Suite 840, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, MD, US, 20857, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Source:
International Journal of Neuroscience, Vol 112(9), Sep, 2002. pp. 1075-1084.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Gordon & Breach Science Publishers, Inc.
US : Informa Healthcare
ISSN:
0020-7454 (Print)
1563-5279 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Trail Making Test, narcotic & opiate abusers, drug abuse treatment programs, derived indices, demographic effects, cognitive impairment
Abstract:
Derived indices on the Trail Making Test (TMT), a test often used to screen for cognitive impairment, were examined in a sample of 191 narcotic/other opiate abusers (mean age 32.6 yrs) in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study (DATOS). The DATOS was a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991-1993 in 96 programs in 11 cities in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of demographic variables on derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing parts A and B of the TMT in this large treatment sample of substance abusers. The variables of age, ethnicity, and education were statistically significant for the total score (A + B) and interaction score (A×B/100) derived indices of the TMT. In addition, the difference score (B - A) was statistically significant for education. The ratio score (B/A) was not significant for any demographic variable. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Derived trail making test indices in a sample of sedative abusers: Demographic effects.
Authors:
Roberts, Charles, Substance Abuse & Mental Health Admin, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US

ISSN:
0020-7454 (Print)

Language:
English
Keywords:
derived indices, drug abuse treatment programs, cognitive impairment, sedative abusers, trail making, demographic effects
Abstract:
Derived indices on the Trail Making test (TMT), a test often used to screen for cognitive impairment, were examined in a sample of 72 sedative abusers in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study (DATOS). The DATOS was a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991-1993 in 96 programs in 11 cities in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of demographic variables on derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing parts A and B of the TMT in this large treatment sample of substance abusers. The variables of sex, age, ethnicity, and education were not statistically significant for selected derived indices of the TMT. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Derived Trail Making Test indices in a sample of substance abusers: Demographic effects.

Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Roberts, Charles, Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US

Abstract:
Derived indices on the Trail Making Test (TMT), a test often used to screen for cognitive impairments, were examined in a sample of substance abusers in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study (DATOS). The DATOS was a naturalistic, prospective cohort study that collected data from 1991 through 1993 within 96 programs in 11 cities in the US. Data were analyzed to determine the effects of demographic variables on derived indices created by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing parts A and B of the TMT in this large treatment sample of substance abusers. Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 103
Title:
Determining the design of child-specific adoption advertisements: A conjoint analysis.
Authors:
Bennett, Roger, London Metropolitan University, United Kingdom
Barkensjo, Anna, London Metropolitan University, United Kingdom
Source:
International Journal of Market Research, Vol 47(3), 2005. pp. 267-294.
Page Count:
28
Publisher:
United Kingdom : World Advertising Research Center Ltd
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of the Market Research Society
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Market Research Society
ISSN:
1470-7853 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
child-specific adoption advertisements, physical disability, psychological difficulty
Abstract:
This empirical study sought to establish the views of a sample of 319 members of the British public concerning the practice of child-specific advertising. It also examined the sample members' relative levels of interest in child-specific advertisements that featured youngsters of specific ages, ethnicities and possessing various forms of disability (physical, psychological or behavioural). Interviews were conducted with individuals of the type targeted by an inner-London local government social services department in venues currently displaying the department's child-specific advertisements. The respondents were generally supportive of child-specific advertising, although older people and individuals of African or African-Caribbean heritage tended to be less enthusiastic about the practice than the rest of the sample. It emerged that behavioural problems were regarded as a more unattractive impairment than either a physical disability or a psychological difficulty. Single people, the less well educated, females, white and mixed-race respondents, and persons with highly altruistic dispositions exhibited significantly different preference structures vis-à-vis alternative combinations of attributes (age, ethnicity and form of impairment) associated with children requiring adoption. The findings should assist managers of local government adoption units to draft child-specific advertisements in manners that maximise the probability of their securing substantial numbers of serious enquiries from particular target audiences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adoption (Child); *Advertising; *Physical Disorders
PsycINFO Classification:
Community & Social Services (3373)
Marketing & Advertising (3940)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
United Kingdom
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs)
Thirties (30-39 yrs)
Middle Age (40-64 yrs)
Methodology:
Empirical Study; Quantitative Study
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
20050815
Accession Number:
2005-05222-004
Number of Citations in Source:

UR:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 104
Title:
Developing multicultural competency in clinical work with people of mixed ancestry.
Authors:
Dixon-Peters, Aisha, California State University at Northridge, Northridge, CA, US
Source:
Handbook of multicultural counseling competencies. Cornish, Jennifer A. Erickson (Ed); Schreier, Barry A. (Ed); Nadkarni, Lavita I. (Ed); Metzger, Lynett Henderson (Ed); Rodolfa, Emil R. (Ed); pp. 231-265; Hoboken, NJ, US: John Wiley & Sons Inc; 2010. xi, 540 pp.
Page Count:
35
ISBN:
978-0-470-43746-9 (Hardcover)
978-0-470-60917-0 (PDF)
978-0-470-60919-4 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multicultural counseling, cultural competency, multicultural therapy, mixed ancestry, mixed race, multiracial
Abstract:
There is a growing number of mixed-race people in the United States and a growing number of individuals who identify as mixed-race or multiracial. In the last census, 6.8 million people identified as multiracial, marking more than one racial category to identify themselves or their children, with 42 percent under 18 years of age (Jones & Symens Smith, 2001). The "biracial baby boom" of the 1970s and 1980s produced a notable cohort of multiracial individuals (Bratter, 2007) and resulted in an increase in the number of mixed-race individuals from 500,000 in 1970 to nearly 7 million in 2000 (Krebs, 2000; Shih & Sanchez, 2005). Given this growing population, mental health practitioners will likely be working with increasing numbers of multiracial individuals (Kerwin, Ponterotto, Jackson, & Harris, 1993); thus, it is important for therapists and counselors to have an awareness and knowledge of the experiences of this population and to be able to transfer this awareness and knowledge into skills useful in working with multiracial individuals. Competent, ethical multicultural practice requires understanding and addressing the unique characteristics and mental health needs of this population. This chapter will provide the reader with guidelines and resources for increasing awareness of one's own values and attitudes, knowledge of ecological issues related to people of mixed ancestry, and skills in developing competency in working with persons of mixed ancestry. Case studies are included and will be referred to throughout the chapter to illustrate critical concepts. Pouse & Ponder exercises will be included throughout the chapter to prompt the reader to stop, reflect, and engage in a more contemplative and dynamic way with the concepts in this text, thus increasing personal awareness and recognition of multicultural issues as they relate to people of mixed ancestry (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Competence; *Cultural Sensitivity; *Interracial Offspring; *Psychotherapy; *Multicultural Counseling; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:
Professional Psychological & Health Personnel Issues (3400)
Psychotherapy & Psychotherapeutic Counseling (3310)
Population:
Human
Intended Audience:

UR:

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2011-12790-008&site=ehost-live&scope=site

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 105
Title:
Development and risk behavior among African American, Caucasian, and mixed-race adolescents living in high poverty inner-city neighborhoods.
Authors:
Bolland, John M., Department of Health Behavior, School of Public Health, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL, US, bollandj@uab.edu
Bryant, Chalandra M., Department of Human Development and Family Studies, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, US
Lian, Bradley E., Department of Health Behavior, School of Public Health, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL, US
McCallum, Debra M., Institute for Social Science Research, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, US
Vazsonyi, Alexander T., Department of Human Development and Family Studies, Auburn University, Auburn, AL, US
Barth, Joan M., Institute for Social Science Research, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, US
Address:
Bolland, John M., Department of Health Behavior, School of Public Health, University of Alabama at Birmingham, RPHB 227, 1530 3rd Avenue South, Birmingham, AL, US, 45294-0022, bollandj@uab.edu
Source:
American Journal of Community Psychology, Vol 40(3-4), Dec, 2007. pp. 230-249.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
Other Publishers:
US : Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers
US : Plenum Publishing Corp.
ISSN:
0091-0562 (Print)
1573-2770 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
adolescent development, risk behavior, African American, Caucasian, mixed-race, high poverty inner-city neighborhoods, hopelessness
Abstract:
Youths growing up in low-income inner-city neighborhoods are at substantial risk for initiating substance use, violent behavior, and sexual intercourse at early ages; these risk behaviors continue at comparatively high rates through adolescence. Hopelessness has been implicated as a risk factor for these behaviors. In this paper, we consider how race influences this process. African Americans form a demographic minority within the United States, but they are often the majority within inner-city neighborhoods. For Caucasians, the opposite typically holds. Mixed-race populations form a minority within both contexts. Using longitudinal data, we examine the relationship between race and risk behaviors in several impoverished inner-city neighborhoods where African Americans form the distinct majority and Caucasians and people of mixed racial heritage form a small minority. We also consider how race moderates the relationship between hopelessness and risk behavior. Our findings show that compared to Caucasian or mixed-race adolescents, African American adolescents are less likely to engage in risk behaviors, and that hopelessness has a less important impact on their behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adolescent Development; *Neighborhoods; *Poverty Areas; *Race (Anthropological); *Risk Taking; Blacks; Hopelessness; Whites

Record: 106
Title:
Development and validation of the Functional Assessment of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Infection (FAHI) quality of life instrument.
Authors:
Cella, D. F., Rush-Presbyterian-St Luke's Medical Ctr, Div of Psychosocial Oncology, Chicago, IL, US
McCain, N. L.
Peterman, A. H.
Mo, F.
Wolen, D.
Source:
Quality of Life Research: An International Journal of Quality of Life Aspects of Treatment, Care & Rehabilitation, Vol 5(4), Aug, 1996. pp. 450-463.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0962-9343 (Print)
1573-2649 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
development & psychometric testing of Functional Assessment of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Infection quality of life instrument, 18–63 yr old patients, conference presentation
Abstract:
Studied the development and psychometric characteristics of the Functional Assessment of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Infection (FAHI), a quality of life instrument composed of the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy (FACT-G) plus a finite set of symptoms and concerns specific to HIV infection. The FACT-G and a 9-item HIV-specific subscale were combined and administered to 18–63 yr olds: 110 English-speaking, stress management male Ss from Chicago, 71 English-speaking urban, mixed race Ss from Chicago and 64 Spanish-speaking urban Ss from Chicago and Puerto Rico. The FAHI showed sufficient internal consistency reliability, concurrent validity, and sensitivity to change (STC). However, the 9-item HIV-specific subscale showed relatively low α coefficients and marginal STC, leading to supplementation of content with 11 more items, creating the FAHI version 3. The use of this new version in evaluating group differences and within-group change over time is encouraged. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*HIV; *Psychological Assessment; *Psychometrics; *Questionnaires; *Test Construction; Quality of Life

Record: 107
Title:
Die faktorstruktuur van die Nuwe Suid-Afrikaanse Groeptoets (NSAG) by verskillende bevolkingsgroepe.
Translated Title:
The factor structure of the New South African Group Test (NSAGT) in various population groups.
Authors:
Claassen, N. C., Inst vir Psigologiese en Edumetriese Navorsing, Raad vir Geesteswetenskaplike Navorsing, Pretoria, South Africa
Cudeck, R.
Source:
South African Journal of Psychology, Vol 15(1), Mar, 1985. pp. 1-10.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
South Africa : Psychological Society of South Africa
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of Behavioural Science
Other Publishers:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0081-2463 (Print)
Language:
Afrikaans
Keywords:
factor structure of New South African Group Test, White vs mixed race African speaking vs White vs Indian English speaking 13 yr olds, South Africa
Abstract:
Examined the factor structure of the NSAGT on the basis of data from 4 groups of 13-yr-olds—319 White Afrikaans-speaking, 171 White English-speaking, 498 Indian English-speaking, and 469 mixed-race Afrikaans-speaking children—to find a single factor model that is optimal in accuracy and simplicity. Although great similarities were found between the factor structures of the 4 populations, the factor structures were not invariant. Factorial invariance was shown to exist for the 2 high socioeconomic status (SES) groups and for the 2 low SES groups. A marked similarity between the nonverbal reasoning factors was also found for all populations. (34 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 108
Title:
Dimensions of racism and their impact on partner selection among men of colour who have sex with men: Understanding pathways to sexual risk.
Authors:
Ro, Annie, UCLA, Fielding School of Public Health, Los Angeles, CA, US, anniero@ucla.edu
Ayala, George, Global Forum on MSM & HIV, Oakland, CA, US
Paul, Jay, Center for AIDS Prevention Studies, University of California, San Francisco, CA, US
Choi, Kyung-Hee, Center for AIDS Prevention Studies, University of California, San Francisco, CA, US
Address:
Ro, Annie, anniero@ucla.edu
Source:
Culture, Health & Sexuality, Vol 15(7), Jul, 2013. pp. 836-850.
Page Count:
15
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
1369-1058 (Print)
1464-5351 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racism, partner selection, sexual risk, gays
Abstract:
While many studies have established the relationship between experiences of racism and sexual risk among men of colour who have sex with men, the pathways by which this occurs are underdeveloped. To address this gap, we must better investigate the lived realities of racism in the gay community. In this study, we had the unique opportunity to examine experiences of racism among African American, Asian/Pacific Islander and Latino men who have sex with men living in Los Angeles through focus groups and individual in-depth interviews. We found three themes of racism: exclusion from West Hollywood and the mainstream gay community, sexual rejection based on race/ethnicity and sexual stereotypes. There were differences across the three racial groups in the experiences of each theme, however. We then considered how racism impacted partner selection and found that race played a salient role in determining power differentials within mixed-race partnerships. Finally, we discussed several future areas for research that can better establish pathways between racism and sexual risk. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Male Homosexuality; *Minority Groups; *Racism; *Sexual Risk Taking; *Sexual Partners

Record: 109
Title:
Do declines in residential segregation mean stable neighborhood racial integration in metropolitan America? A research note.
Authors:
Friedman, Samantha, Department of Sociology and Anthropology, Northeastern University, Boston, MA, US, s.friedman@neu.edu
Address:
Friedman, Samantha, Department of Sociology and Anthropology, Northeastern University, 535 Holmes Hall, Boston, MA, US, 02115, s.friedman@neu.edu
Source:
Social Science Research, Vol 37(3), Sep, 2008. pp. 920-933.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0049-089X (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
residential segregation, stable neighborhood racial integration, metropolitan America
Abstract:
Between 1980 and 2000, residential segregation between non-Hispanic whites and blacks, as measured by the index of dissimilarity, declined by 8.7 percentage points. How this decline reflects stable racial integration at the neighborhood level remains to be seen. Using the Neighborhood Change Database, which provides 1980, 1990, and 2000 census-tract level data in 2000 boundaries, the descriptive analyses conducted here reveal three findings. First, the declines found in white-black segregation are due to increases in multiethnic neighborhoods rather than mixed white-and-black neighborhoods. Second, the decline in segregation appears not to be due to the fact that multiethnic neighborhoods are forming and remaining stable over time. Instead it is due to the increase in the number of these neighborhoods at one point in time. Finally, when focusing explicitly on the stability of mixed-race neighborhoods, such neighborhoods are less stable when examined over two decades as compared to one decade. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Neighborhoods; *Social Integration; *Whites; *Latinos/Latinas
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Location:
US
Conference:
Annual meeting of the Population Association of America, Apr, 2005, Philadelphia, PA, US
Conference Notes:
An earlier version of this paper was presented at the aforementioned conference.
Methodology:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 110
Title:
Do social connections and hope matter in predicting early adolescent violence?
Authors:
Stoddard, Sarah A., School of Nursing, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US, sastodda@umich.edu
McMorris, Barbara J., School of Nursing, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, US
Sieving, Renee E., School of Nursing, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, US
Address:
Stoddard, Sarah A., School of Nursing, University of Michigan, 400 N. Ingalls Street, Room 4320, Ann Arbor, MI, US, 48109-5482, sastodda@umich.edu
Source:
American Journal of Community Psychology, Vol 48(3-4), Dec, 2011. pp. 247-256.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
Other Publishers:
US : Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers
US : Plenum Publishing Corp.
ISSN:
0091-0562 (Print)
1573-2770 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social connections, hope, early adolescent violence, urban environments, neighborhoods
Abstract:
We tested relationships between social connections, hope, and violence among young adolescents from socially distressed urban neighborhoods, and examined whether relationships between adolescents’ family and school connectedness and violence involvement were mediated by hopefulness. Data were from middle school students involved in the Lead Peace demonstration study. The sample (N = 164) was 51.8% female; 42% African American, 28% Asian, 13% Hispanic, and 17% mixed race or other race; average age was 12.1 years; 46% reported physical fighting in the past year. In multivariate models, parent-family connectedness was protective against violence; school connectedness was marginally protective. Hopefulness was related to lower levels of violence. The relationship between school connectedness and violence was mediated by hopefulness; some evidence for mediation also existed in the family-parent connectedness and violence relationship. Findings warrant continued exploration of hopefulness as an important protective factor against violence involvement, and as a mediator in relationships between social connections and violence involvement. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adolescent Development; *Neighborhoods; *Social Interaction; *Urban Environments; *Violence

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 111
Title:
Does college matter for emerging adulthood? Comparing developmental trajectories of educational groups.
Authors:
Mitchell, Lauren L., Department of Psychology, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, US, mitch938@umn.edu
Syed, Moin, Department of Psychology, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, US
Address:
Mitchell, Lauren L., Department of Psychology, University of Minnesota, N218 Elliott Hall, 75 E. River Road, Minneapolis, MN, US, 55441, mitch938@umn.edu
Source:
Journal of Youth and Adolescence, Vol 44(11), Nov, 2015. pp. 2012-2027.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0047-2891 (Print)
1573-6601 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Emerging adulthood, Educational groups, Non-students, Transition to adulthood
Abstract:
Critics of emerging adulthood theory have suggested that it only applies to college students, but this assertion has largely gone untested. The purpose of the present study was to compare developmental trajectories of non-students versus college-educated youth in theoretically relevant domains of work, love, and financial independence. Using data from the Youth Development Study (N = 1139, 49.6 % female, 63.3 % White, 10.9 % Southeast Asian, 1.5 % Other Asian, 8.6 % Black, 5.3 % Mixed Race, 4.0 % Latino, 0.8 % Native American), latent growth curve models were fitted to chart each group’s development, from ages 14 to 30. Different trajectories were revealed for hours worked, children, and financial dependence on parents, spouses, and government aid. No differences were found in employment rates, marriage rates, or financial dependence on own income. These results provide a clearer picture of emerging adulthood for non-students, and highlight problems with generalizing college student research to all emerging adults. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Adult Development; *College Students; Educational Psychology; Income Level

Record: 112
Title:
Does race matter? A study of mixed race siblings' identifications.
Authors:
Song, Miri, University of Kent, Canterbury, United Kingdom, A.M.Song@kent.ac.uk
Address:
Song, Miri, A.M.Song@kent.ac.uk
Source:
The Sociological Review, Vol 58(2), May, 2010. pp. 265-285.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
US : Routledge & Kegan Paul
US : Sherratt Hughes
US : Sociological Publications Ltd.
United Kingdom : University College of North Staffordshire
ISSN:
0038-0261 (Print)
1467-954X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial differences, siblings, multiethnic societies, social experiences, family
Abstract:
‘Mixed’ people comprise one of the fastest growing populations in Britain today, and their growth refutes the idea that there exist distinct, ‘natural’ races among people in multiethnic societies, such as Britain. In recent years, a large body of scholarship, both in the US and Britain, has begun to investigate the diverse social experiences and racial identifications of mixed people. In this article, I investigate the ways in which mixed siblings perceive and think about race and differences in racial, ethnic, and religious identification within their families. What role do race and the recognition of difference play in sibling relationships and in family life more generally? I draw upon a small number of cases to illustrate the diverse ways in which understandings of race, ethnicity, and religion are (or are not) regarded as important in these families. I also consider whether there are group differences in terms of how disparate types of mixed siblings may perceive pressures to identify in particular ways. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Siblings; *Society; Experiences (Events); Family; Social Issues

Record: 113
Title:
Driving under the influence (DUI) among U.S. ethnic groups.
Authors:
Caetano, Raul, University of Texas, School of Public Health, Dallas, TX, US, Raul.Caetano@UTSouthwestern.edu
McGrath, Christine, University of Texas, School of Public Health, Dallas, TX, US
Address:
Caetano, Raul, University of Texas, School of Public Health, Dallas Regional Campus, 5323 Harry Hines Blvd. Room V8.112, Dallas, TX, US, 75390-9128, Raul.Caetano@UTSouthwestern.edu
Source:
Accident Analysis and Prevention, Vol 37(2), Mar, 2005. pp. 217-224.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0001-4575 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
driving under the influence, ethnic group, alcohol, drug
Abstract:
Objective: To report nationwide survey data on driving under the influence of alcohol and drugs (DUI) among U.S. ethnic groups. Methods: Data come from a probability sample of 39,250 adults 18 years of age and older interviewed by the U.S. National Household Survey on Drug Abuse in 2000. Interviews averaging 1 h in length were conducted in respondents' homes by trained interviewers. The survey response rate was 74%. Results: Self-reported rates of DUI were highest among White men (22%), Native American/Native Alaskan men (20.8%) and men of Mixed race (22.5%). Twelve-month arrest rates for DUI were highest among men of Mixed race (5%) and Native American/Native Alaskan men (3.2%). Drinkers who DUI are more likely to be men (regardless of ethnicity), not married, consume more alcohol, and be alcohol dependent than drinkers who do not engage in alcohol-impaired driving. However, important ethnic specific predictors are also identified across the different ethnic groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Alcohol Drinking Patterns; *Driving Under the Influence; *Drug Usage; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; Drugs; Racial and Ethnic Differences

Record: 114
Title:
Dynamic representations of race: Processing goals shape race decoding in the fusiform gyri.
Authors:
Kaul, Christian, Department of Psychology, New York University, New York, NY, US
Ratner, Kyle G., Department of Psychology, New York University, New York, NY, US
Van Bavel, Jay J., Department of Psychology, New York University, New York, NY, US, jay.vanbavel@nyu.edu
Address:
Van Bavel, Jay J., Department of Psychology, New York University, 6 Washington Place, New York, NY, US, 10003, jay.vanbavel@nyu.edu
Source:
Social Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience, Vol 9(3), Mar, 2014. pp. 326-332.
Page Count:
7
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Oxford University Press
ISSN:
1749-5016 (Print)
1749-5024 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social categories, visual cortex, neural activity, processing goals, prefrontal region, racial differences, fusiform gyri, face racial categorization, Black faces: White faces
Abstract:
People perceive and evaluate others on the basis of social categories, such as race, gender and age. Initial processing of targets in terms of visually salient social categories is often characterized as inevitable. In the current study, we investigated the influence of processing goals on the representation of race in the visual processing stream. Participants were assigned to one of two mixed-race teams and categorized faces according to their group membership or skin color. To assess neural representations of race, we employed multivariate pattern analysis to examined neural activity related to the presentation of Black and White faces. As predicted, patterns of neural activity within the early visual cortex and fusiform gyri (FG) could decode the race of face stimuli above chance and were moderated by processing goals. Race decoding in early visual cortex was above chance in both categorization tasks and below chance in a prefrontal control region. More importantly, race decoding was greater in the FG during the group membership vs skin color categorization task. The results suggest that, ironically, explicit racial categorization can diminish the representation of race in the FG. These findings suggest that representations of race are dynamic, reflecting current processing goals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Classification (Cognitive Process); *Face Perception; *Human Information Storage; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Visual Cortex; Blacks; Goals; Prefrontal Cortex; Social Identity; Whites; Biological Neural Networks; Fusiform Gyrus
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 115
Title:
Eating attitudes among black South Africans.
Authors:
Szabo, Christopher P.
Source:
The American Journal of Psychiatry, Vol 156(6), Jun, 1999. pp. 981-982.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : American Psychiatric Assn
Other Journal Titles:
American Journal of Insanity
ISSN:
0002-953X (Print)
1535-7228 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
presence & severity of eating disorder pathology, Caucasian vs Black vs Asian vs mixed race college students, South Africa, commentary
Abstract:
Comments on the article by D. le Grange et al (see record 1997-41469-015) on the eating attitudes and behaviors of Caucasian and non-Caucasian South African college students and presents additional data on eating attitudes among black South Africans. The author has been involved in the treatment of 9 black female South Africans with eating disorders and notes the absence of any unique features designating the sufferers as black. These observations suggest that, within the urban setting, there is a homogenization of eating-related psychopathology across racial groups. In a sample of 213 adolescent female South African private school students, the author found that 20.7% of white Ss and 37.5% of black Ss were classified as having abnormal eating attitudes based on their responses to the Eating Attitudes Test. 18.6% of black and white adolescent government school students (N = 1,353) also showed abnormal eating attitudes. The author suggests that it is clear that, within the broader South African community, eating attitudes exist that place a significant proportion of adolescents and young adults of all racial groups at risk for the development of eating disorders. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 116
Title:
Eating attitudes and behaviors in 1,435 South African Caucasian and non-Caucasian college students.
Authors:
le Grange, Daniel, State U New York, School of Medicine, Dept of Psychiatry & Behavioral Sciences, Stony Brook, NY, US
Telch, Christy F.
Tibbs, Jason
Source:
The American Journal of Psychiatry, Vol 155(2), Feb, 1998. pp. 250-254.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
US : American Psychiatric Assn
Other Journal Titles:
American Journal of Insanity
ISSN:
0002-953X (Print)
1535-7228 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
presence & severity of eating disorder pathology, Caucasian vs Black vs Asian vs mixed race college students, South Africa
Abstract:
Examined the presence and severity of eating disorder pathology in students representing South Africa's ethnically and culturally diverse population. A questionnaire survey, which involved the Eating Attitude Test and the Bulimic Investigatory Test, was administered to 1,435 South African college students (739 Caucasian, 403 Black, 146 Asian, and 147 mixed race; aged 17–25 yrs) from 6 universities in 2 urban centers. Black Ss scored significantly higher than the other ethnic groups on these measures. In addition, a comparable percentage of Black and Caucasian women had scores within the clinical range on these scales. Men scored consistently lower than women. Findings challenge the notion that eating disorders are primarily a Western, Caucasian phenomenon and raise the possibility that the risk of eating disorders may increase in developing societies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Eating Disorders; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Asians; Blacks; Whites

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 117
Title:
Eating attitudes in English secondary school students: Influences of ethnicity, gender, mood, and social class.
Authors:
Thomas, Catherine L., Princess Margaret Hosp, Child & Family Consultation Service, Swindon, United Kingdom
James, Anthony C.
Bachmann, Max O.
Address:
Thomas, Catherine L., U of the Orange Free State, Dept of Community Health, Medical Faculty, P.O. Box 336 (G52), Bloemfontein, South Africa, 9300, gngmomb@med.uovs.ac.za
Source:
International Journal of Eating Disorders, Vol 31(1), Jan, 2002. pp. 92-96.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
US : John Wiley & Sons
ISSN:
0276-3478 (Print)
1098-108X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
ethnicity, gender, self-esteem, mood, social class, eating attitudes, adolescents
Abstract:
Examined the effects of ethnicity, gender, socioeconomic position, self-esteem, and emotion on eating attitudes in adolescents. 722 students (aged 11-16 yrs) in 2 English schools completed measures that included the Eating Attitude Test-26 (EAT), Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale, and Angold Mood and Feeling instruments. Results show that EAT scores were significantly higher for Asians and Muslims and for mixed-race Ss than for White or African Caribbean Ss. Adjusted odds ratios for having a very high EAT score were 2.4 in Asians and Muslims and 2.9 in mixed-race Ss, compared to White Ss. Having only one parent employed was also independently associated with a very high EAT score, compared with having both parents employed. Similar associations were found for a moderately high EAT score and for a combination of low self-esteem and high EAT score. Low self-esteem and depressed mood were independently associated with a high EAT score. Overall, ethnicity, socioeconomic position, self-esteem, and depression, but not gender, were independently associated with eating attitudes. It is stated that effects of cultural and socioeconomic stresses on eating disorders may be mediated through depressed mood and low self-esteem. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Eating Attitudes; *Human Sex Differences; *Psychosocial Factors; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Class; Emotional States; Self Esteem

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 118
Title:
Economic scarcity alters the perception of race.
Authors:
Krosch, Amy R., Department of Psychology, New York University, New York, NY, US, amy.krosch@nyu.edu
Amodio, David M., Department of Psychology, New York University, New York, NY, US, david.amodio@nyu.edu
Address:
Krosch, Amy R., Department of Psychology, New York University, New York, NY, US, 10003, amy.krosch@nyu.edu
Source:
PNAS Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America, Vol 111(25), Jun 24, 2014. pp. 9079-9084.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
US : National Academy of Sciences
ISSN:
0027-8424 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
African Americans, economics, racial perception, decision making
Abstract:
When the economy declines, racial minorities are hit the hardest. Although existing explanations for this effect focus on institutional causes, recent psychological findings suggest that scarcity may also alter perceptions of race in ways that exacerbate discrimination. We tested the hypothesis that economic resource scarcity causes decision makers to perceive African Americans as “Blacker” and that this visual distortion elicits disparities in the allocation of resources. Studies 1 and 2 demonstrated that scarcity altered perceptions of race, lowering subjects’ psychophysical threshold for seeing a mixed-race face as “Black” as opposed to “White.” In studies 3 and 4, scarcity led subjects to visualize African American faces as darker and more “stereotypically Black,” compared with a control condition. When presented to naïve subjects, face representations produced under scarcity elicited smaller allocations than control-condition representations. Together, these findings introduce a novel perceptual account for the proliferation of racial disparities under economic scarcity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Decision Making; *Economics; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
US
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)

Sponsor: National Science Foundation
Grant Number: DGE-0813964
Other Details: Graduate Research Fellowship
Recipients: Krosch, Amy R.

Document Type:

20140825

Record: 119
Title:
Educational inequality, homogamy, and status exchange in Black-White intermarriage: A comment on Rosenfield.
Authors:
Kalmijn, Matthijs, Tilburg University, Tilburg, Netherlands, M.Kalmijn@uvt.nl
Address:
Kalmijn, Matthijs, Department of Sociology, Tilburg University, P.O. Box 90153, 5000 LE, Tilburg, Netherlands, M.Kalmijn@uvt.nl
Source:
American Journal of Sociology, Vol 115(4), Jan, 2010. pp. 1252-1263.
Page Count:
12
Publisher:
US : Univ of Chicago Press
ISSN:
0002-9602 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
educational inequalities, homogamy, status exchange, Black-White intermarriage, mixed race couples
Abstract:
Comments on an article A Critique of Exchange Theory in Mate Selection by Michael J. Rosenfeld (2005). The article of Rosenfeld is one of the more serious and well-thought-out attempts to criticize the hypothesis, both theoretically and empirically. Rosenfeld concludes that simple and complex approaches both refute status exchange. He further claims that homogamy rather than exchange is the most important educational mating pattern in mixed-race couples. Explaining this discrepancy is important since the article by Rosenfeld may have given readers the false impression that complex models and simple models should always lead to the same findings. Loglinear models have often been difficult to interpret for the less technically oriented reader, as Rosenfeld correctly observes, and their complexity may have alienated part of the audience that was originally interested in the topic of intermarriage. Rosenfeld argues that it is important to take account of differential educational homogamy depending on race. If this is what Rosenfeld means by saying that these couples are based on solidarity and affection, he is probably right. But this does not translate into equally strong or stronger levels of educational homogamy—homogamy is weaker in these couples. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Couples; *Equal Education; *Exogamous Marriage; *Human Mate Selection; *Socioeconomic Status; Blacks; Race and Ethnic Discrimination; Whites
PsycINFO Classification:
Marriage & Family (2950)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Comment/Reply
Release Date:
20100524
Copyright:
All rights reserved.. University of Chicago. 2010
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1086/649050
Accession Number:

UR:

Record: 120
Title:
Effect of group racial composition on weight loss in African Americans.
Authors:
Ard, Jamy D., Department of Nutrition Sciences, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL, US, ardj@uab.edu
Kumanyika, Shiriki, Department of Biostatistics and Epidemiology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, US
Stevens, Victor J., Kaiser Permanente, Center For Health Research, Portland, OR, US
Vollmer, William M., Kaiser Permanente, Center For Health Research, Portland, OR, US
Samuel-Hodge, Carmen, Department of Nutrition, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, US
Kennedy, Betty, Pennington Biomedical Research Center, Dietary Assessment and Food Analysis Core, Baton Rouge, LA, US
Gayles, Debra, Johns Hopkins University, Welch Center for Prevention, Epidemiology, and Clinical Research, Baltimore, MD, US
Appel, Lawrence J., Johns Hopkins University, Welch Center for Prevention, Epidemiology, and Clinical Research, Baltimore, MD, US
Brantley, Phillip J., Pennington Biomedical Research Center, Division of Education, Baton Rouge, LA, US
Champagne, Catherine, Pennington Biomedical Research Center, Dietary Assessment and Food Analysis Core, Baton Rouge, LA, US
Charleston, Jeanne, Johns Hopkins University, Welch Center for Prevention, Epidemiology, and Clinical Research, Baltimore, MD, US
Svetkey, Laura P., Duke University Medical Center, Sarah Stedman Nutrition and Metabolism Center, Durham, NC, US
Address:
Ard, Jamy D., ardj@uab.edu
Source:
Obesity, Vol 16(2), Feb, 2008. pp. 306-310.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Nature Publishing Group
Other Journal Titles:
Obesity Research
Other Publishers:
US : North American Assn for the Study of Obesity (NAASO)
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
1930-7381 (Print)
1930-739X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
weight loss, African Americans, group racial composition, behavior modification, clinical trials, behavior change
Abstract:
Objective: We do not know how racial composition of a group influences behavior change for African Americans (AAs) in group-based weight loss programs. We tested the hypothesis that AA who participate in all AA weight loss intervention groups will lose more weight than AA who participate in mixed race groups. Methods and Procedures: This observational study was ancillary to Phase 1 of the Weight Loss Maintenance Study, a multi-center trial of strategies to maintain weight loss after a 20-week behavior modification program. Three of four centers recruited several all-AA intervention groups. Remaining groups were combinations of AA and non-AA participants. All participants received the same weight loss intervention. Change in weight was the primary outcome, comparing participants of all-AA groups with AA participants of mixed race groups conducted by the same AA interventionists. Secondary outcomes included measures of intervention adherence and behavior change. Results: Participants of all-AA groups (n = 271) were comparable to other AA participants (n = 106). The mean proportion of AA in mixed race groups was 56%. All-AA group participants had similar weight loss as those in mixed groups (-4.2 vs. -4.2 kg, P = 0.97). There were no differences between the groups in mean number of sessions attended or changes in dietary intake. Discussion: Significant weight loss was observed in both groups, with no effect of group composition on adherence or weight loss outcomes. Special logistics to accommodate all-AA groups may not be necessary. Despite varying instructional environments, AA appeared to respond positively to intervention messages with significant changes in dietary intake, physical activity (PA), and weight. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Behavior Change; *Behavior Modification; *Blacks; *Weight Control; Clinical Trials

PsycINFO
Record: 121
Title:
Effects of APOE e4, age, and HIV on glial metabolites and cognitive deficits.
Authors:
Chang, Linda, Department of Medicine, Division of Neurology, John A. Burns School of Medicine, University of Hawai’i at Manoa, Honolulu, HI, US, lchang@hawaii.edu
Jiang, Caroline, Department of Medicine, Division of Neurology, John A. Burns School of Medicine, University of Hawai’i at Manoa, Honolulu, HI, US
Cunningham, Eric, Department of Medicine, Division of Neurology, John A. Burns School of Medicine, University of Hawai’i at Manoa, Honolulu, HI, US
Buchthal, Steven, Department of Medicine, Division of Neurology, John A. Burns School of Medicine, University of Hawai’i at Manoa, Honolulu, HI, US
Douet, Vanessa, Department of Medicine, Division of Neurology, John A. Burns School of Medicine, University of Hawai’i at Manoa, Honolulu, HI, US
Andres, Marilou, Pacific Biosciences Research Center, University of Hawai’i at Manoa, Honolulu, HI, US
Ernst, Thomas, Department of Medicine, Division of Neurology, John A. Burns School of Medicine, University of Hawai’i at Manoa, Honolulu, HI, US
Address:
Chang, Linda, lchang@hawaii.edu
Source:
Neurology, Vol 82(24), Jun 17, 2014. pp. 2213-2222.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
US : Lippincott Williams & Wilkins
ISSN:
0028-3878 (Print)
1526-632X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
APOE e4, alleles, age differences, HIV, glial metabolites, cognitive deficits
Abstract:
Objective: We aimed to evaluate the combined effects of HIV and APOE ɛ4 allele(s) on glial metabolite levels, and on known cognitive deficits associated with either condition, across the ages. Methods: One hundred seventy-seven participants, primarily of white and mixed race (97 seronegative subjects: aged 44.7 ± 1.3 years, 85 [87.6%] men, 28 [28.9%] APOE ɛ41; 80 HIV+ subjects: Aged 47.± 6 1.1 years, 73 [91.3%] men, 23 [28.8%] APOE ɛ41), were assessed cross-sectionally for metabolite concentrations using proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy in 4 brain regions and for neuropsychological performance. Results: Frontal white matter myo-inositol was elevated in subjects with HIV across the age span but showed age-dependent increase in seronegative subjects, especially in APOE ɛ41 carriers. In contrast, only seronegative APOE ɛ41 subjects showed elevated myo-inositol in parietal cortex. All APOE ɛ41 subjects had lower total creatine in basal ganglia. While all HIV subjects showed greater cognitive deficits, HIV1 APOE ɛ41 subjects had the poorest executive function, fluency memory, and attention/working memory. Higher myo-inositol levels were associated with poorer fine motor function across all subjects, slower speed of information processing in APOE ɛ41 subjects, and worse fluency in HIV1 APOE ɛ41 subjects. Conclusions: In frontal white matter of subjects with HIV, the persistent elevation and lack of normal age-dependent increase in myo-inositol suggest that persistent glial activation attenuated the typical antagonistic pleiotropic effects of APOE ɛ4 on neuroinflammation. APOE ɛ4 negatively affects energy metabolism in brain regions rich in dopaminergic synapses. The combined effects of HIV infection and APOE ɛ4 may lead to greater cognitive deficits, especially in those with greater neuroinflammation. APOE ɛ4 allele(s) may be a useful genetic marker to identify white and mixed-race HIV subjects at risk for cognitive decline. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Cognitive Impairment; *HIV; *Metabolites; *Apolipoprotein E; *Neuroglia; Age Differences; Alleles
