Title:
Review of Articulate while Black: Barack Obama, language, and race in the U.S.
Authors:
Ore, Ersula J., Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ, US, ejore@asu.edu
Address:
Ore, Ersula J., ejore@asu.edu
Source:
Journal of Language, Identity, and Education, Vol 13(2), Mar, 2014. pp. 124-127.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Lawrence Erlbaum
Reviewed Item:
Alim, H. Samy; Smitherman, G. (2012) Articulate while Black: Barack Obama, language, and race in the US New York, NY: Oxford University Press. 205 pages. $24.95 0199812985 (Paperback).
ISSN:
1534-8458 (Print)
1532-7701 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Blacks, Barack Obama, language, racial differences, articulation
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Articulate While Black: Barack Obama, Language, and Race in the US by H. Samy Alim and G. Smitherman (2012). In the present book, Alim and Smitherman continue to stay true to the language game by decoding the “racially coded meanings of articulate and how they function to reproduce racist ideologies and, more importantly, racial inequalities”. Using a critical linguistics approach, the authors look at patterns of speech, analyze the syntax of White and Black discourse, and observe how the regular and patterned use of adjectives accompanying articulate indicate the racist subtext of what on the surface may appear to be praise, but what smacks of White racist paternalism, particularly when used by White speakers towards speakers of color. The chapters provide the larger ongoing social, historical, and political processes contributing to the racially coded meanings of articulate. The book is just as much about Obama’s walking the line of linguistic versatility and subsequent ascent to the presidency as it is about America’s attitude towards African American Vernacular English (AAVE) and African American culture. The book outline the contours of Obama’s rhetorical style: his blending of the sacred and the profane and his ability to analyze his mixed-race audience and select “a familiar cultural touchstone” such as the jeremiad, which speaks to Americans’ “shared values embodied in the American Dream”. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Articulation (Speech); *Blacks; *Language; *Racial and Ethnic Differences

Title:
Review of Black identity in the 20th century: Expressions of the U.S. And U.K. African diaspora.
Authors:
Allen, Troy D., Southern University, New Orleans, LA, US
Source:
Journal of Black Studies, Vol 39(3), Jan, 2009. pp. 482-487.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Reviewed Item:
Christian, M. (Ed). (2002) Black Identity in the 20th Century: Expressions of the U.S. and U.K. African Diaspora London Habsib
ISSN:
0021-9347 (Print)
1552-4566 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Blacks, ethnic identity, mixed race identity, racism
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Black Identity in the 20th Century: Expressions of the U.S. and U.K. African Diaspora by M. Christian (2002). This book is an outstanding collection of essays that brings together scholars from the United States and the United Kingdom to offer analysis on a wide range of topics from Pan-Africanism to mixed-race identity in the 20th century. The essays are linked through common themes of resistance and struggle against White racism, marginalization, and racial discrimination. The author defines Black as persons/groups who can claim African heritage throughout the world. Although he refuses to be labeled an essentialist, the author takes pains to argue that there is an “essence” to being of African descent in the 20th century. Therefore, the contributors openly discuss the commonality of experiences that Black people have had throughout the various social histories of the United States and the United Kingdom. This offering is a much-needed vehicle for African-centered voices to the discourse on Black identity in the 21st century. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

*Ethnic Identity; *Racism; Blacks

Bird, S. R. (2009) Light bright, and damned near White: Biracial and triracial culture in America Westport, CT: Praeger, 150 pp. $39.95 (hardcover)
ISSN:
0739-9863 (Print)
1552-6364 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
biracial culture, triracial culture, identity
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Light bright, and damned near White: Biracial and triracial culture in America by S. R. Bird (2009). This book begins with a history of biracial and triracial individuals within the US. Bird also discusses the traumas and victories of recognition and acceptance that bi- and triracial persons face because of the constant challenge to define an identity based on the characteristics of the races that come together to make up the person. Other topics covered include stereotypes and prejudice, Native Americans, various Louisianan mixed race groups, and DNA studies and their contribution to our understanding of racial makeup. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Review of Making multiracials: State, family, and market in the redrawing of the color line.
Authors:
Childs, Erica Chito, Hunter College, City University of New York, New York, NY, US
Source:
American Journal of Sociology, Vol 115(2), Sep, 2009. pp. 630-631.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : Univ of Chicago Press
Reviewed Item:
DaCosta, Kimberly McClain. (2007) Making multiracials: State, family, and market in the redrawing of the color line Stanford, Calif.: Stanford University Press, Pp. xiii + 259. $21.95
ISSN:
0002-9602 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multiracials, multiracialism, intermarriage, family, multiracial adults, communities, racial politics, policy, racial inequality
Abstract:
Reviews the book Making multiracials: State, family, and market in the redrawing of the color line by Kimberly McClain DaCosta (2007). Based on multiple methods, the book paints a multiracial mosaic from in-depth interviews with 62 participants in groups formed for intermarried couples, their families, and multiracial adults, in addition to fieldwork conducted at related events such as mixed-race conferences, college campuses, and public hearings on census classification. The book is divided into seven chapters on various realms including families, communities, and the market, woven together by connected threads on how multiracials have been constructed—socially, culturally, and politically. In the end, Making Multiracials provides a compelling and convincing analysis of not only multiracialism, but the larger racial politics. The strength of the work lies in DaCosta’s multilayered critique of the ways in which multiracialism is constructed. By blending theory, empirical examination, and strong analysis, Making Multiracials offers a nuanced context for understanding the roles that individuals, communities, and policies play in perpetuating and potentially combating racial inequality. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Interracial Family; *Interracial Marriage; *Interracial Offspring; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Multiculturalism; Communities; Diversity; Policy Making; Racism; Social Equality

Title:
Review of Mixed race Hollywood.
Authors:
Padilla, Amado M., Stanford University, Stanford, CA, US

Reviewed Item:
Beltrán, M. (Ed); Fojas, C. (Ed). (2008) Mixed race Hollywood New York, NY: New York University Press, 325 pp. $24.00 (paperback)
ISSN:
0739-9863 (Print)
1552-6364 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
films, Hollywood, mixed race individuals, ethnicity, racial stereotypes, Latinos, movie casting
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Mixed race Hollywood, edited by M. Beltrán and C. Fojas (2008). Little scholarship has been given to the portrayal of mixed race individuals on the big screen. In this book, the focus of the different chapter authors is on ethnic ambiguity, interracial relationships, mixed race individuals, and ethnic heritage and how these have been projected in films and TV over the past 70 years. In one way or another most chapters discuss how racial stereotypes and crossings of racial boundaries are seen by the larger society and how these have been portrayed over time by Hollywood. This is an interesting book for scholars seeking information on how Latinos have been cast in movies over the past seven decades. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Review of Mixed: Multiracial students tell their life stories.
Authors:
Harri, Jessica C., Indiana University, IN, US

Source:
Journal of College Student Development, Vol 55(8), Nov, 2014. pp. 856-858.
Page Count:

US : ACPA Executive Office

Journal of College Student Personnel
Reviewed Item:
Garrod, Andrew (Ed); Kilkenny, Robert (Ed); Gomez, Christina (Ed). (2014) Mixed: Multiracial students tell their life stories Ithaca, New York: Cornell University Press, 200 pages, $69.95 (hardcover)
ISSN:
0897-5264 (Print)
1543-3382 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multiracial college students, life stories, narratives
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Mixed: Multiracial College Students Tell Their Life Stories edited by Andrew Garrod, Robert Kilkenny, & Christina Gomez (2014). This book presents multiracial student essays focusing on growing up and living as a mixed-race individual in a society founded on monoracial understandings of race. The purpose of the book is "to capture the phenomenology of being mixed-race in a compelling way, and in so doing to inspire, engage, and move our readers". The edited book contains 12 narratives written by self-identified multiracial students: six men and six women, either current students or recent graduates of Dartmouth College. The introduction provides an important context for the 12 narratives. The book concludes rather abruptly with no discussion of how the 12 narratives may inform higher education research and practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
Review of Obama and the biracial factor: The battle for a new American majority.
Authors:
Andrews, Matthew T. M., Department of Sociology, University of Michigan, MI, US, mmdrews@umich.edu
Address:
Andrews, Matthew T. M., mmdrews@umich.edu
Source:
Ethnic and Racial Studies, Vol 36(5), May, 2013. pp. 918-919.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Reviewed Item:
Jolivette, Andrew J. (Ed). (2012) Obama and the biracial factor: The battle for a new American majority Bristol: Policy Press, v+237 pp., £21.99 (paper)
ISSN:
0141-9870 (Print)
1466-4356 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Obama, biracial factor, political elections
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Obama and the biracial factor: The battle for a new American majority edited by Andrew J. Jolivette (2012). This book a collection of essays that critically explore the role of US President Barack Obama’s biracial background not only in his 2008 election and first term in office but also in the context of an increasingly multiracial USA. This volume is part of a multidisciplinary body of scholarship on 'mixed race' or multiraciality that has grown exponentially in the USA and the UK over the past two decades. However, it also departs from this scholarship’s tendency to focus exclusively on the topics of identity formation and racial classification on government forms. Instead, utilizing the timely case of President Obama -'the son of a black man from Kenya and a white woman from Kansas'- the book examines what Jolivette terms ‘mixed race hegemony’, the assertion that 'biracial and multiracial individuals and families will lead to the end of a race-conscious and racially-discriminatory society in the United States'. Overall, many race scholars, likely, will find Jolivette’s concept of ‘mixed race hegemony’ a more contextualized alternative to broader terms like ‘colour-blindness’ in the critical examinations of multiraciality. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Interracial Offspring; *Political Elections; *Politicians
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)

Title:
Review of Protecting home: Class, race and masculinity in boys' baseball.
Authors:
Wazienski, Robert, Illinois State University, Normal, IL, US
Source:
Men and Masculinities, Vol 10(3), Jan, 2008. pp. 370-372.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Reviewed Item:
Grasmuck, S.; Goldwater, J. (2005) Protecting home: Class, race and masculinity in boys' baseball Piscataway, NJ: Rutgers University Press
ISSN:
1097-184X (Print)
1552-6828 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race, masculinity, boys' baseball, social class, social status
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Protecting Home: Class, Race and Masculinity in Boys' Baseball by S. Grasmuck and J. Goldwater (2005). This book is a captivating piece of work. Its title and subtitle, however, reveal only a fraction of the sociological insight this book genuinely provides. The introductory chapter effectively leads into a marvelous explanation of the gentrification of a Philadelphia neighborhood. Social class and social status are continuously explored throughout the book. The book is organized as to provide a logical succession of concepts derived from the previous set. I will confess that much of my fascination with the book may center around my own life experiences growing up and playing ball in a predominantly Catholic, mixed-race, inner-city neighborhood in Chicago. The book was an introspection for me, and that may be one noteworthy reason for why I enjoyed reading it. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Baseball; *Masculinity; *Race (Anthropological); *Social Class; *Sociology; Life Experiences
PsycINFO Classification:
Sex Roles & Women's Issues (2970)

Human

Record: 318
Title:
Review of Race, ethnicity and nation: Perspectives from kinship and genetics.
Authors:
El-Shaarawi, Nadia, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, US, nadia.el-shaarawi@case.edu
Address:
El-Shaarawi, Nadia, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, US, 44106, nadia.el-shaarawi@case.edu
Source:
Culture, Medicine and Psychiatry, Vol 33(2), Jun, 2009. pp. 335-337.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
Reviewed Item:
Wade, Peter. (2007) Race, ethnicity and nation: Perspectives from kinship and genetics Berghahn Books, New York, 200 pp
ISSN:
0165-005X (Print)
1573-076X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racism, ethnicity, kinship, genetics, culture
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Race, ethnicity and nation: Perspectives from kinship and genetics by P. Wade (2007). Among the issues addressed in this volume are transnational adoption, ethnicity and assisted reproduction, mixed-race families, immigration, the transmission of ethnicity in post-Soviet Lithuania, and changing conceptions of Basque racial identity. This book is a useful and illuminating read for those with a particular interest in the ways in which new technologies and associated practices are changing ways of thinking about kinship in Europe. All the chapters in this volume ask questions about the supposedly ‘given’ nature of kinship. By interrogating the boundaries between nature and culture, the authors illustrate the varied ways in which the supposedly natural relations that are the basis of much racial and ethnic categorization are produced in local social, cultural, and historical worlds. However, despite its strengths, this volume has several weaknesses. A lack of explicitness in methodology may leave the reader wondering how some of the authors arrived at their conclusions. In addition, many of the studies rely heavily on media or print sources. The chapters that make use of both media sources and interviews or participant observation provide a stronger, more convincing and more varied body of evidence than those that rely more exclusively on media sources. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Genetics; *Kinship; Racism; Sociocultural Factors
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 319
Title:
Review of Racial union: Law, intimacy, and the White state in Alabama, 1865-1954.
Authors:
Sullivan, Kathleen, Ohio University, OH, US
Source:
Law & Society Review, Vol 43(2), Jun, 2009. pp. 445-447.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Reviewed Item:
Novkov, Julie. (2008) Racial union: Law, intimacy, and the white state in Alabama, 1865-1954 Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, Pp. 368. $75.00, $26.95
ISSN:
0023-9216 (Print)
1540-5893 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial union, law, intimacy, White state, civil law
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Racial union: Law, intimacy, and the white state in Alabama, 1865-1954 by Julie Novkov (2008). Novkov views bans on interracial intimacy not as a legacy of a bygone era but as a key resource in state-building. Limiting her scope to the development of a single state on a single issue provides a focused lens to track the life of the law and its use in constructing a regime of white supremacy. Novkov steps out of the periodization in one chapter to capture a pattern in white masculinity in the period 1914–1944. White men who bequeathed property to their children were faced with the consequences of anti-miscegenation laws when their bequests to their mixed-race children were called into question. By narrowing her scope to one state and one legal construct, Novkov produces a history of the opportunities and challenges involved in state-building. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Civil Law; *Interracial Marriage; *Laws; *Racism; *Whites; Racial and Ethnic Relations
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 320
Title:
Review of Raising Brooklyn: Nannies, Childcare, and Caribbeans CreatingCommunity.
Authors:
Hondagneu‐Sotelo, Pierrette, Department of Sociology, University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, US, sotelo@usc.edu
Address:
Hondagneu‐Sotelo, Pierrette, Department of Sociology, University of Southern California, 851 Downey Way, HSH 314, Los Angeles, CA, US, 90089-2539, sotelo@usc.edu
Source:
Sociological Forum, Vol 28(3), Sep, 2013. pp. 642-643.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Publishers:
Germany : Springer
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Reviewed Item:
Brown, Tamara Mose. (2011) Raising Brooklyn: Nannies, Childcare, and Caribbeans Creating Community New York: New York University Press
ISSN:
0884-8971 (Print)
1573-7861 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
child care, communities, gentrifying neighborhood, ethnography
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Raising Brooklyn: Nannies, Childcare, and Caribbeans Creating Community by Tamara Mose Brown (2011). Tamara Mose Brown’s new book, continues with this high-quality research and extends the analysis to new spheres. The author, a graduate student and mother of toddlers when she did the research, conducted participant observation and interviews over a period of 3 years with 25 West Indian nannies in a gentrifying neighborhood of Brooklyn. She also interviewed 10 employers of nannies, but we don’t hear too much about them. The author grew up in a Trinidadian immigrant household, and identifies as mixed race; yet she recognizes that like many of the West Indian immigrant nannies she studied, she is racially identified by others as black. All of the research subjects worked as live-out nannies in the neighborhood where the author lived as a resident, and the park benches in the local public parks provide one of the main places of study. This is a rich book. The study is beautifully observed, written in a calm affect, hitting the right pitch. We sociologists don’t usually evaluate this aspect of writing, but tone sets the scene for both ethnographic description and analysis. This book shows an important part of urban life in Brooklyn that goes beyond the media’s glossy portrayal of Brooklyn as iconic hipster neighborhood. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Child Care; *Communities; *Ethnography; *Immigration; *Neighborhoods
PsycINFO Classification:

Title:
Review of The biopolitics of mixing: Thai multiracialities and haunted ascendancies.
Authors:
Kuntsman, Adi, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom
Source:
European Journal of Women's Studies, Vol 21(1), Feb, 2014. pp. 120-122.
Page Count:
3
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Reviewed Item:
Haritaworn, Jinthana. (2012) The biopolitics of mixing: Thai multiracialities and haunted ascendancies Ashgate: Farnham, 198 pp 9780754676805.
ISSN:
1350-5068 (Print)
1461-7420 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racism, multiculturalism, oppression, nationalism, biopolitics, multiraciality, mixed race, diaspora, colonialism
Abstract:
Reviews the book, The Biopolitics of Mixing: Thai Multiracialities and Haunted Ascendancies by Jinthana Haritaworn (2012). This book is one of those scholarly interventions that takes your breath away. Complex, razor sharp and beautifully written, it engages with several fields: multiraciality and ‘mixed race’, diaspora, coloniality, racism and nationalism, sexuality, gender and disability. From the very first pages of the book we are made aware of the complex and often contradictory interrelations of past and present; celebration and forgetting; figurations and fleshy bodies; and location and displacement. The author does so beautifully by constantly moving between the interviewees’ voices and those of feminist and queer-of colour scholars, where the former are never a pre-theorised raw material for a violent scholarly dissection. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Nationalism; *Politics; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Racism; *Multiculturalism; Human Sex Differences; Interracial Offspring; Oppression; Colonialism
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 322
Title:
Review of The global bell curve: Race, IQ and inequality worldwide.
Authors:
Rushton, J. Philippe, Department of Psychology, University of Western Ontario, London, ON, Canada, rushton@uwo.ca
Address:
Rushton, J. Philippe, Department of Psychology, University of Western Ontario, London, ON, Canada, N6A 5C2, rushton@uwo.ca
Source:
Personality and Individual Differences, Vol 45(1), Jul, 2008. pp. 113-114.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
Reviewed Item:
Lynn, R. (2008) The global bell curve: Race, IQ and inequality worldwide Washington Summit Publishers, Augusta, GA 378 pp., US $18.95 1-59368-028-7 (Paperback).
ISSN:
0191-8869 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
socioeconomic status, racism, IQ, social inequality, racial differences
Abstract:
Reviews the book, The Global Bell Curve: Race, IQ and Inequality Worldwide by R. Lynn (2008). The theme of the book is an examination of whether the same type of racial hierarchy in IQ and socio-economic status that Herrnstein and Murray documented in the US is present in other parts of the world. The author's new book provides fascinating historical vignettes to describe all the migrations and mixing of peoples. It also provides clear tables of data, which allow the reader to check the facts for themselves. The author argues that these theories are to some degree plausible for some countries, but are often ad hoc and do not explain the world wide consistency of the differences. The conclusion that IQ differences are the crucial determinant of racial socio-economic hierarchies raises the question of what causes the IQ inequalities. In principle, they could be wholly environmentally determined. However, the author argues that their consistency across time and circumstance points to genetic factors. He reviews other data in support including hybridization studies and finds that "mixed-race" populations fall between parental populations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Intelligence Quotient; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Racism; *Social Equality; *Socioeconomic Status

Title:
Review of Weaving a Family: Untangling Race and Adoption.
Authors:
Laube, Heather, University of Michigan-Flint, Flint, MI, US
Source:
Gender & Society, Vol 20(2), Apr, 2006. pp. 290-291.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Reviewed Item:
Rothman, Barbara Katz. (2005) Weaving a Family: Untangling Race and Adoption Boston: Beacon, 2005, 274 pp., $26.95 (cloth)
ISSN:
0891-2432 (Print)
1552-3977 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
family, adoption, mothering, race, sociology, child care
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Weaving a Family: Untangling Race and Adoption by Barbara Katz Rothman (2005). This is a personal book, more auto-ethnography than memoir. The author grounds her theory in the practice of mothering, race, adoption, and sociology. The author uses mothering (whether performed by women or men), not parenting, as the term for the practices and work of caring for children. Her discussion integrates the complexities of genetic science and genetic ideologies. The child-as-pet theme reflects the traditional relationship of a mother to her small child. The mother indulges her children, but also indulges herself in the joys of nurturing. This is an excellent book for anyone considering transracial adoption or who is a member of a mixed-race family. Those interested in issues of race will benefit from what Weaving a Family teaches us about the tensions between our personal experiences and the social contexts in which they are shaped and interpreted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Child Care; *Family; *Interracial Adoption; *Mothers; Sociology
PsycINFO Classification:
Childrearing & Child Care (2956)

Record: 324
Title:
'Rider of two horses': Eurafricans in Zambia.
Authors:
Milner-Thornton, Juliette Bridgette, School of Humanities, Griffith University, QLD, Australia
Source:
Global mixed race. King-O'Riain, Rebecca C. (Ed); Small, Stephen (Ed); Mahtani, Minelle (Ed); Song, Miri (Ed); Spickard, Paul (Ed); pp. 16-43; New York, NY, US: New York University Press; 2014. xxii, 335 pp.
Page Count:
28
ISBN:
978-0-8147-7073-3 (Hardcover)
978-0-8147-8915-5 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Eurafricans, racial categorization, ethnic identity, marginalization, migration, coloredness
Abstract:
This chapter charts the shifting production and construction of "Colouredness" from its initial racial categorization to its current application as an ethnic and cultural identity in modern-day Zambia. The author uses the term "Eurafrican" and "Coloured" despite their historically controversial nature. Both terms are of historical and contemporary significance in Zambia. In contemporary Zambia the Eurafrican community is known as "Coloured." This concurs with the current application of "Coloured" as an ethnic identity and cultural classification characterized by Eurafricans' and so-called Indo-Africans' historical experiences of marginalization and alienation in colonial Zambia. The author also write and present firsthand autoethnographic accounts to reflect upon Eurafricans' marginalization and alienation in colonial Zambia, and their desire to be recognized as the legitimate descendants of British men, as well as to explore the ongoing legacies of these historical proceedings in Zambian Coloured people's contemporary political experiences and cultural practices. To better understand Zambian Coloured people's contemporary exclusion from Zambia's national census and appreciate their return migration to Britain, there is a need to examine British imperial procedures in colonial Zambia. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*African Cultural Groups; *Ethnic Identity; *Interethnic Family; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Human Migration; Marginalization
PsycINFO Classification:

Population:

Location:
Zambia

Document Type:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 325
Title:
Rooming in the master's house: Psychological domination and the Black conservative.
Authors:
Hall, Ronald E., Asian Institute, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, US, hallr@msu.edu
Address:
Hall, Ronald E., School of Social Work, Michigan State University, Room 224 Baker Hall, East Lansing, MI, US, 48823, hallr@msu.edu
Source:
Journal of Black Studies, Vol 38(4), Mar, 2008. pp. 565-578.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0021-9347 (Print)
1552-4566 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
psychological domination, Black conservatives
Abstract:
Politics contemporaneously may be the most potent extension of domination characteristic of slaves during the American antebellum. As slaves, "house negroes" were the psychologically dominated, mixed-race offspring of the antebellum master class. The political descendants of antebellum house negroes are today's Black Conservatives. Their political aspirations represent a corrupted version of the "American dream." In particular, those who are scholars take part in contrived research in their mandate to serve the political status quo. Black Conservatives must become cognizant of their unique role--that of advocating for the interests of Black people, their class, their community, as well as their country. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Political Conservatism; *Psychodynamics
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
20081103
Correction Date:
20111107
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1177/0021934706288145
Accession Number:
2008-02765-003
Number of Citations in Source:
38
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2008-02765-003&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2008-02765-003&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2008-02765-003&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Rooming in the master's house: Psychological domination and the Black conservative.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 326
Title:
Roommate satisfaction and ethnic identity in mixed-race and White university roommate dyads.
Authors:
Phelps, Rosemary E., U Georgia, Dept of Counseling & Human Development Services, Athens, GA, US
Altschul, Deborah B.
Wisenbaker, Joseph M.
Day, James F.
Cooper, Diane
Potter, Carol G.
Source:
Journal of College Student Development, Vol 39(2), Mar-Apr, 1998. pp. 194-203.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
US : ACPA Executive Office
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of College Student Personnel
ISSN:
0897-5264 (Print)
1543-3382 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
roommate satisfaction & ethnic identity, Asian-American–White vs African-American–White vs White–White vs Hispanic-American–White college roommate dyads
Abstract:
Examined roommate satisfaction and ethnic identity using the Roommate Relationship Inventory, the Ethnicity Questionnaire, and the Multigroup Ethnic Identity Measure in 54 African-American–White, 37 Asian-American–White, 11 Hispanic-American–White, and 48 White randomly assigned roommate dyads at a large, public, predominantly White, Southeastern university. White roommate dyads had significantly higher roommate satisfaction scores than African-American–White roommate dyads. Racial composition of roommate dyads, ethnic pride, and other-group orientation were significant predictors of roommate satisfaction. The authors also discuss implications for practice and suggestions for future research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Peer Relations; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Roommates; *Satisfaction; Asians; Blacks; Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; Whites; Latinos/Latinas

Culture & Ethnology (2930)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 327
Title:
Roommate satisfaction and ethnic pride in same-race and mixed-race university roommate pairs.
Authors:
Phelps, Rosemary E., U Georgia, Dept of Counseling & Human Development Services, Athens,, GA, US
Potter, Carol G.
Slavich, Rita
Day, James F.
Source:
Journal of College Student Development, Vol 37(4), Jul-Aug, 1996. pp. 377-388.
Page Count:
12
Publisher:
US : ACPA Executive Office
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of College Student Personnel
ISSN:
0897-5264 (Print)
1543-3382 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
ethnic pride & roommate satisfaction, Black & White same- race vs mixed-race roommate pairs, implications for practice
Abstract:
Roommate satisfaction and ethnic pride were assessed in 101 same-race and mixed-race randomly assigned roommate pairs (aged 17–28 yrs) at the University of Georgia. There were 39 African American roommate pairs, 30 White pairs, and 32 African- American–White pairs. The Ss were interviewed by means of a telephone survey. Perceptions of the roommate relationships were measured using the Roomate Relationship Inventory and ethnic pride was assessed using The Ethnicity Questionnaire. African American roommate pairs indicated significantly greater roommate satisfaction than did African American–White pairs. African American roommate pairs also had the highest ethnic pride score. Implications for practice and further research directions are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Pride; *Racial and Ethnic Relations; *Roommates; *Satisfaction; Blacks; College Students; Whites
PsycINFO Classification:
Classroom Dynamics & Student Adjustment & Attitudes (3560)

Record: 328
Title:
Rorschach assessment of the borderline child.
Authors:
Acklin, Marvin W., U Hawaii, John Burns School of Medicine, Honolulu, US
Source:
Journal of Clinical Psychology, Vol 51(2), Mar, 1995. pp. 294-302.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
US : John Wiley & Sons
Other Journal Titles:
In Session: Psychotherapy in Practice
ISSN:
0021-9762 (Print)
1097-4679 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Rorschach assessment, children with borderline personality disorders
Abstract:
Examines manifestations of childhood borderline conditions on the Rorschach. The use of the testing interaction and the unique productions on projective techniques, especially the Rorschach, provide remarkable vistas into the primitive agonies, disordered attachments, and chaotic representational worlds of children with borderline personality disorders (BPDs). Their core sense of self has not achieved the sort of stability, constancy, and integrity that allow for effective functioning in the world. Continuity with adult forms of BPDs has been demonstrated in some studies. Poor outcomes and persistent psychopathology are expected for most children who fall within this spectrum of disorders. A case study of a 14-yr-old mixed-race girl is presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Borderline States; *Rorschach Test
PsycINFO Classification:
Personality Disorders (3217)

Record: 329
Title:
Rushton’s r–k life history theory of race differences in penis length and circumference examined in 113 populations.
Authors:
Lynn, Richard, University of Ulster, Coleraine, Northern Ireland, lynnr540@aol.com
Address:
Lynn, Richard, University of Ulster, Coleraine, Northern Ireland, BT52 1SA, lynnr540@aol.com
Source:
Personality and Individual Differences, Vol 55(3), Jul, 2013. pp. 261-266.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0191-8869 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Rushton's r-K life history theory, race differences, penis length, circumference
Abstract:
Rushton’s (1985, 2000) r–K life history theory that Mongoloids are the most K evolved, Caucasoids somewhat less K evolved, and Negroids the least K evolved is examined and extended in an analysis of data for erect penis length and circumference in two new data sets. These new data extend Rushton’s theory by presenting disaggregated data for penis size for European and North African/South Asian Caucasoids; for East Asian and Southeast Asian Mongoloids; for Inuit and Amerindians and Mestizos, and for thirteen mixed race samples. The results generally confirm and extend Rushton’s r–K life history theory. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Penis; *Race and Ethnic Discrimination; Theories

Record: 330
Title:
Say it loud: The Obama effect and racial/ethnic identification of adolescents.
Authors:
Williams, Javonda, School of Social Work, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, US, jwilliams11@sw.ua.edu
Bolland, Kathleen A., School of Social Work, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, US
Hooper, Lisa, Department of Educational and Counseling Psychology, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY, US
Church, Wesley, School of Social Work, Louisiana State University, Baton Rouge, LA, US
Tomek, Sara, College of Education, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, US
Bolland, John, College of Human and Environmental Sciences, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL, US
Address:
Williams, Javonda, School of Social Work, University of Alabama, P.O. Box 870314, Tuscaloosa, AL, US, 35487-0314, jwilliams11@sw.ua.edu
Source:
Journal of Human Behavior in the Social Environment, Vol 24(7), Oct, 2014. pp. 858-868.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Haworth Press
ISSN:
1091-1359 (Print)
1540-3556 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial identification, adolescent development, identity development
Abstract:
The current study examined how self-reported racial/ethnic identification of adolescents living in poverty may be related to significant societal events and seminal public figures. Data from a multiple cohort longitudinal study, conducted in Mobile, Alabama between 1998 and 2011, were used to examine the impact of Barack Obama's nomination and presidency on racial/ethnic identification. The results show that significantly more adolescents changed their self-reported racial/ethnic identification from White or Mixed-Race to Black or Mixed Race after the election than before. These results suggest that a distant public figure can serve as a role model with observable effects for adolescents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adolescent Attitudes; *Ethnic Identity; *Music; *Personality Development; *Poverty; Identity Formation; Interpersonal Influences; Politicians; Racial and Ethnic Relations

Record: 331
Title:
Seeing similarity or distance? Racial identification moderates intergroup perception after biracial exposure.
Authors:
Wilton, Leigh, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ, US, lwilton@rci.rutgers.edu
Sanchez, Diana T., Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ, US
Giamo, Lisa, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC, Canada
Address:
Wilton, Leigh, Department of Psychology, Rutgers University, 53 Avenue E, Piscataway, NJ, US, 08854-8040, lwilton@rci.rutgers.edu
Source:
Social Psychology, Vol 45(2), 2014. pp. 127-134.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
Germany : Hogrefe Publishing
Other Journal Titles:
Zeitschrift für Sozialpsychologie
Other Publishers:
Germany : Hogrefe & Huber Publishers
Switzerland : Verlag Hans Huber
ISSN:
1864-9335 (Print)
2151-2590 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
biracial, intergroup attitudes, racial ambiguity, racial identification, perceived intergroup similarity, facial similarity, racially ambiguous faces, Asian: White
Abstract:
Biracial individuals threaten the distinctiveness of racial groups because they have mixed-race ancestry, but recent findings suggest that exposure to biracial-labeled, racially ambiguous faces may positively influence intergroup perception by reducing essentialist thinking among Whites (Young, Sanchez, & Wilton, 2013). However, biracial exposure may not lead to positive intergroup perceptions for Whites who are highly racially identified and thus motivated to preserve the social distance between racial groups. We exposed Whites to racially ambiguous Asian/White biracial faces and measured the perceived similarity between Asians and Whites. We found that exposure to racially ambiguous, biracial-labeled targets may improve perceptions of intergroup similarity, but only for Whites who are less racially identified. Results are discussed in terms of motivated intergroup perception. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Face Perception; *Group Dynamics; *Social Perception; *Stimulus Ambiguity; Asians; Attitudes; Whites
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Perception & Cognition (3040)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Tests & Measures:

Grant Sponsorship:
Sponsor: National Science Foundation
Grant Number: 1048324; 1226201
Recipients: Sanchez, Diana T.
Methodology:

Document Type:

Record: 332
Title:
Self-categorization with a novel mixed-race group moderates automatic social and racial biases.
Authors:
Van Bavel, Jay J., Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, US, van-bave1.1@osu.edu
Cunningham, William A., Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, US
Address:
Van Bavel, Jay J., Ohio State University, Department of Psychology, 1827 Neil Avenue, Columbus, OH, US, 43210, van-bave1.1@osu.edu
Source:
Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, Vol 35(3), Mar, 2009. pp. 321-335.
Page Count:
15
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0146-1672 (Print)
1552-7433 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
self categorization, race group, automatic social biases, racial biases, social perception, social identity
Abstract:
People perceive and evaluate others according to social categories. Yet social perception is complicated by the fact that people have multiple social identities, and self-categorization with these identities shifts from one situation to another. Two experiments examined whether self-categorization with a novel mixed-race group would override automatic racial bias. Participants assigned to a mixed-race group had more positive automatic evaluations of Black ingroup than Black outgroup members. Comparing these evaluations to Black and White faces unaffiliated with either group indicated this preference was driven by ingroup bias rather than outgroup derogation. Moreover, both outgroup and unaffiliated faces elicited automatic racial bias (White > Black), suggesting that automatic evaluations are sensitive to both the current intergroup context (positive evaluations of novel ingroup members) and race (racial bias toward outgroup and unaffiliated faces). These experiments provide evidence that self-categorization can override automatic racial bias and that automatic evaluations shift between and within social contexts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Group Dynamics; *Intergroup Dynamics; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Issues; *Social Perception; Ingroup Outgroup; Social Identity
PsycINFO Classification:
Personality Traits & Processes (3120)
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:

Male
Female
Location:

Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Methodology:

Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:

Document Type:
Journal Article

Release Date:
20090713
Copyright:
Society for Personality and Social Psychology, Inc.. 2009

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1177/0146167208327743

Record: 333
Title:
Self-reported race and genetic admixture.
Authors:
Sinha, Moumita, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, US
Larkin, Emma K., Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, US
Elston, Robert C., Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, US
Redline, Susan, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, US, susan.redline@case.edu
Address:
Redline, Susan, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH, US, 44106, susan.redline@case.edu
Source:
The New England Journal of Medicine, Vol 354(4), Jan, 2006. pp. 421-422.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : Massachusetts Medical Society
Other Journal Titles:
Boston Medical & Surgical Journal
ISSN:
0028-4793 (Print)
1533-4406 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
self reported racial identity, genetic analysis, research data, inappropriate classification, genetic research
Abstract:
This letter to the editor discusses self-reported race and genetic admixture. The authors of this letter argue that the use of self-reported race in health research is debatable. They cite several other authors who have discussed the limitations in research analysis, inappropriate classifications of groups, and the use of suboptimal model for genetic cluster analysis. Despite advances in genetic analysis, clinicians and epidemiologists still disagree on the usefulness of race in clinical reporting. Sinha et al present data from an admixture analysis study they did on a sample population. The specifics of the study are explained. Although the need for cautious interpretation of racial data is indisputable, genetic analyses show that self-reported race is informative for the classification of genetic clusters. Although self-reported blacks in the United States are largely of mixed race, genetic admixture analyses show clear differences between self-reported blacks and whites, indicating that self-reported race provides a means for identifying distinct groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Genetics; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; Experimentation
PsycINFO Classification:
Genetics (2510)
Population:
Human
Location:
US
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Letter

20060206

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1056/NEJMc052515
PMID:
16436780

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 334
Title:
Shared space invasion and race.
Authors:
Brown, Clifford E., Wittenberg U
Source:
Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, Vol 7(1), Mar, 1981. pp. 103-108.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0146-1672 (Print)
1552-7433 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
invasion of shared space of Black &/vs White dyads, male vs female Black vs White shoppers
Abstract:
Observed the tendency of shoppers at a suburban shopping mall to walk between conversing Black, White, or mixed-race male dyads. Both male and female shoppers (N = 508, 93.7% White) were more likely to walk through the Black dyad than through the White or the mixed-race dyads. Results are interpreted as indicating a relative lack of consideration for the Black dyad's interaction territory. When walking around a mixed-race dyad, shoppers more often chose to pass behind the White member. Findings suggest that the often subtle effects of racial attitudes can be studied unobtrusively using the invasion of shared space paradigm. (9 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Dyads; *Personal Space; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Shopping Centers; Human Sex Differences
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Perception & Cognition (3040)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
19820201
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1177/014616728171016
Accession Number:
1982-03577-001
UR:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 335
Title:
Signs of transcendence? A changing landscape of multiraciality in the 21st century.
Authors:
Lou, Evelina, Department of Psychology, York University, Toronto, ON, Canada, evelinalou@gmail.com
Lalonde, Richard N., Department of Psychology, York University, Toronto, ON, Canada, lalonde@yorku.ca
Address:
Lou, Evelina, Department of Psychology, York University, 4700 Keele Street, Toronto, ON, Canada, M3J 1P3, evelinalou@gmail.com
Source:
International Journal of Intercultural Relations, Vol 45, Mar, 2015. pp. 85-95.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0147-1767 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Identity, Biracial, Multiracial, Mixed-race, Identity integration, Self-concept clarity
Abstract:
The relation between multiracial identity selection and psychological outcomes related to the self and well-being was explored among minority/White biracials spanning four different mixed-race groups (n = 201): Black/Whites, East Asian/Whites, Latino/Whites, and South Asian/Whites. The mixed-race groups showed considerable variability in their selection of multiracial identity categories and different patterns of identity selection, as well as a higher overall representation of transcendent identity (i.e., identity that challenges traditional notions of race) than reported in previously published studies. Our findings demonstrated that biracial identity selection, especially when differentiating between identities that are socially validated or not socially validated by others, was related to a person's level of multiracial identity integration, identification with Whites, perceived discrimination from Whites and non-Whites, and psychological well-being. Identity selection groups did not significantly differ from each other in levels of self-concept clarity or identification with their non-White racial group. Theoretical implications for extending a multidimensional model to other mixed-race groups and redefining race as a social and cultural construction are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Identity Formation; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; *Self Concept; *Well Being; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Whites; Multiculturalism

Record: 336
Title:
'Slim is not in' among adolescents in Trinidad.
Authors:
Simeon, Donald T., U of the West Indies, Faculty of Medical Sciences, St Augustine, Trinidad and Tobago
Abdool, Petal S.
Ali, Aleena C.
Kungeesingh, Komal V.
Panchoo, Kirby
Rattan, Ryan D.
Source:
Journal of Adolescent Health, Vol 28(5), May, 2001. pp. 370-371.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of Adolescent Health Care
ISSN:
1054-139X (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cultural factors, body size perceptions, gender differences, ethnic differences, teen attitudes, body weight, Trinidad and Tobago
Abstract:
Examined cultural factors influencing perceptions of body size in 1,139 14–17 yr olds of different ethnic groups in Trinidad and Tobago. Ss, who were mainly South Asian, African, and individuals of mixed race, completed a questionnaire on desired body size and the factors that influenced their choice. There were significant gender differences in desired body size. The majority (83%) of females wanted to be a normal size, 4% overweight and 13% desiring to be underweight. Among males, 66% wanted to be normal-sized, 31% overweight, and 2% underweight. There were no ethnic differences in desired body weight. The main influences of desired body size in females were movie stars, fashion models, and sport personalities. Among males, the most important influences were sports personalities and movie stars. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Body Image; *Body Size; *Human Sex Differences; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Sociocultural Factors; Adolescent Attitudes; Asians; Blacks; Body Weight

Record: 337
Title:
Smoking and the adult transition among urban teenagers.
Authors:
Entwisle, Doris R., Johns Hopkins U, Dept of Sociology, Baltimore, MD, US, entwisle@jhu.edu
Alexander, Karl L., Johns Hopkins U, Dept of Sociology, Baltimore, MD, US
Olson, Linda Steffel, Johns Hopkins U, Dept of Sociology, Baltimore, MD, US
Address:
Entwisle, Doris R., Johns Hopkins U, Dept of Sociology, 3400 N Charles St., Baltimore, MD, US, 21218, entwisle@jhu.edu
Source:
Adolescent & Family Health, Vol 2(3), Fal 2001. pp. 108-122.
Page Count:
15
Publisher:
US : Inst for Youth Development
ISSN:
1533-9890 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
cigarette smoking, adult transition, urban teenagers, economically disadvantaged, African American teens, White teens
Abstract:
Using a life course perspective, this paper traces cigarette use over ages 13-17 yrs among a mixed-race sample of economically disadvantaged urban students. Compared to African American teens, cigarette use by white teens was much more prevalent. Still, experimentation with cigarettes (aged 13-14 yrs) was a powerful predictor of cigarette use at ages 15 and 17 for youth of both races, with those who were least engaged in school more likely to experiment at early ages. Employment during the school year predicted more use of cigarettes mainly by white males, with cigarette use by white females not related to employment. The number of African Americans in this sample who used cigarettes was so few that to analyze cigarette use in relation to employment is not possible. White male students were more disengaged from school, and more likely to be performing adult-type work than other students. This paper suggests they use cigarettes as a means to signal their acceleration of the adult transition. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Adolescent Development; *Disadvantaged; *Psychosocial Development; *Tobacco Smoking; *Urban Environments; Blacks; Whites

Record: 338
Title:
Social identity theory and the reduction of inequality: Can cross-cutting categorization reduce inequality in mixed-race groups?
Authors:
Goar, Carla D., Northern Illinois University, DeKalb, IL, US, goar@niu.edu
Address:
Goar, Carla D., Northern Illinois University, Department of Sociology, DeKalb, IL, US, 60115, goar@niu.edu
Source:
Social Behavior and Personality, Vol 35(4), 2007. pp. 537-550.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
New Zealand : Society for Personality Research
ISSN:
0301-2212 (Print)
1179-6391 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social identity theory, racial inequality, cross cutting categorization, mixed race groups, individualization
Abstract:
A strategy to modify racial inequality in task groups was tested. Based on social identity literature: If members of a group are encouraged to think of other group members as individuals instead of representatives of a larger group, cross-cutting categorization may decrease the effects of race. Thirty groups of one Black woman and two white women, were randomly assigned to either a condition in which group members knew only that some people did better than others on the task (baseline condition), or a condition in which individualization of group members was emphasized (cross-cutting condition). The task was exactly the same in both conditions; only the description of it varied. Relative to the baseline condition, the cross-cutting condition does not significantly decrease the inequality between Black and white group members. Implications of these results for future research on group racial dynamics are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Race and Ethnic Discrimination; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Equality; *Social Identity
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Social Psychology (3000)
Population:

US

Record: 339
Title:
Social representations of ‘mixed-race’ in early twenty-first-century Britain: Content, limitations, and counter-narratives.
Authors:
Aspinall, Peter J, Centre for Health Services Studies (CHSS), University of Kent, Kent, United Kingdom, P.J.Aspinall@kent.ac.uk
Address:
Aspinall, Peter J, CHSS, University of Kent, CANTERBURY, Kent, United Kingdom, CT2 7NF, P.J.Aspinall@kent.ac.uk
Source:
Ethnic and Racial Studies, Vol 38(7), May, 2015. pp. 1067-1083.
Page Count:
17
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0141-9870 (Print)
1466-4356 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed-race, social representations, census, lived experiences, media, nomenclature
Abstract:
Over the last two decades, lay and professional interest in Britain's ‘mixed-race’ population has markedly increased, following dramatic growth in mixing and mixedness. As is often the case with new phenomena, agencies in the sphere of popular culture have stepped in to offer the wider public interpretative representations of this ‘new’ group. Drawing on challenging concepts, like demographic growth rates and projections, the family ‘norm’, the ostensible benefits of heterozygosity, and the drawbacks of claimed ‘in-betweenness’, they have offered us a picture of the ‘mixed-race’ population that is sometimes at variance with lived experiences or the harder image of statistical reality. Social representation theory is used to explore the limitations of these representations and to offer a number of counter-narratives that are grounded in the evidence base. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Record: 340
Title:
Social significance of Huntington's chorea.
Authors:
Hughes, E. M.
Source:
The American Journal of Psychiatry, 4, 1925. pp. 537-574.
Page Count:
38
Publisher:
US : American Psychiatric Assn
Other Journal Titles:
American Journal of Insanity
ISSN:
0002-953X (Print)
1535-7228 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
HUNTINGTON'S CHOREA, SOCIAL SIGNIFICANCE, CHOREA, HUNTINGTON'S, NERVOUS AND MENTAL DISORDERS, SOCIAL FUNCTIONS OF THE INDIVIDUAL
Abstract:
A study of 218 cases shows the following: (1) The disease is not frequent in the Michigan state hospitals. (2) It appears to be one of the few strictly inheritable diseases. (3) The age of onset varies widely. (4) There seems to be no reliable indication in early life of the later development of the disease. (5) Behavior difficulties appeared in two-thirds of the choreics. (6) With regard to mental disease, the greater number of the hospitalized cases were classified with the psychosis undifferentiated. (7) The average length of life after the development of the disease was found to be 16.1 years. (8) Exhaustion was the most frequent cause of death. (9) Seventeen cases of Sydenham's chorea were found to have occurred in otherwise non-choreic relatives; Sydenham's chorea also occurred in three individuals who afterward developed Huntington's chorea. (10) Other neuropathic conditions found in the families of choreics appear to be incidental. (11) The families were largely of mixed race and rural environment predominated. (12) Only 31 per cent of the choreics became public charges. (13) Potential choreics evidently do not abstain from marriage. Prevention will best be gained through education of the public to the dangers of transmission, in the hope that the affected stock will avoid marriage, or employ voluntary sterilization. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
No terms assigned

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 341
Title:
Social status, race, and the timing of marriage in Cuba’s first constitutional era, 1902-1940.
Authors:
Logan, Enid Lynette, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN, US, elogan@umn.edu
Address:
Logan, Enid Lynette, Department of Sociology, University of Minnesota, 909 Social Science Tower, 267 19th Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN, US, 55455, elogan@umn.edu
Source:
Journal of Family History, Vol 36(1), Jan, 2011. pp. 52-71.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0363-1990 (Print)
1552-5473 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social status, race, marriage, Cuba, constitutional era, whites, Blacks
Abstract:
This article examines the practice of marriage among whites, mestizos, blacks, Cubans, and Spaniards during the first constitutional era, focusing upon the reported ages of brides and grooms. The study consists of a quantitative examination of trends found in the records of 900 Catholic marriages celebrated in Havana during the opening decades of independence. The first major finding of the research is that according to most major indicators of status, age was negatively correlated with rank. Thus, contrary to the conclusions of studies conducted in many other contexts, those in the highest strata of society married younger. Furthermore, very significant differences were detected in the marital patterns of those identified as mixed-race and those labeled as black. This finding offers empirical weight to the notion that the early-mid twentieth-century Cuban racial structure would best be characterized as tripartite, rather than binary in nature. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 342
Title:
Sources of self-categorization as minority for mixed-race individuals: Implications for affirmative action entitlement.
Authors:
Good, Jessica J., Department of Psychology, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ, US, goodj@eden.rutgers.edu
Chavez, George F., Department of Psychology, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ, US
Sanchez, Diana T., Department of Psychology, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ, US
Address:
Good, Jessica J., Department of Psychology, Rutgers University, 53 Avenue E, Tillett Hall, Piscataway, NJ, US, 08854-8040, goodj@eden.rutgers.edu
Source:
Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology, Vol 16(4), Oct, 2010. pp. 453-460.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
US : Educational Publishing Foundation
Other Journal Titles:
Cultural Diversity and Mental Health
Other Publishers:
US : John Wiley & Sons, Inc.
ISSN:
1099-9809 (Print)
1939-0106 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
affirmative action, multiracial, prototypicality, self-categorization
Abstract:
Multiracial individuals are in the unique position of being able to categorize themselves as members of multiple racial groups. Drawing on self-categorization theory, we suggest that similarity to the minority ingroup depends on self-perceptions of physical appearance and connectedness to the minority ingroup. Moreover, we argue that similarity to the ingroup determines self-categorization as minority, which predicts category-based entitlements such as perceived eligibility for minority resources (e.g., affirmative action). Using path analysis, we found support for this model on a convenience sample of 107 mixed-race minority–White participants. The results suggest that affective processes rather than observable characteristics such as prototypical physical appearance better predict self-categorization among mixed-race individuals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Affirmative Action; *Classification (Cognitive Process); *Interracial Offspring; *Self Concept
PsycINFO Classification:
Personality Traits & Processes (3120)
Population:
Male
Female
Location:
US
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs)
Thirties (30-39 yrs)
Middle Age (40-64 yrs)
Grant Sponsorship:
Sponsor: US Department of Education, US
Other Details: Jacob K. Javits Fellowship
Recipients: Good, Jessica J.
Methodology:
Empirical Study; Quantitative Study
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:

Release Date:
20101108
Copyright:
American Psychological Association. 2010
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1037/a0020128

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 343
Title:
South African mixed‐race children's and mothers' judgments and reasoning about children's nurturance and self‐determination rights.
Authors:
Ruck, Martin D., City University of New York, New York, NY, US, mruck@gc.cuny.edu
Tenenbaum, Harriet, Kingston University, Kingston upon Thames, England
Willenberg, Ingrid, Macquarie University, North Ryde, NSW, Australia
Address:
Ruck, Martin D., Department of Psychology, Graduate Center, City University of New York, 365 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY, US, 10016, mruck@gc.cuny.edu
Source:
Social Development, Vol 20(3), Aug, 2011. pp. 517-535.
Page Count:
19
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
ISSN:
0961-205X (Print)
1467-9507 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed race children, mothers, judgments, nurturance, self determination, children's rights, South Africa, social reasoning
Abstract:
This study examined the understanding of children’s rights in 63 (9-, 11-, and 13-year-olds) mixed-race South African children and their mothers. In individual semistructured interviews participants responded to hypothetical vignettes in which children’s nurturance and self-determination rights conflicted with parental authority in the home. Participants were required to decide whether they should support the story characters’ rights and provide justifications for their responses. Findings indicated that both children and mothers were more likely to endorse children’s nurturance than self-determination rights. In contrast to previous research, no significant differences were found between children and mothers in terms of support for either type of right. In terms of reasoning, both children’s and mothers’ responses revealed distinct patterns of thinking influenced by the type of right under consideration. The findings are discussed with reference to the available western and non-western literature on children’s understanding of rights. Limitations, implications, and directions for future research are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Human Rights; *Judgment; *Nurturance; *Reasoning; *Self Determination; Interracial Offspring; Mothers; Social Cognition
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 344
Title:
Speaking up: Mixed race identity in Black communities.
Authors:
Leverette, Tru, University of North Florida, Jacksonville, FL, US
Source:
Journal of Black Studies, Vol 39(3), Jan, 2009. pp. 434-445.
Page Count:
12
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0021-9347 (Print)
1552-4566 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Blacks, communities, racism, ethnic identity
Abstract:
Within Black communities, individuals of mixed Black/White parentage have faced diverse reactions, ranging from elevation to scorn. These reactions have often been based on the oppressions of history, the injustices of the present, and the hopes for a radically different future. This article traces the common historical responses, both positive and negative, within Black communities to mixed race identities, thereby elucidating contemporary reactions to race mixture within Black communities. In so doing, it argues that an historical understanding of these reactions as well as a recognition of the positions mixed race individuals occupy can challenge assumptions about race, difference, identity, and community—fostering new ground on which individuals can stand for common causes within heterogeneous communities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Ethnic Identity; *Racism; Communities
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)

Database:

Record: 345
Title:
'Split me in two': Gender, identity, and 'race mixing' in the Trinidad and Tobago nation.
Authors:
Reddock, Rhoda, University of the West Indies (UWI), St. Augustine, St. Augustine, Trinidad and Tobago
Source:
Global mixed race. King-O'Riain, Rebecca C. (Ed); Small, Stephen (Ed); Mahtani, Minelle (Ed); Song, Miri (Ed); Spickard, Paul (Ed); pp. 44-67; New York, NY, US: New York University Press; 2014. xxii, 335 pp.
Page Count:
24
ISBN:
978-0-8147-7073-3 (Hardcover)
978-0-8147-8915-5 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
gender differences, cultural identity, race-mixing, citizenship, colonial power, globalization
Abstract:
This chapter discusses gender, identity, and "race mixing" in the Trinidad and Tobago nation. The tension between these two strands of identity formation has been central to notions of citizenship in Trinidad and Tobago, although it is not normally discussed in these terms. Interestingly, purist notions of Africanness are also incompatible with the hegemonic hybrid national identity. Still today many people have difficulty in identifying themselves as African—a source of constant disappointment to Afrocentric groups and individuals. The public creole mainstream, therefore, is perceived as a hybrid space, a place where prior "pure" identities become mixed. But it is also a place, possibly due to its identification with "Blackness," which is seen as impure, vulgar, immoral, sexual, and masculine. The author clearly demonstrates in this chapter that the situation of mixed-race people today in various countries has a great deal to do with the dominant colonial influence. While various nations share common features, they also demonstrate unique trajectories and configurations of mixedness, depending, for example, on the former colonial power and the cultural heritage of those who trace their lineage to it. This is evident even within the circum-Caribbean region, as can be seen from the chapter in this book on Mexico. Contemporary forces of globalization are currently stirring up the cultural categories to a significant degree, but it does not override them. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Human Sex Differences; *Interethnic Family; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Citizenship; Globalization
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
Trinidad and Tobago
Intended Audience:
Psychology: Professional & Research (PS)
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Book; Edited Book
Document Type:
Chapter
Release Date:
20140929
Accession Number:
2014-20689-003

https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2014-20689-003&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2014-20689-003&site=ehost-live&scope=site">'Split me in two': Gender, identity, and 'race mixing' in the Trinidad and Tobago nation.</A>

Record: 346
Title:
Status, participation, and influence in task groups.
Authors:
Walker, Lisa Slattery, University of North Carolina, Charlotte, NC, US, lisa.walker@uncc.edu
Doerer, Sharon C., Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association–College Retirement Equities Fund, Charlotte, NC, US
Webster, Murray Jr., University of North Carolina, Charlotte, NC, US
Address:
Walker, Lisa Slattery, Department of Sociology, University of North Carolina, Charlotte, 9201 University City Blvd., Charlotte, NC, US, 28223, lisa.walker@uncc.edu
Source:
Sociological Perspectives, Vol 57(3), Sep, 2014. pp. 364-381.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Other Journal Titles:
Pacific Sociological Review
Other Publishers:
US : University of California Press
ISSN:
0731-1214 (Print)
1533-8673 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race, status, influence, participation, small groups
Abstract:
Status generalization theories describe how society’s status advantages and disadvantages can structure group inequality and also can suggest ways to design interventions to overcome its undesirable effects. We address problems of interaction as affected by the status characteristic race, which often disadvantages black members of work teams. Following the lead of Goar and Sell, we devised mixed-race task groups of women aimed at equalizing influence over the groups’ decisions. In baseline groups, white women exerted greater influence than did black women. In experimental groups, we artificially increased the participation of black women, and thereby increased their influence over group decisions. We consider some implications for diversity in natural settings including business organizations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Group Participation; *Interpersonal Influences; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Status; Blacks; Group Structure

Title:
Stone age crisis: A psychiatric appraisal.
Authors:

Keywords:

Abstract:
Describes the profound social and psychological effects of Western patterns-technology, education, detribalization, migration, urbanization, and cash economy-on the people of Papua New Guinea. Cargo cults, suicide, "running amok," the status of mixed-race persons, and problems of therapy and diagnosis among nonliterate people are discussed. Record: 348
Title:
Stories of race and sex in the Andes.
Authors:
Paulson, Susan, Miami U, Oxford, OH, US
Source:
Sexualities, Vol 6(3-4), Nov, 2003. Special Issue: Re-presenting sexualities in the media. pp. 497-500.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Reviewed Item:
Weismantel, Mary. (2001) Cholas and Pishtacos. Stories of Race and Sex in the Andes Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2001. 326 pp., $22.50 0-226-89154-2.
ISSN:
1363-4607 (Print)
1461-7382 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race, sex, Andes, social structure, cholas, pishtacos
Abstract:
In this provocative book Mary Weismantel explores experiences, practices and social structures of race and sex in the Andes through stories generated around two contradictory characters, cultural icons that thrive on tensions between fantasy and reality. Images of mixed race cholas arouse in white men both desire and disgust for women who difference makes them exciting and whose racial and sexual subordination makes them available. Stories of horrifying white bogeymen called pishtacos frighten poor Indians and women, and evoke their own vulnerability to the predations of the powerful. Weismantel argues that the cultural icons of the sensual brown woman called chola and the aggressively penetrating white man known as pishtaco are not innocent fantasies, for they arouse the violent passions of societies fractured by race and sex, and divided by vast economic inequalities. In a book that is not about gays or lesbians per se, Weismantel helps to queer Andean studies by questioning heteronormative assumptions that often frame discussions of rape, body and identity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Race (Anthropological); *Sexuality; *Social Structure
PsycINFO Classification:

Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2003-10526-018&site=ehost-live&scope=site">Stories of race and sex in the Andes.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 349
Title:
Strategies and Counselor Competencies in Counseling Multiracial Students.
Authors:
Kenney, Kelley, Kutztown University, Kutztown, PA, US
Source:
Special populations in college counseling: A handbook for mental health professionals. Lippincott, Joseph A. (Ed); Lippincott, Ruth B. (Ed); pp. 77-88; Alexandria, VA, US: American Counseling Association; 2007. xviii, 320 pp.
Page Count:
12
ISBN:
1-55620-258-X (Paperback)
978-1-55620-258-2 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
strategies, counselor competencies, counseling, multiracial students, racial backgrounds, mixed-race heritage, interracial unions, racial categories, college
Abstract:
This chapter discusses multiracial college students, defined as students whose biological parents are of two or more different racial backgrounds or heritages (Root, 1992). The repeal of laws in the United States that opposed mixed-race coupling or marriages, brought about by the Loving et ux. v. Virginia (1967) Supreme Court decision, has resulted in a dramatic increase in interracial unions. Subsequently, there has also been a dramatic increase in the births of persons of mixed-race heritage. For the first time in its history, the 2000 Census provided persons of mixed-race heritages and backgrounds with the opportunity to describe how they identify racially by selecting more than one racial category (Root & Kelley, 2003). According to data from the 2000 Census, 6.8 million people were identified as being of more than one racial category, or multiracial (Jones & Smith, 2001). The multiracial population is young. Jones and Smith (2003) indicated that approximately 42% of the population is under 18 years of age and close to 70% is under 35 years of age. At the time of the 2000 Census, only 5.4% of the multiracial population was between the ages of 18 and 20; however, a dramatic increase is expected in the near future. Although all children do not aspire to attend college, these figures suggest that the number of multiracial individuals who will be attending college could also show a dramatic increase (Paladino, 2004). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Interracial Marriage; *Interracial Offspring; *Professional Competence; *Multiculturalism; College Students; Race (Anthropological); School Counseling; School Counselors; Strategies

Record: 350
Title:
Supervision and racial issues.
Parent Book Series:
Counselling supervision
Authors:
Grant, Patricia, U Greenwich, Greenwich, England
Source:
Counselling supervision in context. Carroll, Michael (Ed); Holloway, Elizabeth (Ed); pp. 7-22; Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications Ltd; 1999. ix, 206 pp.
Page Count:
16
ISBN:
0-7619-5788-X (Hardcover)
0-7619-5789-8 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial issues & dilemmas in counseling supervision
Abstract:
In this chapter the concept of race, in the context of counselling supervision, is explored. There is a discussion of the need for supervisors to consider racial issues and to recognize specific racial dilemmas emerging in supervision. Three case studies (two Black women and a mixed-race British woman with an Asian mother and a Black father) are presented to address these issues. Suggestions are made on how supervisors can best be prepared to work with racial issues in supervision. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (create)

Record: 351
Title:
Surveying the intersection: Pathology, secrecy, and the discourses of racial and sexual identity.
Authors:
Diggs, Marylynne, U Oregon, Eugene, US
Source:
Journal of Homosexuality, Vol 26(2-3), 1993. Special Issue: Critical essays: Gay and lesbian writers of color. pp. 1-19.
Page Count:
19
Publisher:
US : Haworth Press
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0091-8369 (Print)
1540-3602 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
risk of metaphorical imperialism in literature containing representations of gay & lesbian & other sexual & racial identities
Abstract:
Cautions against the risks of metaphorical imperialism in readings of codified gay and lesbian representation. The author disagrees with M. Foucault's (1978) view that the secret of the 19th century was the secret of sex, and suggests that, in 19th-century American culture, where African-American identity and equality were among the most controversial issues, the secrets of identity were also secrets of race. Because scientific and literary representations of pathological and/or secret essential identities are sites of intersection in the discourses of homosexual and mixed-race identity, they should be investigated as intersections, rather than read as codifications of sexual difference. A survey of the discourses of scientific racism, genetics, and eugenics suggests that F. E. Harper's (1892 [1987]) representation of the mulatto leader can be read as an act of resistance to the representation of the mulatto as a degenerate, hybrid species. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Lesbianism; *Literature; *Male Homosexuality; *Race (Anthropological)
PsycINFO Classification:
Literature & Fine Arts (2610)
Sexual Behavior & Sexual Orientation (2980)
Population:
Human

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1300/J082v26n02_01

1994-20840-001
