Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 352
Title:
Teachers and learners: Roles adopted in interracial discussions.
Authors:
Tatum, Travis Jonathan Daniel, U Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US, travist@umich.edu
Sekaquaptewa, Denise, U Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Address:
Tatum, Travis Jonathan Daniel, Department of Psychology, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US, 48109-1109, travist@umich.edu
Source:
Group Processes & Intergroup Relations, Vol 12(5), Sep, 2009. pp. 579-590.
Page Count:
12
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
1368-4302 (Print)
1461-7188 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
teacher role, learner role, interracial discussions, stereotypes, prejudice, racial differences, communication roles, Whites, Blacks
Abstract:
Whites are stereotyped as ignorant of race issues, and African Americans as race experts. Therefore they may respond differently when discussing race. We examined whether Whites and African Americans adopt ‘teacher’ versus ‘learner’ roles when discussing race-relevant versus race-irrelevant topics in mixed-race versus same-race groups. Furthermore, we tested whether concern about appearing prejudiced and prior knowledge of the topic predicted role adopted. Results confirmed that African Americans adopted a ‘teacher’ role whereas Whites adopted a ‘learner’ role during interracial discussions about race. Assuming a teacher role predicted greater willingness to engage in future interracial discussions about race; but Whites, who were concerned about appearing prejudiced when talking about race, were less likely to adopt a teacher role than African Americans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Communication; *Group Dynamics; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Role Taking; *Stereotyped Attitudes; Blacks; Conversation; Prejudice; Teachers; Whites

Group & Interpersonal Processes (3020)
Culture & Ethnology (2930)

Record: 353
Title:
Tematiche identitarie nella psicoterapia di un adolescente di razza mista adottato.
Translated Title:
Identification's themes in an adopted mixed-race adolescent's psychotherapy.
Authors:
Rustin, Margaret, Tavistock Clinic, London, United Kingdom
Address:
Rustin, Margaret, Child and Family Department, Tavistock Centre, 120 Belsize Lane, London, United Kingdom, NW3 5BA
Source:
Richard e Piggle, Vol 14(3), Sep-Dec, 2006. pp. 239-257.
Page Count:
19
Publisher:
Italy : Pensiero Scientifico
ISSN:
1121-9602 (Print)
Language:
Italian
Keywords:
identifications themes, adolescent psychotherapy, adopted adolescents, birth families, adoptive families
Abstract:
This paper describes elements of three years of once - weekly psychotherapy with a young man who had had therapy as a child. The normal developmental tasks of the later teenage years often appear overwhelmingly daunting to adopted adolescents, who must deal with an inner world peopled both by birth and adoptive families. Painful feelings of early loss are revived and intensified confusion and dissonance can predominate in the face of the necessity for separation. It is suggested that late adolescence is a particularly fruitful time for work on the fundamentals of who one is. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

PsycINFO
Record: 354
Title:
Test of time: Children who wait (1973) by Jane Rowe and Lydia Lambert.
Authors:
Barratt, Sara, Tavistock and Portman NHS Trust, London, United Kingdom, SBarratt@tavi-port.nhs.uk
Address:
Barratt, Sara, Fostering, Adoption and Kinship care Team, Tavistock and Portman NHS Trust, 120 Belsize Lane, London, United Kingdom, NW3 5BA, SBarratt@tavi-port.nhs.uk
Source:
Clinical Child Psychology and Psychiatry, Vol 15(4), Oct, 2010. pp. 627-631.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
1359-1045 (Print)
1461-7021 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
permanent families, child care, foster care, child adoption, siblings, social work, waiting, residential care
Abstract:
Children Who Wait is the report of a study that was commissioned by the Association of British Adoption Agencies following concerns about the number of children in local authority care waiting for permanent families. The study sought to understand the reasons why so many children in local authority care were waiting for permanent families. Their study was concerned only with children in long-term care under the age of 11 and living apart from their parents. At the time of the study there was a cultural adjustment to the diminishing numbers of babies available for adoption. The study indicates that a larger proportion of children in residential care had parents who objected to foster care. One of the factors which determined a decision for children to remain in foster or residential care was the difficulty in placing sibling groups, children from "black" or "mixed race" families, and the view that, through adoption, children should lose all contact with their biological families. The authors also described the effect of changes of social worker on children, saying that 80% of the children had a change of social worker within a two-year period. Social work needs to be more valued and have the resources needed to draw on existing knowledge to ensure that they are able to meet the needs of children who are waiting for them to act. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Adoption (Child); *Child Care; *Child Welfare; *Foster Care; *Residential Care Institutions; Family; Siblings; Social Casework

Record: 355
Title:
Testing the genetic hypothesis of group mean IQ differences in South Africa: Racial admixture and cross-situational consistency.
Authors:
Rushton, J. Philippe, Department of Psychology, University of Western Ontario, London, ON, Canada, rushton@uwo.ca
Address:
Rushton, J. Philippe, Department of Psychology, University of Western Ontario, London, ON, Canada, N6A 5C2, rushton@uwo.ca
Source:
Personality and Individual Differences, Vol 44(3), Feb, 2008. pp. 768-776.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0191-8869 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
intelligence, IQ differences, interracial individuals, genetic hypothesis
Abstract:
Two predictions from the hereditarian model of group mean IQ differences are tested on a total sample of 1556 first-year university students in post-apartheid South Africa. The first prediction is that people of Mixed-Race average between the two parental populations. The second prediction is that the pattern of group means remains consistent over time and place. Data collated on South African university students given the Raven's Standard and Advanced Progressive Matrices confirm the predictions. Combining the results for both versions of the test showed the rank order of group IQ means is East Asians, Whites, South Asians, Coloreds, and Blacks (IQs = 116, 113, 106, 103, and 98, respectively; Ns = 23, 398, 212, 36, and 887). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Genetics; *Intelligence; *Intelligence Quotient; *Interracial Offspring; *Racial and Ethnic Differences

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 356
Title:
The assessment of tobacco dependence in young users of smokeless tobacco.
Authors:
DiFranza, Joseph R., Department of Family Medicine and Community Health, University of Massachusetts Medical School, Worcester, MA, US, difranzj@ummhc.org
Sweet, Michael, Newsome High School, Lithia, FL, US
Savageau, Judith A., Department of Family Medicine and Community Health, University of Massachusetts Medical School, Worcester, MA, US
Sanouri Ursprung, W. W., Department of Family Medicine and Community Health, University of Massachusetts Medical School, Worcester, MA, US
Address:
DiFranza, Joseph R., Department of Family Medicine and Community Health, University of Massachusetts Medical School, 55 Lake Avenue North, Worcester, MA, US, 01655, difranzj@ummhc.org
Source:
Tobacco Control: An International Journal, Vol 21(5), Sep, 2012. pp. 471-476.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
United Kingdom : BMJ Publishing Group
ISSN:
0964-4563 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
tobacco dependence, smokeless tobacco, Hooked on Nicotine Checklist, Autonomy Over Smoking Scale, test reliability, test validity, psychometrics
Abstract:
Introduction: As all published measures of dependence for users of smokeless tobacco (dippers) have poor reliability, in the present work the Hooked on Nicotine Checklist (HONC) and the Autonomy Over Smoking Scale (AUTOS) were evaluated for use with this population. Dippers and smokers were also compared in relation to dependence, the pleasure derived from using tobacco and the latency to the onset of withdrawal. Methods: In 2010, an anonymous self-completed paper survey was administered to 1541 students of mixed race and ethnicity in grades 9-12 (mean age 15.9 years) in a Florida high school where students used cigarettes and smokeless tobacco. Results: The reliability (Cronbach’s α) for the HONC was 0.90 for smokers (n = 139) and 0.91 for dippers (n = 85), and for the AUTOS was 0.94 for smokers and dippers. Dippers and smokers did not differ significantly in relation to scores on the HONC, AUTOS, latency to withdrawal onset or pleasure derived from smoking. One or more symptoms on the HONC were reported by 56% of dippers and 57% of smokers with <100 lifetime uses of their favoured tobacco product, and by 91% of dippers and 91% of smokers with ≥100 lifetime uses (not significant). Greater lifetime use was associated with a significantly shorter latency to withdrawal for smokers and dippers. Conclusions: The HONC and AUTOS are highly reliable measures of dependence for adolescent users of cigarettes and smokeless tobacco. Using these measures and other indicators, no meaningful differences in dependence were found between dippers and smokers at comparable levels of lifetime use. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Drug Dependency; *Measurement; *Nicotine; *Psychometrics; *Smokeless Tobacco; Test Reliability; Test Validity

Record: 357
Title:
The best of both worlds? Family influences on mixed race youth identity development.
Authors:
Crawford, Susan E., Halton Multicultural Council, Oakville, ON, Canada, scrawford@halton-multicultural.org
Alaggia, Ramona, Faculty of Social Work, University of Toronto, Toronto, ON, Canada, ramona.alaggia@utoronto.ca
Address:
Crawford, Susan E., Halton Multicultural Council, 635 Fourth Line, Unit 48, Oakville, ON, Canada, L6L 5W4, scrawford@halton-multicultural.org
Source:
Qualitative Social Work: Research and Practice, Vol 7(1), Mar, 2008. pp. 81-98.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
1473-3250 (Print)
1741-3117 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
family influences, mixed race, youth identity development, young adults
Abstract:
This study explored influences on racial identity of mixed race youth who identified themselves to be part of mixed African (Black) and European (White) origin. Research questions emerged following a review of the literature identifying the ways in which views of self, family, peers and society impact youth and their racial identification. Eight in-depth interviews employing the Long Interview Method were conducted, transcribed and coded to determine themes. Family influences emerged as playing a significant role in biracial identity formation. Three major themes were identified: (1) level of parental awareness and understanding of race issues; (2) impact of family structure; and (3) communication and willingness to talk about race issues. Implications for researchers and social work practitioners working with this population are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Title:
The biracial bind: An identity dilemma.
Authors:
Hart-Webb, Diane, Metro-West Medical Ctr, Natick, MA, US
Source:
Diversity in college settings: Directives for helping professionals. Jenkins, Yvonne M. (Ed); pp. 117-127; Florence, KY, US: Taylor & Frances/Routledge; 1999. xvi, 260 pp.
Page Count:
11
ISBN:
0-415-91305-5 (Hardcover)
0-415-91306-3 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed race identity issues & developmental conflicts, 25-yr-old male college student of Black & White heritage in therapy at university counseling center
Abstract:
Ryan was a 25-yr-old single biracial (Black and White) man in college, who presented, self-referred, at a university counseling center. This was his first encounter with therapy. The case study of Ryan poignantly illustrates how mixed race identity issues can both affect and complicate developmental conflicts. It also illustrates how racial identity provides a frame of reference or "language" for the client as he struggles to describe his presenting problem, the history of the problem, and to interpret traumatic life events. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 359
Title:
The case of Carla: Dilemmas of helping all students to understand science.
Authors:
Kurth, Lori A., American Association for the Advancement of Science, Project 2061, Washington, DC, US
Anderson, Charles W., Michigan State U, Coll of Education, Dept of Teacher Education, East Lansing, MI, US
Palincsar, Annemarie S., U Michigan, School of Education, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Address:
Anderson, Charles W., andya@msu.edu
Source:
Science Education, Vol 86(3), May, 2002. pp. 287-313.
Page Count:
27
Publisher:
US : John Wiley & Sons
ISSN:
0036-8326 (Print)
1098-237X (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
dilemmas of helping, science education, collaboration, small groups, sixth-grade students, intersubjective communication, colored solutions, race, class
Abstract:
This paper tells the story of 4 sixth-grade students, of mixed race and social class, who worked together in a small group and experimented with colored solutions of different densities. In spite of common interests, they often failed to achieve intersubjective communication about the colored solutions or about the process of planning and making a poster to report their findings. The authors explain this using the concepts of polysemy, privileging, and holding the floor. In particular, Carla (an African American girl) was unable to hold the floor within the group, so her opportunities for science learning were diminished. The four students were not overtly prejudiced in their speech or actions. Yet the expectations they brought with them led them to reconstruct among themselves some of the most troubling inequities of our society as a whole. This story is about important connections. In particular it is about how the actions of children are connected to the histories of their families, and how the privileging of ideas is connected to that of people, and how the practice of science is connected to that of discrimination. Science education reformers may underestimate the difficulty of separating conceptual conflict about ideas from interpersonal conflict about privilege and status. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Color; *Cooperation; *Group Problem Solving; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Science Education; Elementary School Students; Interpersonal Communication; Social Class
PsycINFO Classification:
Classroom Dynamics & Student Adjustment & Attitudes (3560)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 360
Title:
The collection of race-based data in the USA: A call for radical change.
Authors:
Aspinall, Peter, Centre for Health Services Studies, University of Kent, Kent, United Kingdom, P.J.Aspinall@kent.ac.uk
Address:
Aspinall, Peter, Centre for Health Services Studies, University of Kent, George Allen Wing, Canterbury, Kent, United Kingdom, CT5 7NF, P.J.Aspinall@kent.ac.uk
Source:
Ethnic and Racial Studies, Vol 37(10), Aug, 2014. pp. 1839-1846.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0141-9870 (Print)
1466-4356 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
census, race, mixed-race, national origins, colour line, nativity line
Abstract:
Two important new books by Greg Carter and Kenneth Prewitt provide detailed historical perspectives on how understandings of race and race categories have evolved since the founding of the republic. Prewitt focuses on an analysis of racial classification in the US census—the so-called ‘statistical races’ –and its changing role in US policy, culminating in recommendations for radical change. Carter takes as his theme population mixing across the races, offering a positive, even celebratory, but little known account of the moments and movements that have praised mixing. As pressures mount on the ‘statistical races’ in the late twentieth century, Prewitt uses the political space opened up by these debates to offer fundamental changes to US methods of ethno-racial data collection, including the removal of these questions from the census. The jury is in recess for further deliberations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Culture Change; *Racism; Books; History; Indigenous Populations
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Location:
US
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Publication History:
Accepted: Jun 4, 2014; First Submitted: Dec 14, 2013
Release Date:
20150914
Copyright:
Taylor & Francis. 2014
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1080/01419870.2014.932407
Accession Number:
2014-34657-025
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2014-34657-025&site=ehost-live&scope=site

PsycINFO
Record: 361
Title:
The complications of fathering in Southern Africa: Separation, uncertainty, and multiple responsibilities.
Authors:
Townsend, Nicholas W., Department of Anthropology, Brown University, Providence, RI, US
Source:
Fathers in cultural context. Shwalb, David W. (Ed); Shwalb, Barbara J. (Ed); Lamb, Michael E. (Ed); pp. 173-200; New York, NY, US: Routledge/Taylor & Francis Group; 2013. xxii, 419 pp.
Page Count:
28
ISBN:
978-1-84872-948-3 (Paperback)
978-1-84872-947-6 (Hardcover)
978-0-203-81600-4 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Southern African cultures, social policy, fathering, financial support, gendered division of labor, collective fatherhood, socioeconomic conditions
Abstract:
In this chapter "Southern Africa" is restricted to South Africa, Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland. South Africa has 90% of this region's population; the other three countries are incorporated into the South African economy by their overwhelming dependence on bilateral trade and by longstanding patterns of labor migration. This chapter does not consider fathering among the original foraging or hunter-gathering population, who were by the time of European settlement restricted to areas too dry for cattle-herding or cultivation. Nor is it much concerned with fathering among the white population, for whom aspirations and institutional arrangements concerning family life are relatively similar to those in Western Europe and North America. This chapter focuses on the behavioral patterns and problems of fathering among the 45 million black Africans who make up 81% of the population of the region. Unless otherwise specified, references to men, women, families, and population are restricted to black Africans. South Africa's population is 9% white and 11% "other" (mostly "coloured" or mixed race, or of South Asian ancestry), and the percentage of the population that is black in Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland are 97%, 99%, and 97%, respectively. The national population of South Africa is 49 million; of Botswana and Lesotho it is 2 million each; and of Swaziland it is 1.35 million. In the regional map, the names of ethnic groups are indications of the areas of their greatest concentration; all the peoples of the region are now widely distributed. Southern African cultures include important roles for men in the lives of children even though the care of young children is seen as women's responsibility within a gendered division of labor and social activity. In a system of distributed or collective fatherhood, the father is one of several men expected to contribute to a child's well-being and fathers are expected to play a role in the lives of children other than their own offspring. More than a century of white domination, labor migration, and racial segregation have separated families. Social policy and cultural attitudes increasingly emphasize financial support as the central aspect of adequate fathering, but massive unemployment and economic inequality make it impossible for many fathers to provide financial support to their children. Families and governments must acknowledge and encourage the many non-financial ways that men can contribute to the lives of children. This chapter includes the following elements: 1) A case story of a specific father(s); 2) Cultural and historical influences on fathering; 3) Comprehensive review of fathering research in the target culture(s) or region; 4) Social policy issues related to fathering; 5) Sub-cultural variations in fathering; 6) Contemporary social/economic conditions that affect fathering; 7) Speculation, predictions for the future, and comparisons with fathers in other societies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*African Cultural Groups; *Cross Cultural Differences; *Division of Labor; *Fathers; Childhood Development; Collectivism; Family Socioeconomic Level; Financial Strain; Government Policy Making; Income (Economic)
PsycINFO Classification:
Childrearing & Child Care (2956)
Population:
Human
Male
Location:
Botswana; Lesotho; South Africa; Swaziland
Intended Audience:
Psychology: Professional & Research (PS)
Methodology:

Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Book; Edited Book
Document Type:
Chapter
Release Date:
20121231

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2012-25940-008&site=ehost-live&scope=site

<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2012-25940-008&site=ehost-live&scope=site">The complications of fathering in Southern Africa: Separation, uncertainty, and multiple responsibilities.</A>

Record: 362
Title:
The conceptualisation and categorisation of mixed race/ethnicity in Britain and North America: Identity options and the role of the state.
Authors:
Aspinall, P. J., Centre for Health Services Studies, George Allen Wing University of Kent at Canterbury, Canterbury, England, P.J.Aspinall@ukc.ac.uk
Address:
Aspinall, P. J., Centre for Health Service Studies, George Allen Wing University of Kent at Canterbury, Canterbury, England, CT2 7NF, P.J.Aspinall@ukc.ac.uk
Source:
International Journal of Intercultural Relations, Vol 27(3), May, 2003. pp. 269-296.
Page Count:
28
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0147-1767 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed race, mixed ethnicity, mixed heritage, identity options, classification, categorization, conceptualization, government
Abstract:
Estimates of around 1.7-2.4% of the population in the USA, 2% in Canada, and 0.6% in Britain now self-identify as mixed race. Inter-ethnic unions comprise around 2.7% of all unions in the USA and 1.3% in Britain and are increasing. The impact of these changes on the ethnic/racial diversity of Britain and North America and the demand from persons of mixed race to describe their 'full' identity requires a response from government and Census agencies that classify the population by race/ethnicity. Research show that the self-understandings of persons of mixed race may incorporate a range of identities, some biracial and others a single group like 'black', although the options available in the USA may still be limited by the legacy of the hypodescent policy. The solutions offered by classifications in the 2000/2001 round of censuses include a subdivided 'mixed' category in England and Wales and provision to select one or more categories in the USA. This marks an end to the official conceptualisation of 'pure' races that has been so pervasive in the past and, for the first time, offers mixed race identity to those of mixed heritage. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Government; *Race (Anthropological); Interracial Offspring
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
Great Britain; North America
Format Covered:
Print

Document Type:

Release Date:
20040816

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1016/S0147-1767(03)00012-9

Record: 363
Title:
The construct validity of the Griffiths Scales of Mental Development.
Authors:
Luiz, D. M., U Port Elizabeth, Dept of Psychology, Port Elizabeth, South Africa
Foxcroft, C. D., U Port Elizabeth, Dept of Psychology, Port Elizabeth, South Africa
Stewart, R., U Port Elizabet, Dept of Psychology, Port Elizabeth, South Africa
Address:
Luiz, D. M., U Port, Dept of Psychology, PO Box 1600, 6000, Port Elizabeth, South Africa
Source:
Child: Care, Health and Development, Vol 27(1), Jan, 2001. pp. 73-83.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0305-1862 (Print)
1365-2214 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Griffiths Scales of Mental Development, construct validity, common factor analysis, White, Black, mixed race, Asian
Abstract:
The aim of this study was to contribute to knowledge of the construct validity of the Griffiths Scales of Mental Development (Griffiths Scales) through an examination of the underlying dimensions tapped by the six subscales, using Common Factor Analysis. A sample of 430 South African children (aged 54-83 mo), from four ethnic groups (i.e. White, Mixed Race, Asian and Black) participated. The correlation coefficients obtained for the South African groups were compared to those Griffiths obtained in her work with the British standardization sample of the Griffiths Scales. The pattern of correlation for South African and British subjects was found to be similar. This suggests that the Scales are measuring a construct which is consistent across cultures and through time. A factor analysis was performed with the data for each South African ethnic group separately and the factor solutions were compared to determine whether the Griffiths Scales measure similar or different constructs for the groups. The results indicate that the Griffiths Scales tend to measure one factor, and including only common variables, the factor appears to be similar cross-culturally. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cognitive Development; *Factor Analysis; *Scaling (Testing); *Statistical Validity; *Test Validity; Developmental Measures; Racial and Ethnic Differences

Record: 364
Title:
The curious career of the one-drop rule: Multiraciality and membership in Germany today.
Authors:
Nandi, Miriam, University of Freiburg, Freiburg, Germany
Spickard, Paul, University of California, Santa Barbara, Santa Barbara, CA, US
Source:
Global mixed race. King-O'Riain, Rebecca C. (Ed); Small, Stephen (Ed); Mahtani, Minelle (Ed); Song, Miri (Ed); Spickard, Paul (Ed); pp. 188-212; New York, NY, US: New York University Press; 2014. xxii, 335 pp.
Page Count:
25
ISBN:
978-0-8147-7073-3 (Hardcover)
978-0-8147-8915-5 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multiraciality, membership, racial differences, racism
Abstract:
This chapter discusses multiraciality and membership in Germany. The authors have tried to lay out the background for thinking about race and mixed race in Germany. Race in Germany is a tricky business, and so is racial mixedness. For many Germans, perhaps, guilt and shame about race are almost as disabling as straightforward racism. Perhaps the fear of being labeled "racist" prevents White Germans from actually confronting their own racism and coming to terms with it. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Interethnic Family; *Membership; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Racism; *Multiculturalism; Ingroup Outgroup

Record: 365
Title:
The development of fair-play standards in same-race and mixed-race situations.
Authors:
Graziano, William G., U Georgia, Athens
Musser, Lynn M.
Rosen, Sidney
Shaffer, David R.
Source:
Child Development, Vol 53(4), Aug, 1982. pp. 938-947.
Page Count:
10
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Journal Titles:
Child Development: Abstracts & Bibliography
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0009-3920 (Print)
1467-8624 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
reward allocation to Black vs White vs mixed dyads, Black vs White 1st vs 3rd graders, 4-yr followup
Abstract:
Conducted 3 convergent studies to investigate the hypothesis that task-irrelevant status attributes of peers influence judgment of deservingness more for younger than for older children. In Study 1, 112 Black and White 1st and 3rd graders allocated rewards to peer pairs whose members were either both Black or both White. Allocations of 1st graders were more influenced by the player's race than were the 3rd graders'. In Study 2, 144 Black and White 1st and 3rd graders made allocations to pairs in which one partner was Black and the other White. Relative size and task performance were also varied. Player's race did not influence allocations, but relative size did. In Study 3, 68 Ss who had been 1st-grade Ss in Studies 1 or 2 were reassessed 4 yrs later. Also, 77 new 5th graders served as Ss. Allocations of younger Ss and of Ss who had been held back in elementary school were less task-based than those of older and promoted Ss. Results are discussed in terms of children's cognitive capacities, equity theory, status generalization, and the development of fair-play standards. (38 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Dyads; *Equity (Payment); *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Whites; Age Differences; Followup Studies
PsycINFO Classification:
Psychosocial & Personality Development (2840)
Population:

Age Group:

School Age (6-12 yrs)

Record: 366
Title:
The Effects of Defendant Race, Victim Race, and Juror Gender on Evidence Processing in a Murder Trial.
Authors:
ForsterLee, Robert, Central Queensland University, School of Psychology and Sociology, North Rockhampton, QLD, Australia, r.forsterlee@cqu.edu.au
ForsterLee, Lynne, Central Queensland University, North Rockhampton, QLD, Australia
Horowitz, Irwin A., Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR, US
King, Ellen, Central Queensland University, North Rockhampton, QLD, Australia
Address:
ForsterLee, Robert, Central Queensland University, School of Psychology and Sociology, Bruce Highway, North Rockhampton, QLD, Australia, 4702, r.forsterlee@cqu.edu.au
Source:
Behavioral Sciences & the Law, Vol 24(2), 2006. pp. 179-198.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
US : John Wiley & Sons
ISSN:
0735-3936 (Print)
1099-0798 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
defendant race, victim race, juror gender, evidence processing, murder trial
Abstract:
The effects of defendant race, victim race, and juror gender on sentencing and information processing were examined within the context of a murder trial. A sample consisting of 96, jury eligible White Australians read one of four versions of a real trial transcript, in which the race of a male defendant and female victim were varied. The participants imposed the severest sentences on the Indigenous (Black) defendant. Jurors were most lenient with White defendants who killed a White victim. Female jurors were more punitive than the males toward the Indigenous defendant. Jurors processed evidence systematically in same-race trials, but used both systematic and heuristic processing in mixed-race trials. In these instances, female jurors employed significantly more emotive responses, especially when the victim was Black. The effects of subtle racism and the black processing effect when the victim was non-White are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adjudication; *Homicide; *Human Sex Differences; *Legal Evidence; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Crime Victims; Criminals; Defendants; Juries
PsycINFO Classification:
Criminal Law & Adjudication (4230)

Record: 367
Title:
The effects of proportional representation on intragroup behavior in mixed-race decision-making groups.
Authors:
Li, Ji, Hong Kong Baptist U, School of Business, Hong Kong
Karakowsky, Leonard
Siegel, Jacob P.
Source:
Small Group Research, Vol 30(3), Jun, 1999. pp. 259-279.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Other Journal Titles:
Small Group Behavior
ISSN:
1046-4964 (Print)
1552-8278 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
proportional representation, intragroup decision making, Asian Ss in Asian vs Asian-Caucasion vs Caucasion-dominated groups
Abstract:
Drawing on Kanter's (1977) observations and assertions, this study employs a structural approach to examine the influence of group racial composition on the behavior of group members. To be specific, this study assesses the effects of proportional representation on the behavior of 90 Asian group members who were assigned to one of three types of groups: all-Asian groups, Asian-Caucasian balanced groups, and Caucasian-dominated groups. Groups were assigned the task of discussing and generating a solution for a managerial case scenario. The discussions were videotaped and viewed by independent judges who evaluated patterns of intragroup behavior including levels of participation and leadership behavior among group members. The findings suggest that proportional representation can act as a significant source of influence on behavior of group members. We conclude this article with a discussion of the implications of these findings from both a practical and theoretical perspective. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Asians; *Group Decision Making; *Group Dynamics; *Racial and Ethnic Differences
PsycINFO Classification:
Group & Interpersonal Processes (3020)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Methodology:

Print

Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:

19990701

1999-05286-001

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=1999-05286-001&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Cut and Paste:
<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=1999-05286-001&site=ehost-live&scope=site">The effects of proportional representation on intragroup behavior in mixed-race decision-making groups.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 368
Title:
The effects of race on observer judgments of nonverbal communications.
Authors:
Forgas, Joseph P., U New South Wales, School of Psychology, Kensington, Australia
Brown, L. B.
Source:
The Journal of Social Psychology, Vol 104(2), Apr, 1978. pp. 243-251.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
US : Heldref Publications
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0022-4545 (Print)
1940-1183 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
White vs Black males as individual stimulus vs mixed-race vs mixed-sex vs same-race vs same-sex dyads as stimulus, judgment of nonverbal communication
Abstract:
Studied the effects of race on observer judgments of nonverbal communications (NVC) with the use of 2 sets of stimulus slides, showing (a) White or Black males individually and (b) same race (White) or mixed race (Black male, White female) interacting couples. For both sets of stimuli, 2 levels of nonverbal behavior were programmed, a "neutral" stance and a "positive," or in the case of couples, an "intimate" stance. The stimuli were presented to a 60-student sample and judgments were recorded on a set of 6 bipolar scales. Multivariate ANOVAs indicated that while NVC effects were highly significant for both sets of stimuli, race effects were only significant on evaluative scales, and this effect could be wholly attributed to an interaction of race and NVC cues. Thus, for individual stimulus persons, the effects of positive NVC are relatively attenuated for Black models, and for couples the effects of nonverbal intimacy are more accentuated for mixed-race couples. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Dyads; *Judgment; *Nonverbal Communication; *Social Influences
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Perception & Cognition (3040)
Population:
Human
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
19790601

20090907

Record: 369
Title:
The epidemiology of drinking among women of child-bearing age.
Authors:
Caetano, Raul, University of Texas School of Public Health at Houston, Houston,, TX, US, Raul.Caetano@UTSouthwestern.edu
Ramisetty-Mikler, Suhasini, University of Texas School of Public Health at Houston, Houston,, TX, US
Floyd, Louise R., National Center on Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities, Center for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, GA, US
McGrath, Christine, University of Texas School of Public Health at Houston, Houston,, TX, US
Address:
Caetano, Raul, 6011 Harry Hines Blvd. Room V8.112, Dallas, TX, US, 75390-9128, Raul.Caetano@UTSouthwestern.edu
Source:
Alcoholism: Clinical and Experimental Research, Vol 30(6), Jun, 2006. pp. 1023-1030.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0145-6008 (Print)
1530-0277 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
epidemiology, women, child-bearing age, binge drinking, drinking, alcohol abuse, alcohol dependence
Abstract:
Objectives: To estimate the prevalence of drinking, binge drinking (4 or more drinks), and alcohol abuse and dependence and to identify predictors of heavier drinking among women of child-bearing age (18-44 years). Methods: Subjects are part of a national multistage random sample from the 2002 National Epidemiologic Survey on Alcohol and Related Conditions (NESARC). Results: Binge drinking, abuse, and dependence are higher in younger (<30 years) pregnant and nonpregnant women. Among pregnant women, binge drinking is highest among Whites; alcohol abuse and dependence rates are relatively low and similar in all racial/ethnic groups. Among nonpregnant women, Whites and mixed race women have the highest rates of binge drinking. Alcohol abuse and dependence are highest among Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islanders, followed by Native American/Alaska Native women. Women who are White, younger (21-29 years), single, or cohabiting and with a higher income (>$40,000) are at a higher risk for heavier drinking. Conclusions: Drinking and heavier drinking remain at high levels among women of child-bearing age. Prevention efforts must be comprehensive and should target pregnant women who are drinking and those who could become pregnant and are drinking at high-risk levels. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Alcohol Drinking Patterns; *Alcoholism; *Binge Drinking; *Epidemiology; *Pregnancy

Record: 370
Title:
The five-factor model of personality in South African college students.
Authors:
Heuchert, J. W. P., Allegheny Coll, PA, US
Parker, Wayne D.
Stumpf, Heinrich
Myburgh, Chris P. H.
Source:
American Behavioral Scientist, Vol 44(1), Sep, 2000. pp. 112-125.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Other Journal Titles:
Political Research, Organization and Design
ISSN:
0002-7642 (Print)
1552-3381 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
factor structure of Revised NEO Personality Inventory, similarities & differences of personality between racial groups, Black vs White vs Indian vs mixed race South African college students
Abstract:
Analyzed the factor structure of the Revised NEO Personality Inventory (NEO-PI-R) in 408 White, Black, Indian, and mixed race South African college students to see if the five-factor model can be recovered and determined the utility of the use of the test in South Africa and if a comparable factor structure can be recovered in White and Black South Africans. When the instrument was factor analyzed, the structure of the five-factor model was well reproduced for the entire sample as well as the White and Black subgroups. Parallel analysis indicated the appropriateness of the five-factor solution. Whereas the structure of personality was highly similar across race, there were statistically significant differences in mean scores of some domains and facets by race. The greatest difference was in Openness to Experience, particularly in the Openness to Feelings facet, with the White subgroup scoring relatively high, the Black subgroup scoring relatively low, and the Indian subgroup scoring in an intermediate range. The authors speculate that these differences are primarily the result of social, economic, and cultural differences between the races rather than the direct product of race itself. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Factor Structure; *Five Factor Personality Model; *NEO Personality Inventory; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; Blacks; Cross Cultural Psychology; Test Norms; Test Validity; Whites

Record: 371
Title:
The formation of in-group favoritism and out-group prejudice in young children: Are they distinct attitudes?
Authors:
Aboud, Frances E., McGill U, Montreal, PQ, Canada, frances.aboud@mcgill.ca
Address:
Aboud, Frances E., Dept of Psychology, 1205 Dr. Penfield Avenue, Montreal, PQ, Canada, H3A 1B1, frances.aboud@mcgill.ca
Source:
Developmental Psychology, Vol 39(1), Jan, 2003. pp. 48-60.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
ISSN:
0012-1649 (Print)
1939-0599 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
in-group favoritism, out-group prejudice, formation, attitudes, racially homogeneous school, mixed race school, White children
Abstract:
Although standardized measures of prejudice reveal high levels of ethnocentric bias in the preschool years, it may reflect in-group favoritism or out-group prejudice. A measure that partially decouples the two attitudes was given to White children between 4 and 7 years of age to examine the reciprocal relation between and the acquisition and correlates of in-group and out-group attitudes. The two attitudes were reciprocally correlated in 1 sample from a racially homogeneous school but not in a 2nd sample from a mixed-race school. In-group favoritism did not appear until 5 years of age but then reached significant levels; it was strongly related to developing social cognitions. Out-group prejudice was weaker, but its targets suffer from comparison with the high favoritism accorded in-group members. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Child Attitudes; *Ingroup Outgroup; *Prejudice; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *School Integration; Attitude Formation; Ethnocentrism; Whites

Record: 372
Title:
The historical problematization of 'mixed race' in psychological and human-scientific discourses.
Authors:
Teo, Thomas, York U, Dept of Psychology, Toronto, ON, Canada
Source:
Defining difference: Race and racism in the history of psychology. Winston, Andrew S. (Ed); pp. 79-108; Washington, DC, US: American Psychological Association; 2004. xi, 303 pp.
Page Count:
30
ISBN:
1-59147-027-7 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed race persons, historical problematization, history of psychology, scientific discourse, racial attitudes
Abstract:
This chapter focuses on the problematization of hybridity in psychology and the human sciences. Academic problematization is the process by which groups or individuals are made into a problem. Historically women, various "races," gay men and lesbians, mentally ill persons, and other groups have been transformed into problems in the human sciences. Analyses of problematization seek to reconstruct when, why, and how a particular problematization took place, but the focus of this chapter will be on the "how"--that is, the techniques of problematization. The chapter will not answer exactly when hybridity became a problem in the course of Western history or how the discourses on hybridity as a biological, psychological, cultural, and political problem shifted over time. Instead, I am more interested in the conceptual and empiricist techniques that were construed, used, and repeated to make hybridity a problem. I hope to provide some understanding by tracing a few of these techniques from the Enlightenment to the present. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*History of Psychology; *Interracial Offspring; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Sciences; Race (Anthropological)
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:

Record: 373
Title:
The identity of transracial adoptees.
Authors:
McRoy, Ruth G., U Texas Ctr for Social Work Research, School of Social Work, Austin
Zurcher, Louis A.
Lauderdale, Michael L.
Anderson, Rosalie E.
Source:
Social Casework, Vol 65(1), Jan, 1984. pp. 34-39.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
US : Alliance for Children & Families
Other Journal Titles:
Families in Society
ISSN:
0037-7678 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
development of racial self perceptions, Black or mixed-race 10–21 yr olds adopted by White parents
Abstract:
Examined familial and contextual factors that influenced the development of racial self-perceptions among 30 Black or mixed-race children and adolescents (aged 10–21 yrs) who had been adopted by White parents. Questionnaires and interviews with both children and parents revealed 3 ways that families dealt with racial identity issues. 18 of the families rarely discussed racial issues or associated with Blacks, and the children perceived themselves as different from other Blacks in terms of attitudes and culture. These children also held strong feelings of "differentness" and negative attitudes toward other Blacks. A 2nd group of 6 families acknowledged the child's racial identity and the need to provide Black role models for the child. These families lived in integrated neighborhoods, and the children expressed an interest in contact with other Blacks and often discussed racial identity issues with parents and peers. A 3rd group, in which parents generally had adopted several Black children, were characterized as interracial, and children were taught to emphasize their Black heritage. These families also provided a psychological support network for the adopted children. Findings suggest that transracial adoptions require special efforts on the part of parents and children and postplacement work on the part of the adoption agency. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Adopted Children; *Adoptive Parents; *Ethnic Identity; *Racial and Ethnic Differences

Record: 374
Title:
The impact of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection on quality of life in a multiracial South African population.
Authors:
O'Keefe, A. E., U Cape Town, Somerset Hosp, Dept of Medicine, Cape Town, South Africa
Wood, R.
Source:
Quality of Life Research: An International Journal of Quality of Life Aspects of Treatment, Care & Rehabilitation, Vol 5(2), Apr, 1996. pp. 275-280.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0962-9343 (Print)
1573-2649 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
sex & race & clinical stage of disease, quality of life, 20–40 yr olds with HIV, South Africa
Abstract:
Used the Medical Outcomes Survey SF-36 instrument to determine if the quality of life (QOL) in males and females with HIV was affected by race, gender, or clinical stage of disease. Ss were 134 HIV outpatients (aged 20–40 yrs, 42 White, 49 Mixed race and 43 Black), who were referred to an HIV clinic in western Cape Town, South Africa, and 115 healthy, non-medical hospital personnel (36 Whites, 37 Mixed race, 42 Blacks). Scores on 8 QOL concepts were assessed. Black female controls scored significantly lower on all scales except physical function. HIV-infected Ss of Mixed race (both genders) reported poorer physical function; no other scale was affected by race. HIV Ss scored significantly lower on all scales; the majority of the decline in function occurred early in disease by WHO stages 1 and 2. It is concluded that HIV infection impacts early on all aspects of QOL and that this impact is largely independent of racial origin. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*HIV; *Human Sex Differences; *Quality of Life; *Racial and Ethnic Differences
PsycINFO Classification:

Record: 375
Title:
The inheritability of identity: Children's understanding of the cultural biology of race.
Authors:
Hirschfeld, Lawrence A., U Michigan, Dept of Anthropology, Ann Arbor, US
Source:
Child Development, Vol 66(5), Oct, 1995. pp. 1418-1437.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
Other Journal Titles:
Child Development: Abstracts & Bibliography
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0009-3920 (Print)
1467-8624 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
beliefs about inheritability of identity & racial characteristics of mixed race children, 7–12 yr olds & undergraduates & adults
Abstract:
Examined beliefs about inheritability of identity and racial characteristics of mixed-race children. In Exp 1, 32 children (aged 7–21 yrs) and 43 undergraduates described the category membership of mixed-race children and the degree to which they resembled each parent. Exp 2 investigated whether 36 children (age 7–12 yrs) and 18 adults expected mixed-race children to have White, Black, or intermediate features. Exp 3 explored 46 children's (age 7–22) expectations about the inheritability of the same properties in animals. Older children, like adults, believed mixed-race children have Black racial features. Adults believe such children inherit the categorical identity of the minority parent. Exp 4 repeated these tasks with 39 Black and White children (age 7–22) attending an integrated school. Unlike children attending a predominantly White school, Ss in the integrated school expect mixed-race children to have intermediate racial features. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Interracial Offspring; *Physical Appearance; *Race (Anthropological); *Self Concept
PsycINFO Classification:
Psychosocial & Personality Development (2840)
Population:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 376
Title:
The interracial experience: Growing up Black/White racially mixed in the United States.
Authors:
Brown, Ursula M., Private Practice, Montclair, NJ, US
Source:
Westport, CT, US: Greenwood Press/Greenwood Publishing Group; 2000. x, 153 pp.
Page Count:
153
ISBN:
0-275-97046-9 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
interracial marriage & racial identity & racism & psychosocial experiences of interracial people in America
Abstract:
Investigates how mixed race people cope in a world that has shoehorned them into a racial category that denies half of their physiological and psychological existence. The author presents relevant demographic, research, and sociocultural data as well as a series of personal vignettes based on interviews with 119 American-born black/white interracial young adults (mean age of 21.4 yrs) from all walks of life. The author interweaves research findings with these interviews in order to highlight certain psychosocial phenomenon and experiences. The history of interracial marriages in the US is examined, and the scientific and social theories that underlie the racial bigotry suffered by mixed people are discussed. Questions of racial identity, conflict, and self-esteem are addressed and treated as issues of mental health, and the struggle for acceptance in a black and white world and the racist abuses that many interracial people have suffered are discussed as well. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (publicity materials)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Interracial Marriage; *Interracial Offspring; *Psychosocial Factors; *Racism

Record: 377
Title:
The life narrative of a mixed-race man in recovery from addiction: A case-based psychosocial approach to researching drugs, 'race' and ethnicity.
Authors:
Roy, Alastair, Psychosocial Research Unit, School of Social Work, University of Central Lancashire, Preston, United Kingdom, anroy@uclan.ac.uk
Address:
Roy, Alastair, Psychosocial Research Unit, School of Social Work, University of Central Lancashire, Preston, United Kingdom, PR1 2HE, anroy@uclan.ac.uk
Source:
Journal of Social Work Practice, Vol 27(4), Dec, 2013. pp. 375-392.
Page Count:
18
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0265-0533 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
life narratives, addiction, psychosocial approach, researching drugs, race, ethnicity
Abstract:
This paper explores the use of a psychosocial approach to researching drugs, race and ethnicity. It produces an analysis of interviews with Bobby, a mixed-race man in recovery from addiction. Sociological and psychoanalytic perspectives are brought to bear on the data in order to consider the character of Bobby's opportunities, identifications, crises and resolutions. Despite the affective components of the wider discourse on drugs and race, the majority of previous research on the subject has focused on the production of rational explanations produced within objectivist epistemological frames. In contrast, the methods used in this project seek an explicit engagement with the irrational and unconscious aspects of researching these subjects. The paper concludes by reflecting on the value of psychosocially oriented narrative methods in this field. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Addiction; *Narratives; *Psychosocial Factors; Ethnic Identity

Title:
The multiracial contribution to the psychological browning of America.
Authors:
Root, Maria P. P., Private Practice, Seattle, WA, US
Source:
American mixed race: The culture of microdiversity. Zack, Naomi (Ed); pp. 231-236; Lanham, MD, England: Rowman & Littlefield; 1995. xxv, 379 pp.
Page Count:
6
ISBN:
0-8476-8012-6 (Hardcover)
0-8476-8013-4 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
attitudes & determination of situational ethnicity & multiple transformed racial identity through life cycle, multiracial persons
Abstract:
[answers] the question of how others determine where a mixed-race person lands in the choice of racial identity with positive reasons for affirming traditional rules of hypodescent / many multiracial individuals who now choose to identify with their relatives of color may be motivated by family acceptance and a better known family history, as well as rejection from white relatives / the sense of belonging that accompanies present choices of hypodescent may be preferable to the isolation and alienation that could accompany insistence on white identity, mixed identity, or no racial identity (introduction)

in this discussion, observations of situational ethnicity, multiple identities, and transformed identities through the life cycle are discussed in the context of being a multiracial person in this country (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Record: 379
Title:
The multiracial movement: Bridging society's language barrier.
Parent Book Series:
Praeger perspectives: Race and ethnicity in psychology
Authors:
Del Prado, Alicia M., Wright Institute, Berkeley, CA, US
Lyda, James, Counseling and Psychological Services, University of Califomia, Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, US
Source:
Diversity in mind and in action, Vol 1: Multiple faces of identity. Chin, Jean Lau (Ed); pp. 1-16; Santa Barbara, CA, US: Praeger/ABC-CLIO; 2009. xviii, 167 pp.
Page Count:
16
ISBN:
978-0-313-34709-2 (Hardcover)
978-0-313-34710-8 (PDF)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race, multiracial movement, rights, self-expression, mixed-race community, racial identity, language barrier, identity terminology
Abstract:
Race is a socially constructed way of grouping people, which differs among societies and over time. It has no biological basis. In the United States, many individuals have experienced misrepresentation because of restrictive racial labels. Multiracial is an inclusive identification term that "refers to people who are of two or more racial heritages" and refers "to people across all racial mixes". The multiracial movement, which gained momentum in the late 1970's and early 1980's, has been proactively addressing the unique issues of the mixed race population in the United States. The multiracial movement is being pursued by people dedicated to the advancement of the rights and self-expression of multiracial individuals and families. Our chapter aims to advance the multiracial movement by bridging the language barrier that is present both within the mixed-race community and between multiracial and monoracial persons. We propose that this language barrier is the lack of a vernacular that is sufficiently reflective of the identities and existence of people of mixed heritage. The voice and authentic experiences of racially mixed people within the United States have been suppressed and silenced by a lack of inclusive terminology. Current racial conceptualizations emphasize an either/or approach that can unnecessarily dichotomize identity for people of racially mixed heritage. There is a need for people to openly consider the multiple possibilities of mixed race individuals' heritages. The language barrier in the United States can be overcome if society as a whole is willing to adopt a multiracial-affirmative language and mindset. In this chapter, we advocate suggestions for how all individuals—both multiracial and monoracial persons—can use various mixed race identity terminology, see the world through a multiracial-affirmative lens, and implement multiracial-affirmative actions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Society; *Terminology; Activism; Human Rights; Language; Social Identity; Self Expression
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Location:
US
Intended Audience:
Psychology: Professional & Research (PS)
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Book; Edited Book

Record: 380
Title:
The Myth of 'Race' (and 'Mixed Race').
Authors:
Fairchild, Halford H., Pitzer College, Claremont, CA, US
Rodriguez, Norma, Pitzer College, Claremont, CA, US
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 42 (7), Jul, 1997. pp. 620-621.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Zack, Naomi (Ed). (1995) American Mixed Race: The Culture of Microdiversity Lanham, MD: Rowman & Littlefield. 379 pp. $68.50 hardcover; $26.95 paperback 0-8476-8012-6 (Hardcover); 0-8476-8013-4 (Paperback).
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial diversity, microdiversity
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1997, Vol 42(7), 620-621. American Mixed Race: The Culture of Microdiversity (see record 1995-97907-000), edited by Naomi Zack, probes this problem of the color line from the perspective of racial diversity within individuals. The book argues that discussions of diversity (i.e., racial difference, multiculturalism) tend to focus on rigidly defined racial categories that impose group membership for individuals who differ from others in those groups and who may not belong to, or identify with, any particular group. The important contributions of American Mixed Race are twofold. First, the book is multidisciplinary. Contributors represent a number of specialties within the social sciences and humanities. The five sections of the book are autobiography, art, social science, public policy, and identity theory. Second, the book demonstrates the breadth of the microdiversity concept. Although racial distinctions will remain salient within the broader social culture well into the 21st century, the real challenge is recognizing and appreciating the commonalities within human experiences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

*Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Multiculturalism

Culture & Ethnology (2930)

Record: 381
Title:
The neural substrates of in-group bias: A functional magnetic resonance imaging investigation.
Authors:
Van Bavel, Jay J., Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, US
Packer, Dominic J., Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, US
Cunningham, William A., Ohio State University, Columbus, OH, US, cunningham.417@osu.edu
Address:
Cunningham, William A., Ohio State University, Department of Psychology, Lazenby Hall, 1827 Neil Ave., Columbus, OH, US, 43210, cunningham.417@osu.edu
Source:
Psychological Science, Vol 19(11), Nov, 2008. pp. 1131-1139.
Page Count:
9
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0956-7976 (Print)
1467-9280 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
neural substrates, in-group bias, brain
Abstract:
Classic minimal-group studies found that people arbitrarily assigned to a novel group quickly display a range of perceptual, affective, and behavioral in-group biases. We randomly assigned participants to a mixed-race team and used functional magnetic resonance imaging to identify brain regions involved in processing novel in-group and out-group members independently of preexisting attitudes, stereotypes, or familiarity. Whereas previous research on intergroup perception found amygdala activity—typically interpreted as negativity—in response to stigmatized social groups, we found greater activity in the amygdala, fusiform gyri, orbitofrontal cortex, and dorsal striatum when participants viewed novel in-group faces than when they viewed novel out-group faces. Moreover, activity in orbitofrontal cortex mediated the in-group bias in self-reported liking for the faces. These in-group biases in neural activity were not moderated by race or by whether participants explicitly attended to team membership or race, a finding suggesting that they may occur automatically. This study helps clarify the role of neural substrates involved in perceptual and affective in-group biases. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Brain; *Group Dynamics; *Ingroup Outgroup; Neurology
PsycINFO Classification:
Neuropsychology & Neurology (2520)

Record: 382
Title:
The performativity of Black beauty shame in Jamaica and its diaspora: Problematising and transforming beauty iconicities.
Authors:
Tate, Shirley, University of Leeds, Leeds, United Kingdom, S.A.Tate@leeds.ac.uk
Address:
Tate, Shirley, Centre for Ethnicity and Racism Studies, School of Sociology and Social Policy, University of Leeds, Leeds, United Kingdom, LS2 9JT, S.A.Tate@leeds.ac.uk
Source:
Feminist Theory, Vol 14(2), Aug, 2013. pp. 219-235.
Page Count:
17
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
1464-7001 (Print)
1741-2773 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Black beauty shame, personality traits, body image, heritage women, virtue
Abstract:
Black beauty shame emerges within the Black/white binary because of the beauty values sedimented in our structure of feeling since African enslavement. This article does not start from white beauty as the ideal, but focuses on the performativity of Black beauty shame as it transforms or intensifies the meanings of parts of the body in Jamaica and its UK diaspora. Using extracts from interviews with UK Jamaican heritage women, the discussion illustrates how Black beauty shame produces such intensification. First, where white beauty is iconic and reproduces the Black other as ‘ugly’, and second, where the Black ‘mixed race’ body is constructed as ‘other’ because of Black Nationalist discourses on beauty. The women’s critique of the shaming event shows that shame is undone through dis-identification as speakers draw on alternative beauty discourses to produce new beauty subjectivities. Dis-identification illustrates the transformational potential of shame as new Black beauty positionings emerge within the diaspora, drawing on beauty ideologies and models from Jamaica and thus destabilising the Black/white binary. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Body Image; *Personality Traits; *Shame; *Virtue; Human Females

Record: 383
Title:
The potency of indigenous 'bibles' and biographies: Mapuche shamanic literacy and historical consciousness.
Authors:
Bacigalupo, Ana Mariella, Department of Anthropology, SUNY Buffalo, Buffalo, NY, US, anab@buffalo.edu
Address:
Bacigalupo, Ana Mariella, Department of Anthropology, SUNY Buffalo, 380 MFAC, Ellicott Complex, Buffalo, NY, US, 14261, anab@buffalo.edu
Source:
American Ethnologist, Vol 41(4), Nov, 2014. pp. 648-663.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
US : University of California Press
ISSN:
0094-0496 (Print)
1548-1425 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
shaman, text, bible, mestizo, history, literacy, Mapuche, Chile
Abstract:
Mapuche oral shamanic biographies and performances—some of which take the form of “bibles” and involve shamanic literacies—play a central role in the production of indigenous history in southern Chile. In this article, I explain how and why a mixed‐race Mapuche shaman charged me with writing about her life and practice in the form of such a “bible.” This book would become a ritual object and a means of storing her shamanic power by textualizing it, thereby allowing her to speak to a future audience. The realities and powers her “bible” stored could be extracted, transformed, circulated, and actualized for a variety of ends, even to bring about shamanic rebirth. Ultimately, I argue, through their use and interpretation of this kind of “bible,” Mapuche shamans expand academic notions of indigenous history and literacy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Biography; *Ethnology; *Indigenous Populations; *Religious Literature; *Spirituality; Birth; Culture (Anthropological); Religion
PsycINFO Classification:

Chile

<A href="https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2014-48836-003&site=ehost-live&scope=site">The potency of indigenous 'bibles' and biographies: Mapuche shamanic literacy and historical consciousness.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 384
Title:
The price of ‘community’ from bisexual/biracial women's perspectives.
Authors:
Thompson, Beverly Yuen, Siena College, Loudonville, NY, US, BThompson@siena.edu
Address:
Thompson, Beverly Yuen, Sociology Department, Siena College, 515 Loudon Road, Loudonville, NY, US, 12211, BThompson@siena.edu
Source:
Journal of Bisexuality, Vol 12(3), Jul, 2012. pp. 417-428.
Page Count:
12
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Haworth Press
ISSN:
1529-9716 (Print)
1529-9724 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
identity communities, bisexual biracial women
Abstract:
When the words ‘identity’ or ‘community’ are evoked, a homogenizing process forms for the sake of community coherence. This article is based upon interviews with nine bisexual and mixed race participants about their conceptualization of identity-based communities. All participants expressed discontent with the ‘established’ gay and lesbian community for being monolithically White in racial composition and also biphobic. More than one half of the participants had been involved in queer Asian American women’s organizations, within which they felt the least conflict and the most inclusion. The ideals of identity-based organizations have only sporadically manifested themselves for the bisexual-biracial women who are otherwise marginalized, silenced or excluded. Because their diverse needs and identities are not represented within these organizations, many of the participants felt they gave more than they received. Finding that communities based upon narrow identity clusters were not ideal, the participants created diverse communities based upon their expanded interests and identities. These bisexual-biracial women have revolutionized their personal concepts of community as they integrated the ideals of identity politics yet moved to include individuals who share similar progressive politics, responsibility and acceptance. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Bisexuality; *Community Psychology; *Human Females; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; *Social Identity; Communities
PsycINFO Classification:
Sex Roles & Women's Issues (2970)
Population:
Human
Female
Location:
US

Format Covered:

Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal

Release Date:
20130114

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1080/15299716.2012.702623

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):

Title:
The psychology of prejudice and discrimination: Ethnicity and multiracial identity, Vol. 2.
Book Series:
Race and ethnicity in psychology
Authors:
Chin, Jean Lau, (Ed), California School of Professional Psychology, Alliant International University, CA, US
Source:
Westport, CT, US: Praeger Publishers/Greenwood Publishing Group; 2004. xv, 236 pp.
Page Count:
236
ISBN:
0-275-98236-X (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial prejudice, race discrimination, ethnicity, multiracial identity, immigration, language, cultural factors, cultural discrimination, prejudice
Abstract:
This four-volume set, The Psychology of Prejudice and Discrimination, takes a fresh look at that issue that is embedded in today's global environment. Each chapter offers new perspectives on standing issues, with practical information about how to cope with prejudice and discrimination. The "toolbox" at the end of each chapter suggests steps to be taken at different levels to combat prejudice and discrimination and to achieve change. In the second volume of this series, Ethnicity and Multiracial Identity, the text looks at discrimination toward differences due to immigration, language, culture, and mixed race. Written for today's people and environment, these volumes are rich with anecdotes, stories, examples, and research. These stories illustrate the emotional impact of prejudice and discrimination throughout history and as it still strikes people's lives today. While the chapters spotlight psychology, they interweave history, politics, legislation, social change, education, and more. These interdisciplinary views reflect the broad contexts of prejudice and discrimination that ultimately affect identity, life adjustment, and well-being for every one of us. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (introduction)

Source: The multiracial experience: Racial borders as the new frontier.
Record: 386
Title:
The psychology of prejudice and discrimination: Racism in America, Vol. 1.
Book Series:
Race and ethnicity in psychology
Authors:
Chin, Jean Lau, (Ed), California School of Professional Psychology, Alliant International University, CA, US
Source:
Westport, CT, US: Praeger Publishers/Greenwood Publishing Group; 2004. xv, 257 pp.
Page Count:
257
ISBN:
0-275-98235-1 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
prejudice, discrimination, racism, racism in America, stereotypes, racial bias, race relations, ethnicity, cultural factors, gender differences, sexual orientation
Abstract:
This four-volume set, The Psychology of Prejudice and Discrimination, takes a fresh look at that issue that is embedded in today's global environment. Images, attitudes and perceptions that sustain prejudice and discrimination are more covert, but no less pernicious. What people say, believe, and do all reflect underlying bias. We do not claim here to address every existing form of prejudice or discrimination, nor do we cite every possible group targeted today. What we offer are insights into a range from the most to least recognized, or openly discussed, forms of this injustice. Each chapter offers new perspectives on standing issues, with practical information about how to cope with prejudice and discrimination. The "toolbox" at the end of each chapter suggests steps to be taken at different levels to combat prejudice and discrimination and to achieve change. At the individual level, self-reflection needs to occur by both the victims and perpetrators of discrimination. Practitioners, educators, and all who deliver services potentially impart a bias perpetuating prejudice and discrimination. At the systems level, communities and policymakers must join together and have the will to combat discrimination. Volume 1, Racism in America, looks at stereotypes, racial bias, and race relations. Volume 2, Ethnicity and Multiracial Identity, looks at discrimination toward differences due to immigration, language, culture, and mixed race. Volume 3, Bias Based on Gender and Sexual Orientation, looks at gender bias, women's issues, homophobia, and oppression of gay/lesbian lifestyles. Volume 4, Disability, Religion, Physique, and Other Traits, strives to examine less-spotlighted bias against other forms of difference, and begins the difficult dialogue that must take place if we are to eradicate prejudice and discrimination. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (introduction)
Subjects:
*Discrimination; *Prejudice; *Race and Ethnic Discrimination; *Racism; *Stereotyped Attitudes; Human Sex Differences; Sex Discrimination; Sexual Orientation; Sociocultural Factors

Record: 387
Title:
The Relational Emplotment of Mixed Racial Identity.
Authors:
Schiff, Brian, St Martin's U, Lacey, WA, US
O'Neill, Tracie, St Martin's U, Lacey, WA, US
Source:
The meaning of others: Narrative studies of relationships. Josselson, Ruthellen (Ed); Lieblich, Amia (Ed); McAdams, Dan P. (Ed); pp. 143-163; Washington, DC, US: American Psychological Association; 2007. x, 301 pp.
Page Count:
21
ISBN:
1-59147-816-2 (Hardcover)
978-1-59147-816-4 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed racial identity, relational experience, biracial, relatedness to parent, identity formation
Abstract:
In this chapter, we inquire into the part that relationships play in orienting persons to the cultural resources for identity formation. In our research, we consider how young adults with parents of different racial backgrounds come to rewrite their racial identity, becoming biracial, multiracial, or mixed race. We study the personal narratives of biracial youth to understand how they talk about arriving at these new self-identifications. The personal narrative is an attempt to make sense of the self through time (Cohler, 1998) by organizing experience into an understandable story of the past, present, and future (Ricoeur, 1984). Through the workings of plot, the personal narrative configures the me into a story that conveys a sense of identity (McAdams, 1996). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Identity Formation; *Interracial Offspring; *Narratives; *Sociocultural Factors; Blacks; Parent Child Relations; Whites

Record: 388
Title:
The role of identity integration in enhancing creativity among mixed‐race individuals.
Authors:
Tendayi Viki, G., University of Kent, Kent, United Kingdom, g.t.viki@kent.ac.uk
Williams, May Liang J., University of Kent, Kent, United Kingdom
Address:
Tendayi Viki, G., Department of Psychology, University of Kent, Kent, United Kingdom, CT2 7NP, g.t.viki@kent.ac.uk
Source:
The Journal of Creative Behavior, Vol 48(3), Sep, 2014. pp. 198-208.
Page Count:
11
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
Other Publishers:
US : Creative Education Foundation
ISSN:
0022-0175 (Print)
2162-6057 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
creativity, identity, integration, mixed‐race, race
Abstract:
Identity integration among bicultural individuals refers to the perception that their two cultural identities are compatible. Previous research has shown that identity integration is likely to lead to enhanced creativity. However, this research was conducted among first‐ and second‐generation immigrants, but not among mixed‐race individuals. The current research examined identity integration and creativity among mixed‐race individuals. We also explored the role of integrated identity experiences at home. We found that identity integration was related to increases in creativity; and this was partly mediated via integrated identity experiences at home. Our findings suggest that positive bicultural experiences at home may create a context for the individual to integrate their biracial identities; and this is ultimately beneficial for creativity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Creativity; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; Social Identity

Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:

Remotes Associate Test
Unusual Uses Test
Exemplar Generation Task

Record: 389
Title:
The sable pride of night.
Authors:
Truhon, Stephen A.
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 53 (37), 2008.
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Quintana, Stephen M. (Ed); McKown, Clark (Ed). (2008) Handbook of race, racism, and the developing child Hoboken, NJ: Wiley. 507pp, $85.00 978-0-470043226.
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race, racism, child development, child recognition, self-identification, racial attitudes, influence of racial bias, adjustment
Abstract:
Reviews the book, Handbook of race, racism, and the developing child edited by Stephen M. Quintana and Clark McKown (see record 2008-00226-000). The title of their book is apt because the chapters in this book deal with two overlapping topics: (a) children's recognition and self-identification of race and (b) the formation of racial attitudes and the influence of racial bias on children's development and adjustment. Although most of the chapters in this book focus on these topics with respect to children in the United States, researchers' work from Australia, Canada, England, Israel, and the Netherlands is also included. Likewise most of the emphasis is on African Americans, although several chapters address how these topics apply to Latinos, Asian Americans, and those of mixed race. The first half of the book describes and attempts to explain the changes in children's thinking about race, racism, and racial attitudes. The second half of the book examines the outcomes of race and racism in such areas as mental health, academic achievement, and occupational aspirations. This is a good source book for those who want to read the latest thinking and research on race, racism, and children. Thus it will primarily appeal to researchers and graduate students. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Adjustment; *Childhood Development; *Ethnic Identity; *Racial and Ethnic Attitudes; *Racism
