Title:
The Seventh Jack Tizard Memorial Lecture: Aspects of adoption.
Authors:
Hersov, Lionel, U Massachusetts Medical Ctr, Dept of Psychiatry, Worcester, US
Source:
Annual Progress in Child Psychiatry & Child Development, 1991. pp. 619-639.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
US : Brunner/Mazel Publishers, Inc.
ISSN:
0066-4030 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
adoption as form of child care, conference presentation, reprint
Abstract:
(This reprinted article originally appeared in the Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry and Allied Disciplines, 1990, 31[4], 493–510. The following abstract of the original article appeared in PA, Vol 77:29209.) Adoption is now seen as a form of child care, one of a spectrum of resources for children in need. Adopted children generally show a good outcome but are overrepresented in clinical populations. This trend is likely to continue as older children with histories of severe deprivation, neglect, abuse, and institutionalization are placed. Attitudes toward the adoption of mixed-race and older children are also changing: Black and mixed-race children are becoming easier to place. Developmental studies have thrown new light on revealing to children that they were adopted. Adoption disruption increases with age and other factors at placement, requiring further research into its origins and management. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

Title:
The Seventh Jack Tizard Memorial Lecture: Aspects of adoption.

Hersov, Lionel, U Massachusetts Medical Ctr, Dept of Psychiatry, Worcester, US

Netherlands : Elsevier Science
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.

0021-9630 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
adoption as form of child care, conference presentation
Abstract:
Adoption is now seen as a form of child care, one of a spectrum of resources for children in need. Adopted children generally show a good outcome but are overrepresented in clinical populations. This trend is likely to continue as older children with histories of severe deprivation, neglect, abuse, and institutionalization are placed. Attitudes to the adoption of mixed-race and older children are also changing: Black- and mixed-race children are becoming easier to place. Developmental studies have thrown new light on revealing to children that they were adopted. Adoption disruption increases with age and other factors at placement, requiring further research into its origins and management. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

Record: 392
Title:
The sexual basis of racial formation: Anti-vice activism and the creation of the twentieth-century 'color line'.
Authors:
Donovan, Brian, Department of Sociology, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, US, bdonovan@ku.edu
Address:
Donovan, Brian, Department of Sociology, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, US, 66045, bdonovan@ku.edu
Source:
Ethnic and Racial Studies, Vol 26(4), Jul, 2003. pp. 707-727.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0141-9870 (Print)
1466-4356 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial distinctions, sexual basis, anti-vice activism, mixed-race women, gender, color line, White slavery, racial boundaries, racial formation theories, racial categories, cultural narratives
Abstract:
White slavery narratives--stories about white women forced into prostitution--played an important role in the construction of racial distinctions in the early twentieth century. New York City politicians launched a well-publicized anti-vice crusade in 1910 that led to the imprisonment of a mixed-race woman named Belle Moore. In this article, I analyse this event to show the importance of sexuality and gender for creating racial boundaries. Testimony in People vs. Belle Moore designated certain intimacies as violating the color line, thereby clarifying what it meant to be 'White' or 'Colored'. I argue that theories of racial formation must include a more careful consideration of gender and sexuality because the ongoing maintenance of racial categories depends upon cultural narratives about sexual deviance and purity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Human Females; *Human Sex Differences; *Racism; *Sexuality; *Sociocultural Factors; Culture (Anthropological); Racial and Ethnic Differences
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
US
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Format Covered:
Print
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
20040628

http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1080/0141987032000087370
Accession Number:
2003-99632-004

48
UR:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 393
Title:
The social position of multiracial groups in the United States: Evidence from residential segregation.
Authors:
Bennett, Pamela R., Department of Sociology, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD, US, pbennett@jhu.edu
Address:
Bennett, Pamela R., Department of Sociology, Johns Hopkins University, 3400 N. Charles Street, Baltimore, MD, US, pbennett@jhu.edu
Source:
Ethnic and Racial Studies, Vol 34(4), Apr, 2011. pp. 707-729.
Page Count:
23
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0141-9870 (Print)
1466-4356 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multiracial groups, social position, residential segregation, racial hierarchy, neighborhoods
Abstract:
I use multiple perspectives on the racial order in the United States to generate hypotheses about the social position of mixed-race groups. Perspectives that view the racial order as binary, ternary with an undifferentiated middle, or ternary with a stratified middle present different expectations for the social position of multiracial groups. I use a group’s level of residential segregation as an index of social position. In 2000, multiracial persons lived in neighbourhoods that were more white than the neighbourhoods of single-race minorities, though more diverse than the neighbourhoods of whites. Thus, multiracial groups appear to occupy an intermediate social position relative to blacks and whites, a finding that supports contemporary arguments about shifting colour-lines in the United States and the emergence of a triracial system of stratification. Yet, findings also suggest that the social space between blacks and whites is, itself, racially stratified. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Interracial Offspring; *Neighborhoods; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; *Social Integration; *Social Structure
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Location:
US
Age Group:
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)
Methodology:

Record: 394
Title:
The strangeness of passing: Commentary on paper by Christopher Bonovitz.
Authors:
Bushra, Annabella, Westchester Center for the Study of Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy, US, annabellabushra@cs.com
Address:
Bushra, Annabella, 330 West 58th Street, #504, New York, NY, US, 10019, annabellabushra@cs.com
Source:
Psychoanalytic Dialogues, Vol 19(4), Jul, 2009. pp. 442-449.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Analytic Press
ISSN:
1048-1885 (Print)
1940-9222 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
negotiation, conflicts, culture, internalization, self–states, biracial patients, psychoanalytic theory
Abstract:
Comments on an article by Christopher Bonovitz (see record 2010-11288-008). Christopher Bonovitz gives us a rich landscape of the theoretical, historical, and relational aspects of his work with his mixed-race patient. In my response I explore what seems missing: a stronger sense of the patient as a person, more of her own history in her family, more of the clinical back and forth with her therapist, a sense of what is being played out in the transference, and particularly what “passing” is for her. I show how his choices about how to think about her story and how to tell it are oversaturated with awareness of identity and race at the expense of the basic human relationship. In the face of such racial anxiety, there is a pull to rely too strongly on countertransference as a way to gain privileged access to knowledge about the other. I attribute many of these problems to the inescapable power of race in our culture. Furthermore, I address the themes of hatred, silence, secrecy and transgression as they relate to the history of transgenerational trauma for this patient and invite our broadening our awareness about how they play out in the therapeutic process. We are faced with the difficult, yet the essential task of holding and living out the patient's anger and outrage at the racial hatred that has been endured. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Conflict; *Internalization; *Interracial Offspring; *Psychoanalytic Theory; *Race (Anthropological); Culture (Anthropological); Negotiation; Patients; Self Concept

Abstract:
[discuss] the effects of policy upon practice [in the UK], in this case on the clinical work of psychiatrists and clinical psychologists in the field of children's mental health (introduction)

as a psychologist studying developmental issues in their social context, B. Tizard turned her attention to a remarkable variety of research issues with significance for clinicians dealing with children and their families as well as for public policy / these include the importance of play, the development of language, the outcome of children adopted after infancy, and the identity of children of mixed race / in all these areas, she has carefully considered the way in which her findings might influence practice and policy and has often entered public debate on the issues / at the same time, there has been a very considerable expansion of research activity relevant to the management and prevention of child psychiatric disorders / consider evidence for the impact of this work aetiological research [genetic factors, family relationships, life events, school effects, other epidemiological research, psychological processes] / clinical assessment / classification / clinical trials / evidence-based clinical approaches (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Record: 396
Title:
The use of the Social Support Behaviors Scale with adolescents.
Authors:
Corcoran, Jacqueline, U Texas, School of Social Work, Arlington, TX, US
Franklin, Cynthia
Bennett, Patricia
Source:
Research on Social Work Practice, Vol 8(3), May, 1998. Special Issue: Assessment and treatment of youth and families. pp. 302-314.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
1049-7315 (Print)
1552-7581 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
validity of Social Support Behaviors Scale, low SES multiethnic 11–22 yr olds at risk for parenting & pregnancy
Abstract:
The psychometric properties of a multidimensional measure of social support, A. Vaux's Social Support Behaviors Scale (SS-B), were evaluated. The SS-B is represented by subscales describing 5 central categories of supportive behaviors (Emotional, Socializing, Practical, Financial, and Advice/Guidance), assessed for both friends and family. The SS-B was administered to a low SES, mixed-race (19% Anglo, 37% African American, and 40% Hispanic) sample of 105 adolescents who were attending pregnancy prevention programs. A trend toward high scores, low variance, and few differences between pregnant/parenting and nonpregnant/parenting teens were found on subscale scores. Factor analyses on separate subscales showed loadings more consistently for "family" than "friends." Overall results of psychometric analysis indicate that the scale needs further work to more accurately assess the salient behavioral dimensions of social support for samples from varying racial and socioeconomic backgrounds. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Pregnancy; *Rating Scales; *Social Support; *Socioeconomic Status; *Test Validity; At Risk Populations

Title:
Therapy with mixed-race families.
Authors:
Laszloffy, Tracey A., Private Practice, Norwich, CT, US
Source:
Re-visioning family therapy: Race, culture, and gender in clinical practice (2nd ed.). McGoldrick, Monica (Ed); Hardy, Kenneth V. (Ed); pp. 275-285; New York, NY, US: Guilford Press; 2008. xxvii, 483 pp.
Page Count:
11
ISBN:
1-59385-427-7 (Hardcover)
978-1-59385-427-0 (Hardcover)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed-race families, multiracial identity, mixed-race people, racial identification, mixed-race children, intervention, racial identities, racism, society, therapy with mixed-race families, family dynamics
Abstract:
In the United States, mixed-race people must either deny their multiracial identity by identifying with only a single race or create an identity that is not recognized or validated by the broader society. Consequently, the core issue facing mixed-race people is how to identify racially and manage the assortment of dynamics, dilemmas, and challenges associated with racial identification in a society that denies and devalues multiracial identity. This chapter examined several family dynamics that commonly undermine or compromise how mixed-race children explore, define, assert, and negotiate their racial identities. Strategies for intervention were presented, including how to support parents in teaching their children how to understand and manage encounters with racism. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Title:
'There's a war against our children': Black educational underachievement revisited.
Authors:
Crozier, Gill, University of Sunderland, Sunderland, United Kingdom, gill.crozier@sunderland.ac.uk
Address:
Crozier, Gill, University of Sunderland, School of Education and Lifelong Learning, Forster Building, Chester Road, Sunderland, United Kingdom, SR1 3SD, gill.crozier@sunderland.ac.uk
Source:
British Journal of Sociology of Education, Vol 26(5), Nov, 2005. pp. 585-598.
Page Count:
14
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0142-5692 (Print)
1465-3346 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
educational experiences, parental attitudes, minority ethnic groups, academic underachievement
Abstract:
This paper focuses on the educational experiences of a group of African Caribbean and mixed 'race' young people from the perspectives of their parents. The discussion is set within a national context where children of African Caribbean origin are one of the lowest achieving minority ethnic groups in the UK and are disproportionately one of the highest ethnic groups of children excluded from school. The parents recount a pattern of cumulative negative experiences which for many of the children results in academic underachievement and becoming demotivated to learn, by a system that they feel has rejected them, or imposed exclusion. The story is hardly new but it provides important further evidence that schools need to tackle head-on factors such as low teacher expectations and negative stereotyping of young black people and their contribution to black underachievement. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Record: 400
Title:
Through Foreign Eyes: Adoption Angles and Maternity-Leave Suggestions.
Authors:
Brantner, Christina E., University of Nebraska--Lincoln, Lincoln, NE, US
Source:
Parenting & professing: Balancing family work with an academic career. Bassett, Rachel Hile (Ed); pp. 192-203; Nashville, TN, US: Vanderbilt University Press; 2005. xvii, 214 pp.
Page Count:
12
ISBN:
0-8265-1477-4 (Hardcover)
0-8265-1478-2 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
motherhood, university environment, antifamily, academic, family friendly
Abstract:
First and foremost, I am a happily obsessed mother of two--not atypical among older and intellectual types. I am also single by choice, German by birth, part of a mixed-race family through life's interesting turns (my two adopted sons are African American), and, based on my university position, a resident alien (I could go on and on about being a quirky alien, but that's best left for another essay). And I'd like to stress one significant element in this puzzle right from the start: Without the flexibility of an academic schedule, it would have been nearly impossible for me to both continue a rewarding professional and international life (living months on end in Germany) and spend lots of formative baby time (plus now preschool time) with my sons. So I am very grateful to academia. Nonetheless, there are still countless ways to help the typical university environment grow into a more family-friendly one. And this is precisely what inspired me to contribute to this volume, because over my 20 years in academia I have observed far too many incidents of "antifamily" structures and acts. It is not enough to have a "family leave" policy at any given academic institution, although it is a necessary first step. For any reader contemplating a parental leave in the future, I hope to provide a model or two that go beyond the individual and anecdotal. My experiences with the "powers that be" were unique, frustrating, funny, and--in the end--supportive, which I hope will make this an interesting narrative. I mainly hope to show elements any new academic-parent-to-be could use to plan for a smoother transition from a more traditionally male academic role to a more inclusive one. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Record: 401
Title:
To reveal or conceal?: Privacy management processes among interracial romantic partners.
Authors:
Brummett, Erin A., Department of Communication Studies, University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, US, erin-brummett@uiowa.edu
Steuber, Keli Ryan, Department of Communication Studies, College of New Jersey, NJ, US
Address:
Brummett, Erin A., Department of Communication Studies, University of Iowa, 105 Becker Communication Studies Building, Iowa City, IA, US, 52242, erin-brummett@uiowa.edu
Source:
Western Journal of Communication, Vol 79(1), Jan, 2015. pp. 22-44.
Page Count:
23
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Journal Titles:
Western Journal of Speech Communication
ISSN:
1057-0314 (Print)
1745-1027 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Intercultural, Interracial Romantic Relationships, Marginalization, Privacy Management, Social Support
Abstract:
This study uses communication privacy management theory (CPM; Petronio, 2002) to examine interracial romantic partners' privacy rule development criteria and privacy control tactics. Semistructured interviews (N = 27) were subjected to a thematic analysis. Results reveal that although interracial partners perceive societal opposition, many choose to disclose relational information to social network members. Participants experience power struggles with co-owners in managing their private, relational information, and their disclosures often follow sequences that align with relational turning points. Findings suggest that mixed-race couples frequently partake in both an interracial and intercultural identity, which carries with it additional opportunities for disclosure negotiations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Management; *Privacy; *Romance; *Social Support; Communication; Interracial Marriage; Relationship Quality; Sexual Partners; Marginalization
PsycINFO Classification:
Group & Interpersonal Processes (3020)

Database:

Record: 402
Title:
To see or not to see: Blinded by guilt: Reply to commentary.
Authors:
Bonovitz, Christopher, Faculty of Psychotherapy, William Alanson White Institute, Faculty New York University Postdoctoral Program in Psychotherapy & Psychoanalysis, New York, NY, US, chrisfb@nyc.rr.com
Address:
Bonovitz, Christopher, 119 Waverly Place, Ground Floor, New York, NY, US, 10011, chrisfb@nyc.rr.com
Source:
Psychoanalytic Dialogues, Vol 19(4), Jul, 2009. pp. 450-453.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Analytic Press
ISSN:
1048-1885 (Print)
1940-9222 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
negotiation, conflicts, culture, internalization, self–states, biracial patients, psychoanalytic theory
Abstract:
Reply by the current author on the comments made by Annabella Bushra (see record 2010-11288-009) on the original article (see record 2010-11288-008). In response to Annabella Bushra's discussion and her focus on what is missing in the clinical material, the author speculates about the repetition of the historical trauma of purifying mixed race in the face of its complexity—trying to neatly package race despite it not so neatly fitting into any one category—and losing the individual by overly focusing on skin color. The author considers the silence, secrecy, and transgression in the treatment and, in this context, a few of Bushra's key points are addressed—sorting out the nature of hate in relation to Susan, passing as transgression, and White guilt. A distinction is made between a malevolent, destructive hate and a loving hate, and White guilt is considered as a defense against recognition of the other. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

PsycINFO
Record: 403
Title:
Tobacco use among Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians/Pacific Islanders, and mixed-race individuals: 2002–2010.
Authors:
Wu, Li-Tzy, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US, litzy.wu@duke.edu
Swartz, Marvin S., Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US
Burchett, Bruce, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US
Blazer, Dan G., Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC, US
Institutional Authors:
National Institute on Drug Abuse Asian American and Pacific Islander (NIDA AAPI) Researchers and Scholars Workgroup, Bethesda, MD, US
Address:
Wu, Li-Tzy, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Duke University School of Medicine, Duke University Medical Center, Box 3903, Durham, NC, US, 27710, litzy.wu@duke.edu
Source:
Drug and Alcohol Dependence, Vol 132(1-2), Sep 1, 2013. pp. 87-94.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0376-8716 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
tobacco usage, racial & ethnic differences, chewing tobacco, prevalence, correlates, demographic factors
Abstract:
Background: Non-Hispanic Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians/Pacific Islanders (NHs/PIs), and mixed-race individuals are the fastest growing segments of the US population. We examined prevalences and correlates of tobacco use among these understudied groups. Prevalences among whites were included as a comparison. Methods: Data were drawn from the 2002–2010 National Surveys on Drug Use and Health. Respondents aged ≥12 years were assessed for current (past-month) use of cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco (chewing tobacco, snuff), and pipe tobacco. Respondents’ race/ethnicity, age, sex, household income, government assistance, urbanicity of residence, residential stability, self-rated health, alcohol use, and drug use were examined as correlates. Results: Between 2002 and 2010, there was a decline in the prevalence of cigarette smoking among whites (26.9% in 2002; 24.3% in 2010) and Asian Americans (18.0% in 2002; 11.1% in 2010). Prevalence of pipe tobacco use among mixed-race individuals increased from 0.2% in 2002 to 1.6% in 2010; there was little change in the prevalence of cigar and smokeless tobacco use in these racial/ethnic groups. Adjusted analyses showed that, compared with Asian Americans, mixed-race individuals had greater odds of using four tobacco products, and NHs/PIs had greater odds of using cigarettes, cigars, and smokeless tobacco. Regardless of race/ethnicity, male sex was a correlate of use of cigars, smokeless tobacco, and pipe tobacco; alcohol and drug use increased the odds of cigarette and cigar smoking. Conclusions: These new findings show prevalent tobacco use among NHs/PIs and mixed-race individuals, and highlight the importance of including these populations in future research and reporting. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Epidemiology; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Smokeless Tobacco; *Tobacco Smoking; Demographic Characteristics

PsycINFO
Record: 404
Title:
Trail Making Test and malingering among substance abusers.
Authors:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Roberts, Charles, Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockville, MD, US
Address:
Horton, Arthur MacNeill Jr., Substance Abuse & Mental Health Services Administration, Ctr for Substance Abuse Treatment, Rockwall II Building, Suite 840, 5600 Fishers Lane, Rockville, MD, US, 20857, ahorton@samhsa.gov
Source:
International Journal of Neuroscience, Vol 112(12), Dec, 2002. pp. 1489-1496.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Gordon & Breach Science Publishers, Inc.
US : Informa Healthcare
ISSN:
0020-7454 (Print)
1563-5279 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Trail Making Test, cognitive assessment, substance abuse, malingering, cutting scores
Abstract:
The Trail Making Test (TMT) is often used for screening cognitive impairments in substance abusers. A possible limitation of the TMT in clinical settings is that substance abusers may malinger and give poor effort. In this study, previously validated cutting scores for malingering were applied to a sample of 7,689 substance abusers (aged 18-44+ yrs) in drug abuse treatment programs. A mixed race sample was drawn from electronic files of data from the Drug Abuse Treatment Outcome Study. Data were analyzed to determine the number of substance abusers that fell beyond the preset malingering cutting scores on the TMT. Results indicate that the TMT variables of seconds to complete Part A and Part B, and the ratio score of Part B divided by Part A (B/A), ranged from no subjects beyond the preset cutting score for Part B to 2.28% for Part A to 9.74% for the ratio score. Most substance abusers fell within preset cutting score ranges, a finding that suggests that their scores are valid. Another interpretation of the data, however, is that the cutoff scores were not particularly sensitive to biased responding. Further research is indicated. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Cognitive Assessment; *Cutting Scores; *Drug Abuse; *Malingering
PsycINFO Classification:
Clinical Psychological Testing (2224)
Substance Abuse & Addiction (3233)

Record: 405
Title:
Transitions in current substance use from adolescence to early-adulthood.
Authors:
Mistry, Ritesh, Department of Health Behavior and Health Education, University of Michigan, School of Public Health, Ann Arbor, MI, US, riteshm@umich.edu
Heinze, Justin E., Department of Health Behavior and Health Education, University of Michigan, School of Public Health, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Cordova, David, School of Social Work, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Heish, Hsing-Fang, Department of Health Behavior and Health Education, University of Michigan, School of Public Health, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Goldstick, Jason E., Department of Emergency Medicine, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Ayer, Sophie M., Department of Health Behavior and Health Education, University of Michigan, School of Public Health, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Zimmerman, Marc A., Department of Health Behavior and Health Education, University of Michigan, School of Public Health, Ann Arbor, MI, US
Address:
Mistry, Ritesh, Department of Health Behavior and Health Education, University of Michigan, School of Public Health, 1415 Washington Heights, SPH I, Room 3806, Ann Arbor, MI, US, 48109-2029, riteshm@umich.edu
Source:
Journal of Youth and Adolescence, Vol 44(10), Oct, 2015. pp. 1871-1883.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
Germany : Springer
ISSN:
0047-2891 (Print)
1573-6601 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
alcohol, tobacco, marijuana, substance use, youth, longitudinal
Abstract:
Substance use behaviors do not occur in isolation of one another and are not static over time. As adolescents age into early adulthood, there may be dynamic changes in their substance use behaviors, and these changes may be influenced by family and school factors. The current study uses Latent Transition Analysis to examine these changes by measuring transitions among different substance use profiles based on past 30-day alcohol, tobacco and marijuana use, and by estimating associations with demographic, family and school factors. Data were from youth (n = 850; 80 % African American, 17 % white, 3 % mixed race, 50 % female and 50 % male) in grade 10 (Time 1), with 24- (Time 2) and 48-month (Time 3) follow-ups. Substance use profiles included Non-users (54 %), Alcohol and Marijuana Users (20 %), and Alcohol, Tobacco and Marijuana Users (26 %). There were considerable transitions among profiles from Time 1 to Time 2, and fewer transitions from Time 2 to Time 3. At Time 1, African American race and positive school attitudes were negatively associated with being an Alcohol and Marijuana User, and being an Alcohol, Tobacco and Marijuana User. Family conflict, parental school involvement, female gender and African American race were associated with transitions among substance use profiles. Implications are discussed for a better understanding of transitions in substance use profiles, and for promoting maintenance of non-use and transitions from substance using profiles to non-use. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adolescent Development; *Drug Usage; *Life Changes; Alcohols; Nicotine

Title:
Transracial adoptees: Developmental status after 17 years.
Authors:
Vroegh, Karen S., Chicago Child Care Society, Chicago, IL, US
Source:
American Journal of Orthopsychiatry, Vol 67(4), Oct, 1997. pp. 568-575.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
US : American Orthopsychiatric Association, Inc.
Other Publishers:
US : Educational Publishing Foundation
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0002-9432 (Print)
1939-0025 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial identity & self-esteem & general adjustment, Black adolescents adopted into White families, 14 yr study, implications for adoption policy & placement decisions
Abstract:
At the fifth phase of a longitudinal study of transracial adoption outcomes, 52 adolescents of black descent adopted in infancy were examined with respect to racial self-identity, general adjustment, and self-esteem. The 34 adolescents adopted into white families and the 18 adopted into black families identified themselves as black or of mixed race in similar proportions, and most were found to be well adjusted and to have good or very good self-esteem. The findings offer implications for adoption policy and placement decisions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Adopted Children; *Blacks; *Ethnic Identity; *Interracial Adoption; *Self Esteem; Adjustment; Adoption (Child); Cross Cultural Differences; Longitudinal Studies; Sociocultural Factors; Whites

Record: 407
Title:
Transracial adoption in Britain: A follow-up study, with policy considerations.
Authors:
Bagley, Christopher, City Polytechnic of Hong Kong, Kowloon, Hong Kong
Source:
Child Welfare: Journal of Policy, Practice, and Program, Vol 72(3), May-Jun, 1993. Special Issue: Adoption. pp. 285-299.
Page Count:
15
Publisher:
US : Child Welfare League of America
ISSN:
0009-4021 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
transracial adoption, self esteem & identity & adjustment, Afro Caribbean & mixed race children with Caucasian adoptive parents, England, 12 yr followup
Abstract:
Reports the findings of a British, 12-yr follow-up study (C. Bagley et al, 1979) of 27 Afro-Caribbean and mixed-race children (mean age 19 yrs) adopted by Caucasian parents, and 25 Caucasian children (mean age 19.2 yrs) adopted by same-race parents. Ss completed questionnaires, including the Crown-Crisp Experiential Index, Coopersmith Self-Esteem Inventories, and a measure of identity. Outcomes for both groups of adoptees in terms of adjustment and identity were generally excellent, although 10% of both groups had poor adjustment. There was no evidence from this or other studies that intercultural identity leads to unfavorable adjustment. Ss seemed well prepared by transracial adoption to participate effectively in a multicultural, multiracial society. Transracial adoptions should be considered for all children who cannot be placed inracially. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Adjustment; *Adoptees; *Interracial Family; *Self Concept; *Self Esteem; Adoption (Child); Adoptive Parents; Followup Studies
PsycINFO Classification:

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 408
Title:
Type 1 diabetes eHealth psychoeducation: Youth recruitment, participation, and satisfaction.
Authors:
Whittemore, Robin, Yale, School of Nursing, New Haven, CT, US, robin.whittemore@yale.edu
Jaser, Sarah S., Vanderbilt University, Department of Pediatrics, Nashville, TN, US
Faulkner, Melissa S., University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, US
Murphy, Kathryn, Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, Diabetes Center for Children, Philadelphia, PA, US
Delamater, Alan, University of Miami, Miami, FL, US
Grey, Margaret, Yale, School of Nursing, New Haven, CT, US
Institutional Authors:
TEENCOPE Research Group, US
Address:
Whittemore, Robin, Yale, School of Nursing, 100 Church Street South P.O. Box 9740, New Haven, CT, US, 06536-0740, robin.whittemore@yale.edu
Source:
Journal of Medical Internet Research, Vol 15(1), Jan, 2013. pp. 75-90.
Page Count:
16
Publisher:
Canada : Gunther Eysenbach
ISSN:
1438-8871 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
type 1 diabetes, eHealth psychoeducation, youth recruitment & participation & satisfaction
Abstract:
Background: The Internet and other eHealth technologies offer a platform for improving the dissemination and accessibility of psychoeducational programs for youth with chronic illness. However, little is known about the recruitment process and yield of diverse samples in Internet research with youth who have a chronic illness. Objective: The purpose of this study was to compare the demographic and clinical characteristics of youth with Type 1 diabetes on recruitment, participation, and satisfaction with 2 eHealth psychoeducational programs. Methods: Youth with Type 1 diabetes from 4 sites in the United States were invited to participate (N = 510) with 320 eligible youth consenting (mean age = 12.3, SD 1.1; 55.3% female; 65.2% white; and mean A1C = 8.3, SD 1.5). Data for this secondary analysis included demographic information (age, race/ethnicity, and income), depressive symptoms, and recruitment rates, including those who refused at point of contact (22.0%), passive refusers who consented but did not participate (15.3%), and those who enrolled (62.7%). Participation (80% lessons completed) and a satisfaction survey (ie, how helpful, enjoyable) were also analyzed. Chi-square or analysis of variance (ANOVA) analyses were used. Results: There were significant differences in recruitment rates by income and race/ethnicity such that black, Hispanic, or mixed race/ethnicity and low-income youth were more likely to refuse passively compared to white and higher-income youth who were more likely to enroll (P < .001). Participation in program sessions was high, with 78.1% of youth completing at least 4 of 5 sessions. There were no significant differences in participation by program, age, gender, or race/ethnicity. Low-income youth were less likely to participate (P = .002). Satisfaction in both programs was also high (3.9 of 5). There were significant gender, race/ethnicity, and income differences, in that girls (P = .001), black, Hispanic, or mixed race/ethnicity youth (P = .02), and low-income youth (P = .02) reported higher satisfaction. There were no differences in satisfaction by program or age. Conclusions: Results indicate that black, Hispanic, or mixed race/ethnicity youth and low-income youth with Type 1 diabetes are less likely to enroll in Internet-based research than white and higher-income youth; thus, creative recruitment approaches are needed. Low-income youth were less likely to participate, possibly due to access. However, once enrolled, youth of diverse race/ethnicity and low-income youth with Type 1 diabetes were as highly satisfied with the eHealth programs as white youth and those with higher income. Results suggest that eHealth programs have the potential to reach diverse youth and be appealing to them. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Diabetes; *Internet; *Psychoeducation; Participation; Satisfaction
PsycINFO Classification:
Promotion & Maintenance of Health & Wellness (3365)
Population:
Human
Male
Female
Location:
US
Age Group:
Childhood (birth-12 yrs)
School Age (6-12 yrs)
Adolescence (13-17 yrs)
Tests & Measures:
Children's Depression Inventory
Grant Sponsorship:
Sponsor: National Institute of Nursing Research
Grant Number: R01-NR04009
Recipients: Grey, Margaret (Prin Inv); Whittemore, Robin (Prin Inv)
Methodology:

Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:

Document Type:

First Posted: Jan 29, 2013; Accepted: Oct 2, 2012; Revised: Sep 10, 2012; First Submitted: May 10, 2012
Release Date:
20130826

Robin Whittemore, Sarah S. Jaser, Melissa S. Faulkner, Kathryn Murphy, Alan Delamater, Margaret Grey, TEENCOPE Research Group.

Title:
Understanding the Identities of Mixed-Race College Students Through a Developmental Ecology Lens.
Authors:
Renn, Kristen A., Higher, Adult, & Lifelong Education, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI, US, renn@msu.edu
Address:
Renn, Kristen A., Higher, Adult, & Lifelong Education, Michigan State University, 428 Erickson Hall, East Lansing, MI, US, 48824-1034, renn@msu.edu
Source:
Journal of College Student Development, Vol 44(3), May-Jun, 2003. pp. 383-403.
Page Count:
21
Publisher:
US : ACPA Executive Office
Other Journal Titles:
Journal of College Student Personnel
ISSN:
0897-5264 (Print)
1543-3382 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed race identity, racial identities, human development, college students, mixed race students, multiple racial heritages, developmental ecology, environmental interaction
Abstract:
Using an ecology model of human development (Bronfenbrenner, 1979, 1993), I frame the exploration of racial identities of 38 college students with multiple racial heritages. I map the influence of interactions within and between specific environments on students' decisions to identify in one or more of five patterns of mixed race identity found in a previous study. PsycINFO
Record: 410
Title:
Unmixing for race making in Brazil.
Authors:
Bailey, Stanley R., University of California, Irvine, CA, US, bailey@uci.edu
Address:
Bailey, Stanley R., University of California, Department of Sociology, 3151 Social Science Plaza, Irvine, CA, US, 92697-5100, bailey@uci.edu
Source:
American Journal of Sociology, Vol 114(3), Nov, 2008. pp. 577-614.
Page Count:
38
Publisher:
US : Univ of Chicago Press
ISSN:
0002-9602 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race targeted policy, racism, Brazil
Abstract:
This article analyzes race-targeted policy in Brazil as both a political stake and a powerful instrument in an unfolding classificatory struggle over the definition of racial boundaries. The Brazilian state traditionally embraced mixed-race classification, but is adopting racial quotas employing a black/white scheme. To explore potential consequences of that turn for beneficiary identification and boundary formation, the author analyzes attitudinal survey data on race-targeted policy and racial classification in multiple formats, including classification in comparison to photographs. The results show that almost half of the mixed-race sample, when constrained to dichotomous classification, opts for whiteness, a majority rejects mixed-race individuals for quotas, and the mention of quotas for blacks in a split-ballot experiment nearly doubles the percentage choosing that racial category. Theories of how states make race emphasize the use of official categories to legislate exclusion. In contrast, analysis of the Brazilian case illuminates how states may also make race through policies of official inclusion. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Policy Making; *Racism
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:
Human
Location:
Brazil
Tests & Measures:
General Social Survey
British Social Attitudes Survey
Methodology:

Electronic

Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal

PsycINFO
Record: 411
Title:
Variables de riesgo para la infección por VIH: Análsis comparative, en función del género, entre adolescetes indígenas y mestizo mexicanos.
Translated Title:
Risk variables for the transmission of HIV: Comparative analysis, based on gender, among Wixaritari indigenous and mixed race Mexican adolescents.
Authors:
Ramiro, María Teresa, Universidad de Granada, Facultad de Psicologia, Granada, Spain
Falomir, Liliana López, Consejo Estatal para la Prevencion del Sida en Jalisco, COESIDA, Jalisco, Mexico
Bermúdez, María Paz, Universidad de Granada, Facultad de Ciencias de la Educacion, Granada, Spain, maripaz@ugr.es
Source:
Revista Argentina de Clínica Psicológica, Vol 20(2), Aug, 2011. pp. 143-150.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
Argentina : Fundación AIGLÉ
ISSN:
0327-6716 (Print)
Language:
Spanish; Castilian
Keywords:
gender differences, HIV, AIDS prevention, condoms
Abstract:
The current study was conducted to carry out a comparative analysis, based on gender, considering several risk variables for the transmission of HIV amongst Wixaritari indigenous and mixed race Mexicans adolescents. A sample of 300 students between 14 to 19 years old was selected, of which 107 were Wixaritari indigenous and 193 were mixed race from the north of Jalisco, Mexico. Assessed variables were knowledge about HIV/STI, locus of control for the HIV infection, concern about HIV/STI and attitudes towards condom use. Statistically significant differences based on gender were found, in the variables internal locus of control, attitudes towards condom use and knowledge about HIV/STI. We did not find differences in the variable concern about HIV/STI. Wixaritari indigenous adolescents, regardless of gender, are exposed to a higher level of risk of HIV infection than mixed race adolescents. It is necessary to keep on researching about other variables that could intervene in preventive behavior in indigenous population, and make HIV prevention programs suitable for the population. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*AIDS Prevention; *HIV; *Human Sex Differences; *Indigenous Populations; *Risk Factors; Condoms

Promotion & Maintenance of Health & Wellness (3365)

Mexico

Title:
Voice of the voiceless? Multiethnic student voices in critical approaches to race, pedagogy, literacy and agency.
Authors:
Chang, Benji, Teachers College, Columbia University, New York, NY, US, benjamin.chang@tc.columbia.edu
Address:
Chang, Benji, Department of Curriculum & Teaching, Teachers College, Columbia University, Box 107, 525 West 120th Street, New York, NY, US, 10027-6696, benjamin.chang@tc.columbia.edu
Source:
Linguistics and Education, Vol 24(3), Sep, 2013. pp. 348-360.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0898-5898 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
multiethnicity, student voices, racial differences, pedagogy, literacy, agency, sociocultural approaches
Abstract:
In this article, the author utilizes critical and sociocultural approaches to race, language and culture to examine the intersectional experiences of a multiethnic and ‘mixed race’ cohort of students in an inner-city, working-class neighborhood between their elementary and high school years. This article examines the students’ experiences in a nine-year educational process focused on critical pedagogy, sociocultural learning, and community engagement in and out of classrooms. More specifically, the article looks at interview, participant observation, and narrative data with a Latina/o and Asian American male student, and an Asian American female student, and how they made sense of their experiences over time with regards to issues of race, pedagogy, literacy, and agency. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Title:
Voices from the movement: Approaches to multiraciality.
Authors:
Nakashima, Cynthia L., U California, Berkeley, CA, US
Source:
The multiracial experience: Racial borders as the new frontier. Root, Maria P. P. (Ed); pp. 79-97; Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; 1996. xxviii, 481 pp.
Page Count:
19
ISBN:
0-8039-7058-7 (Hardcover)
0-8039-7059-5 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
mixed race movement & perspectives on & approaches to multiraciality
Abstract:
within the mixed-race movement, as in any social movement, there are differing perspectives on and approaches to the various issues / in examining the ideologies expressed in the dialogue on multiraciality, I have identified the following 3 approaches, or "voices" as dominating the discourse: 1. the struggle for inclusion and legitimacy in the "traditional" racial/ethnic communities / 2. the shaping of a shared identity and common agenda among racially mixed people into a new multiracial community / 3. the struggle to dismantle dominant racial ideology and group boundaries and to create connections across communities into a community of humanity discuss each of these approaches to and perspectives on multiraciality and . . . consider the ideological and practical issues and conflicts that have occurred or might occur between them / make the argument that each is legitimate, and in fact, central to the movement itself / attempt to demonstrate how the 3 voices can be viewed as dimensions rather than divisions, both of the movement and of the experience of multiraciality / suggest that as dimensions, the 3 voices not only can peacefully coexist, but they can function to serve as a system of "checks and balances" in order to avoid what many consider to be potential dangers of the mixed-race movement (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (chapter)

Record: 414
Title:
'What are you?': Explaining identity as a goal of the multiracial Hapa movement.
Authors:
Bernstein, Mary, University of Connecticut, Storrs, CT, US, Mary.Bernstein@uconn.edu
De la Cruz, Marcie, Empirical Education Inc., Palo Alto, CA, US, marcie.delacruz@gmail.com
Address:
Bernstein, Mary, Department of Sociology, University of Connecticut, 344 Mansfield Rd., Storrs, CT, US, 06269-2068, Mary.Bernstein@uconn.edu
Source:
Social Problems, Vol 56(4), Nov, 2009. pp. 722-745.
Page Count:
24
Publisher:
US : University of California Press
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Oxford University Press
ISSN:
0037-7791 (Print)
1533-8533 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
identity, Multiracial Hapa movement, social movements
Abstract:
This article uses the Hapa movement as a case study in order to provide a framework for understanding identity as a goal of social movements and to expand on a theoretical understanding of multiracial social movements. In contrast to current understandings of identity-based movements, this article argues that the Hapa movement seeks simultaneously to deconstruct traditional notions of (mono)racial identities and to secure recognition for a multiracial “Hapa” identity. Movements that have identity as a goal are motivated by activists’ understandings of how categories are constituted and how those categories, codes, and ways of thinking serve as axes of regulation and domination. The Hapa movement simultaneously challenges (mono)racial categories at both the institutional level through targeting the state and at the micro level through challenging the quotidian enactment of race and promulgating a Hapa identity. Activism by mixed-race individuals and organizations constitutes an important challenge to power that has significant implications for racial categorization and classification in contemporary American society. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Social Change; *Social Identity; *Social Movements; *Multiculturalism
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)

Record: 415
Title:
What does 'White' mean? Interpreting the choice of 'race' by mixed race young people in Britain.
Authors:
Song, Miri, University of Kent, Kent, United Kingdom, a.m.song@kent.ac.uk
Hashem, Ferhana, University of Kent, Kent, United Kingdom
Address:
Song, Miri, Cornwallis NE, Canterbury, Canterbury, Kent, United Kingdom, CT2 7NF, a.m.song@kent.ac.uk
Source:
Sociological Perspectives, Vol 53(2), Sum 2010. pp. 287-292.
Page Count:
6
Publisher:
US : University of California Press
Other Journal Titles:
Pacific Sociological Review
Other Publishers:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0731-1214 (Print)
1533-8673 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial identity, Britain, public policy, Whites, multiracial respondents
Abstract:
Despite the often cited idea that racial identities are socially constructed, and potentially fluid, much public policy is still based on surveys that elicit only one measure of racial identity. A number of U.S. studies have employed “best single race” questions on racial identification, in which multiracial respondents are asked to choose only one race to describe themselves. We extend some American studies by examining responses to a “best single race” survey question posed to a small sample of multiracial young people in Britain. In-depth interviews with British multiracial respondents are employed to investigate the extent to which a “best single race” (BSR) question captures someone’s sense of attachment and belonging to a particular ethnic or racial group. In particular, we focus on how we should interpret East Asian/white respondents’ choice of “white” as their BSR. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Government Policy Making; *Interracial Offspring; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; *Whites; Racism

Title:
What happens after segmented assimilation? An exploration of intermarriage and 'mixed race' young people in Britain.
Authors:
Song, Miri, University of Kent, Canterbury, United Kingdom, a.m.song@kent.ac.uk
Address:
Song, Miri, University of Kent, Kent, Canterbury, United Kingdom, CT2 7NF, a.m.song@kent.ac.uk
Source:
Ethnic and Racial Studies, Vol 33(7), Jul, 2010. pp. 1194-1213.
Page Count:
20
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0141-9870 (Print)
1466-4356 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
segmented assimilation, intermarriage, Britain, ethnic social networks
Abstract:
Theorizing on segmented assimilation has usefully spurred debate about the experiences and positions of the second generation in the US and, more recently, Europe. This theory has focused primarily on how young people fare in secondary school and the crucial role that families and ethnic social networks can play in supporting second-generation individuals. But what happens when young people leave home and enter into mainstream higher education institutions? Theorizing on segmented assimilation does not address either the implications of intermarriage for integration and upward mobility or how we should conceptualize the experiences of the growing numbers of ‘mixed race’ individuals. In this paper, I first consider the question of whether intermarriage is linked with upward mobility in the British context. I then explore the racial identifications and experiences of disparate types of mixed race young people in Britain. How do such young people identify themselves, and what may their identifications reveal about their sense of belonging in Britain? (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Acculturation; *Exogamous Marriage; *Racial and Ethnic Groups; *Social Networks
PsycINFO Classification:
Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)
Population:
Human
Location:
Great Britain
Format Covered:
Electronic
Publication Type:
Journal; Peer Reviewed Journal
Document Type:
Journal Article
Release Date:
20100802
Copyright:
Taylor & Francis. 2010
Digital Object Identifier:
http://dx.doi.org.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/10.1080/01419871003625271
Accession Number:
2010-12961-004
Number of Citations in Source:
48
UR:
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2010-12961-004&site=ehost-live&scope=site
Persistent link to this record (Permalink):
https://libproxy-cc-stonybrook-edu.proxy.library.stonybrook.edu/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=psyh&AN=2010-12961-004&site=ehost-live&scope=site

An exploration of intermarriage and 'mixed race' young people in Britain.</A>
Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 417
Title:
When Memory Shifts Toward More Typical Category Exemplars: Accentuation Effects in the Recollection of Ethnically Ambiguous Faces.
Authors:
Corneille, Olivier, Department of Psychology, Catholic University of Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium, olivier.corneille@psp.ucl.ac.be
Huart, Johanne, Department of Psychology, Catholic University of Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, France
Becquart, Emilie, Department of Psychology, Catholic University of Louvain, Louvain-la-Neuve, France
Brédart, Serge, Department of Psychology, University of Liège, Liège, Belgium
Address:
Corneille, Olivier, Catholic University of Louvain, PSP-PSOR, 10, Place du Cardinal Mercier, B-1348, Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium, olivier.corneille@psp.ucl.ac.be
Source:
Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, Vol 86(2), Feb, 2004. pp. 236-250.
Page Count:

Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
ISSN:
0022-3514 (Print)
1939-1315 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
categorization, face recollection, ethnically ambiguous faces, ethnic features, memory distortion
Abstract:
In 4 studies, the authors examined the impact of categorization on the recollection of ethnically ambiguous faces. Participants were presented with faces lying at various locations on mixed-race continua (i.e., Caucasian-North African and Caucasian-Asian faces were used as source images in a morphing program). In all studies, the prevalence of exclusive ethnic features in a face distorted participants' recollections of the face toward faces more typical of the category. Specifically, the recollection of 30% North African (or 30% Asian) faces shifted toward Caucasian source faces, whereas the recollection of 70% North African (or 70% Asian) faces shifted toward North African (Asian) source faces. Memory distortions did not emerge for extremely ambiguous (50%) faces and proved larger on mixed-race than same-race continua (Studies 3 and 4). Memory distortions also emerged with high levels of confidence. The authors elaborate on the theoretical and practical implications of these findings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Classification (Cognitive Process); *Face Perception; *Memory; *Recall (Learning); *Stimulus Ambiguity; False Memory; Racial and Ethnic Groups
PsycINFO Classification:
Learning & Memory (2343)
Population:
Human
Location:
Belgium

Record: 418
Title:
Whiteness as stigma: Essentialist identity work by mixed-race women.
Authors:
Storrs, Debbie, U Idaho, Dept of Anthropology/Sociology, Moscow, ID, US
Source:
Symbolic Interaction, Vol 22(3), 1999. pp. 187-212.
Page Count:
26
Publisher:
US : University of California Press
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0195-6086 (Print)
1533-8665 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social process of racial identity formation, mixed-race females
Abstract:
Explains the reversal of the racial mixing problem as well as the identity work of women as they rearticulate the meaning of race and racial belonging within dominant racial logic. The identification of macro constraints and the illustration of individual agency in the negotiation of identity extends the symbolic interactionist perspective on identity formation. The author captures the micro level social process of racial formation through an analysis of women's ability to rearticulate the meaning of stigma. This research also adds to the symbolic interactionist literature that emphasizes face-to-face interaction, the micro processes, in the construction of self by revealing the dynamic interplay between macro and micro processes in the development of racial identity. The date used are drawn from a larger study that examines the racial and gendered identity constructions of 27 mixed-race women living in the US. The women in this study reject dominant patterns of stigma by reassigning stigma to their European ancestry. Given this reversal, women articulate and embrace non-white identities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

*Interracial Offspring; *Race (Anthropological); *Self Concept; *Social Identity; *Social Processes

Title:
Whiteness in Latina immigrants: A Venezuelan perspective.
Authors:
Padrón, Elena, California School of Professional Psychology, Alliant International University, San Francisco, CA, US, epadron@alliant.edu
Address:
Padrón, Elena, California School of Professional Psychology, Alliant International University, 1 Beach Street, Suite 100, San Francisco, CA, US, 94133, epadron@alliant.edu
Source:
Women & Therapy, Vol 38(3-4), Oct, 2015. pp. 194-206.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
Other Publishers:
US : Haworth Press
ISSN:
0270-3149 (Print)
1541-0315 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Latin America, psychotherapy, race, Venezuela, whiteness, women
Abstract:
This article examines the construct of Whiteness in Venezuela, which requires a framework that differs from the fixed racial categories commonly used in the United States. In Venezuela, where most citizens are of mixed race and where the concept of race is fluid, race and racism take on more complex forms that include dimensions such as social class, eye color, family, education, and even manners. This means that Whiteness and privilege do not always go hand in hand. I discuss ways in which this culturally defined notion of race can be incorporated into psychotherapy with Latina immigrants to the United States. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

*Attitudes; *Ethnic Identity; *Immigration; *Racism; *Latinos/Latinas; Psychotherapists; Psychotherapy

Record: 420
Title:
Who are the Whites? Imposed census categories and the racial demography of Brazil.
Authors:
Harris, Marvin, U Florida, US
Consorte, Josildeth G.
Lang, Joseph
Byrne, Bryan
Source:
Social Forces, Vol 72(2), Dec, 1993. pp. 451-462.
Page Count:
12
Publisher:
US : University of North Carolina Press
ISSN:
0037-7732 (Print)
1534-7605 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
use of morena vs parda as racial category in census, self identification as Black vs White vs mixed race, residents, Brazil
Abstract:
Tested the consequences of ignoring or overriding the distinctive features of the cognitive system by which Brazilians express their race/color identities. A salient vernacular term (morena) was substituted for the seldom-used term (parda) that the Brazilian census offers as self-identification for a person who has both Black and White color/race features. When morena was offered in a split census, the proportion of respondents who self-identified as being of mixed color/race substantially increased while the proportion identifying as White or Black substantially declined. Findings suggest an error of imposing on the rest of the hemisphere rigid dichotomous (White/non-White) or trichotomous (White/mixed/Black) categories deemed appropriate for establishing racial identity in the US. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Ethnic Identity; *Race (Anthropological); *Terminology; Data Collection; Demographic Characteristics

Title:
Who are we? Producing group identity through everyday practices of conflict and discourse.
Authors:
Jones, Jennifer A., University of California, Berkeley, CA, US, jjones@berkeley.edu
Address:
Jones, Jennifer A., 410 Barrows Hall, Berkeley, CA, US, 94720-1980, jjones@berkeley.edu
Source:
Sociological Perspectives, Vol 54(2), Sum 2011. pp. 139-162.
Page Count:
24
Publisher:
US : University of California Press
Other Journal Titles:
Pacific Sociological Review
Other Publishers:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0731-1214 (Print)
1533-8673 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
group identity, conflict, discourse, ingroup diversity, ethnographic research, multiracial identity
Abstract:
Multiracials have the flexibility to opt out of multiracial identity, to shift identities depending on context, and are characterized by in-group diversity. Given this fluid space, how do multiracials come to see themselves as a collective? This article describes an empirical example of collectivization processes at work. Specifically, the author observed the process of collective identity-building through ethnographic research in a mixed-race student-run organization. This case study indicates that group identity formation is a negotiated process involving strategies to achieve a sense of belonging and cohesion. The author shows that over time, by using experiences of social conflict to construct shared experiences, the members of this mixed-race organization developed collective identity. In so doing, their experience underscores how collective identity development is socially constructed and how micropractices are essential components of group formation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Conflict; *Ethnic Identity; *Ethnography; Discourse Analysis; Ingroup Outgroup

Title:
Who is black, white, or mixed race? How skin color, status, and nation shape racial classification in Latin America.
Authors:
Telles, Edward, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, US, etelles@princeton.edu
Paschel, Tianna, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL, US
Address:
Telles, Edward, Deparment of Sociology, Princeton University, 151 Wallace Hall, Princeton, NJ, US, 08544, etelles@princeton.edu
Source:
American Journal of Sociology, Vol 120(3), Nov, 2014. pp. 864-907.
Page Count:
44
Publisher:
US : Univ of Chicago Press
ISSN:
0002-9602 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
racial classification, skin color, country variations, socioeconomic status, Latin America, Blacks, Whites
Abstract:
Comparative research on racial classification has often turned to Latin America, where race is thought to be particularly fluid. Using nationally representative data from the 2010 and 2012 America’s Barometer survey, the authors examine patterns of self-identification in four countries. National differences in the relation between skin color, socioeconomic status, and race were found. Skin color predicts race closely in Panama but loosely in the Dominican Republic. Moreover, despite the dominant belief that money whitens, the authors discover that status polarizes (Brazil), mestizoizes (Colombia), darkens (Dominican Republic), or has no effect (Panama). The results show that race is both physical and cultural, with country variations in racial schema that reflect specific historical and political trajectories. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2015 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Countries; *Ethnic Identity; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Latinos/Latinas; Color; Interracial Offspring; Socioeconomic Status; Whites

Title:
Who is the fairest of them all? Race, attractiveness and skin color sexual dimorphism.
Authors:
Lewis, Michael B., School of Psychology, Cardiff University, Cardiff, United Kingdom, Lewismb@cf.ac.uk
Address:
Lewis, Michael B., School of Psychology, Cardiff University, Park Place, Cardiff, United Kingdom, CF10 3AT, Lewismb@cf.ac.uk
Source:
Personality and Individual Differences, Vol 50(2), Jan, 2011. pp. 159-162.
Page Count:
4
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0191-8869 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race, attractiveness, skin color, sexual dimorphism, personality
Abstract:
Previous research has suggested that perceived attractiveness and personality are affected by the race such that White faces are more attractive but less masculine than Black faces. Such studies, however, have been based on very small stimulus sets. The current study investigated perceived attractiveness and personality for 600 Black, White and mixed-race faces. Many of the investigated personality traits were correlated with race when rated by White participants. Attractiveness specifically was greater for Black male faces than White male faces and among mixed-race faces. Blackness correlated with increased attractiveness. A reverse pattern was found for female faces with Whiteness being associated with attractiveness. The results are discussed in terms of the sexual dimorphism demonstrated in skin color. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

Record: 424
Title:
Why Barack Obama is Black: A cognitive account of hypodescent.
Authors:
Halberstadt, Jamin, University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand, jhalbers@psy.otago.ac.nz
Sherman, Steven J., Indiana University, Bloomington, IN, US
Sherman, Jeffrey W., University of California, Davis, CA, US
Address:
Halberstadt, Jamin, University of Otago, Department of Psychology, P.O. Box 56, Dunedin, New Zealand, 9054, jhalbers@psy.otago.ac.nz
Source:
Psychological Science, Vol 22(1), Jan, 2011. pp. 29-33.
Page Count:
5
Publisher:
US : Sage Publications
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Blackwell Publishing
United Kingdom : Wiley-Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
ISSN:
0956-7976 (Print)
1467-9280 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
Barack Obama, blacks, hypodescent, minority groups, cognitive processes, learning, categorization
Abstract:
We propose that hypodescent—the assignment of mixed-race individuals to a minority group—is an emergent feature of basic cognitive processes of learning and categorization. According to attention theory, minority groups are learned by attending to the features that distinguish them from previously learned majority groups. Selective attention creates a strong association between minority groups and their distinctive features, producing a tendency to see individuals who possess a mixture of majority- and minority-group traits as minority-group members. Two experiments on face categorization, using both naturally occurring and manipulated minority groups, support this view, suggesting that hypodescent need not be the product of racist or political motivations, but can be sufficiently explained by an individual’s learning history. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Blacks; *Minority Groups; Cognitive Processes; Learning
PsycINFO Classification:
Culture & Ethnology (2930)
Population:

Male
Female
Location:
New Zealand

Adolescence (13-17 yrs)
Adulthood (18 yrs & older)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 425
Title:
Winter setback: The racial composition of schools and learning to read.
Authors:
Entwisle, Doris R., Johns Hopkins U, Dept of Sociology, Baltimore, MD, US
Alexander, Karl L.
Source:
American Sociological Review, Vol 59(3), Jun, 1994. pp. 446-460.
Page Count:
15
Publisher:
US : American Sociological Assn
Other Publishers:
US : Sage Publications
ISSN:
0003-1224 (Print)
1939-8271 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
reading comprehension gains during winter vs summer, Black vs White elementary school students attending segregated vs integrated schools
Abstract:
Explored the growth in reading comprehension (RDC) over the 1st 2 yrs of school among a mixed-race random sample of children in Baltimore, Maryland. Black Ss in integrated schools made less progress in RDC in winter than did their counterparts in segregated schools. In summers, however, when they were not in school, the Black Ss who attended integrated schools gained more than their counterparts who attended segregated schools. White Ss made about the same progress in RDC in integrated and segregated schools in winters and summers, even though the Whites in integrated schools came from more educationally advantaged families. Ss of both races in integrated schools, who came from more educated families, did not make the expected gains in RDC when school was open. In summers, however, Ss whose parents had more education forged ahead of those whose parents were high school dropouts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Academic Achievement; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Reading Comprehension; *School Attendance; *School Integration; Blacks; Elementary School Students; Whites
PsycINFO Classification:
Academic Learning & Achievement (3550)

Persistent link to this record (Permalink):

PsycINFO
Record: 426
Title:
Women and the psychotherapeutic 'color line'.
Authors:
Reid, Pamela Trotman, City University of New York, Graduate School and University Center, New York, NY, US
Bing, Vanessa
Source:
PsycCRITIQUES, Vol 41 (1), Jan, 1996. pp. 19-20.
Page Count:
2
Publisher:
US : American Psychological Association
Reviewed Item:
Comas-Diaz, Lillian (Ed); Greene, Beverly (Ed). (1994) Women of Color: Integrating Ethnic and Gender Identities in Psychotherapy New York: Guilford Press, 1994. 518 pp. $44.95 0-89862-371-5.
ISSN:
1554-0138 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
psychotherapy, female clients, minority groups, stereotyped attitudes, segregation
Abstract:
Originally published in Contemporary Psychology: APA Review of Books, 1996, Vol 41(1), 19-20. Is there a "color line" in psychotherapy? Certainly there are stereotypes developed and preserved by psychological theorists and therapists that serve as expressions of established expectations and assumptions. These have, it is argued in this book (see record 1994-98466-000), prevented adequate treatment and service delivery to women who do not fit their image of a model client. The color line, a term drawn from recent U.S. history, was an actual demarcation drawn down hallways and waiting rooms to keep "colored people" (as Blacks and others were designated) separate from Whites as part of enforced segregation. This compendium of conceptual analyses, case examples, and suggestions for therapy invites those who would address the therapeutic needs of women to consider change. The goal of this book, which is well conceived and carefully organized, is to alert therapists to the changing realities of the U.S. demographics and prepare them to deliver services to an increasingly diverse population. This book makes a respectable effort at covering the topics of importance for women of the major ethnic groups now in the United States. As it stands, they include chapters on at least six ethnic groups (African Americans, American Indians, Asians, Latinas, women from the Caribbean, and women from India) and five special populations (professionals, lesbians, women of mixed race, refugees, and women who are battered). If there is any major omission, it is the surprising lack of any detailed discussion of the therapist-client relationship. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Clients; *Human Females; *Minority Groups; *Psychotherapy; *Social Integration; Stereotyped Attitudes
PsycINFO Classification:

Social Processes & Social Issues (2900)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 427
Title:
Women in interracial relationships.
Authors:
Faulkner, Janette, U California, Langley Porter Neuropsychiatric Inst, San Francisco
Source:
Women & Therapy, Vol 2(2-3), Sum-Fal 1983. Special Issue: Women changing therapy: New assessments, values and strategies in feminist therapy. pp. 191-203.
Page Count:
13
Publisher:
US : Haworth Press
Other Publishers:
United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
ISSN:
0270-3149 (Print)
1541-0315 (Electronic)
Language:
English
Keywords:
social support group concerns & experiences & activities, females in interracial relationships
Abstract:
Describes the activities, experiences, and concerns of members of 7 support groups that helped participants work on issues related to different- or mixed-race living during a 3-yr period. 25 White, 12 Black, and 1 Chinese Ss lived with partners and/or children of a different or mixed race. Initial group encounters were intellectual and somewhat educational as Ss shared their life experiences. Armoring was used by Black and other Ss of color to promote self-caring during direct encounters with racist experiences. Co-leaders of the group were a Black clinician (the author) paired with a graduate student who had or was experiencing a mixed race relationship. Most Ss moved to the host environment of the spouse upon marriage. Group activity focused on establishing a definite identity for children and reinforcing it with models to support pridefulness. Group concerns about childrearing practices were racial: White Ss were criticized for being too permissive with children, and Black Ss were criticized by spouses for being too strict and by their families for being too permissive. Ss needed support and clarification around the question of what is developmental and what is cultural. Ss were trained to take leadership roles and continued meeting in their homes. A 5-item bibliography is appended. (1 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
Subjects:
*Couples; *Human Females; *Interracial Marriage; *Racial and Ethnic Differences; *Social Support
PsycINFO Classification:
Health & Mental Health Services (3370)
Population:

Female

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 428
Title:
Working with issues of race in counselling.
Authors:
Dupont-Joshua, Aisha, Lambeth Coll, London, United Kingdom
Source:
Multicultural counselling: A reader. Palmer, Stephen (Ed); pp. 21-26; Thousand Oaks, CA, US: Sage Publications, Inc; 2002. xvii, 280 pp.
Page Count:
6
ISBN:
0-7619-6375-8 (Hardcover)
0-7619-6376-6 (Paperback)
Language:
English
Keywords:
race, counseling, therapy development, counselor attitudes
Abstract:
This reprinted article originally appeared in Counselling, Journal of the British Association for Counselling, 1997, 8(4), 282-284. The author focuses on how to work with issues of race in counseling. She refers to relevant models to help counselors access the different development stages that the counselor and client may have attained that aid understanding of the dynamics which may emerge during counseling. A case study of a young man of mixed race is provided to illustrate how the author's attitudes influenced the tone of the relationship. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (introduction)

Database:
PsycINFO
Record: 429
Title:
Young adult injection drug users in the United States continue to practice HIV risk behaviors.
Authors:
Rondinelli, Amanda J., San Diego State University, Graduate School of Public Health, San Diego, CA, US
Ouellet, Lawrence J., University of Illinois at Chicago, School of Public Health, Division of Epidemiology and Biostatistics (MC 923), Chicago, IL, US
Strathdee, Steffanie A., University of California San Diego, School of Medicine, San Diego, CA, US
Latka, Mary H., Aurum Institute for Health Research, Johannesburg, South Africa
Hudson, Sharon M., Health Research Association, Hollywood, CA, US
Hagan, Holly, National Development and Research Institutes, New York, NY, US
Garfein, Richard S., Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Division of HIV/AIDS Prevention, Atlanta, GA, US, rgarfein@ucsd.edu
Address:
Garfein, Richard S., Division of Global Public Health, Department Medicine, University of California San Diego School of Medicine, 9500 Gilman Drive, Mailstop 0507, San Diego, CA, US, 92093-0507, rgarfein@ucsd.edu
Source:
Drug and Alcohol Dependence, Vol 104(1-2), Sep 1, 2009. pp. 167-174.
Page Count:
8
Publisher:
Netherlands : Elsevier Science
ISSN:
0376-8716 (Print)
Language:
English
Keywords:
young adults, injection drug users, HIV risk, sexual practices, drug usage
Abstract:
Background: Injection drug users (IDUs) are at risk of acquiring HIV through injection and sexual practices. Methods: We analyzed data collected in five U.S. cities between 2002 and 2004 to identify correlates of HIV infection among 3285 IDUs ages 15–30 years. Results: Overall, HIV prevalence was 2.8% (95% CI 2.3–3.4), ranging from 0.8% in Chicago to 6.3% in Los Angeles. Mean age was 24 years, 70% were male, 64% non-Hispanic (NH) white, 7% NH black, 17% Hispanic, and 12% were other/mixed race. HIV infection was independently associated with: race/ethnicity (NH black [AOR 4.1, 95% CI 1.9–9.1], Hispanic [AOR 3.6, 95% CI 1.5–8.4], or other/mixed [AOR 2.3, 95% CI 1.1–5.2] vs. NH white); males who only had sex with males compared to males who only had sex with females (AOR 15.3, 95% CI 6.8–34.5); injecting methamphetamine alone or with heroin compared to heroin only (AOR 4.0, 95% CI 1.7–9.7); reporting inconsistent means of obtaining income compared to regular jobs (AOR 2.3, 95% CI 1.1–4.8); and having a history of exchanging sex for money/drugs (AOR 2.8, 95% CI 1.5–5.2). Conclusions: More than two decades after injection and sexual practices were identified as risk factors for HIV infection, these behaviors remain common among young IDUs. While racial/ethnic disparities persist, methamphetamine may be replacing cocaine as the drug most associated with HIV seropositivity. HIV prevention interventions targeting young IDUs and address both sexual and injection practices are needed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
Subjects:
*Drug Self Administration; *Drug Usage; *HIV; *Risk Factors
PsycINFO Classification:
